revision.text:
{{Infobox non-profit | name = AIGA |abbreviation = | image =Aiga logo.svg | caption =AIGA logo | map = | map_size = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | map_alt = <!-- map alt text --> | map_caption = | map2 = | type =Professional Association | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = --> | registration_id = | founded_date = {{start date|1914}} | founder = | predecessor = | dissolved = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merged = | successor = | location =Headquarters in [[New York City]]<ref name="AIGA-about">{{cite web|url=http://www.aiga.org/About/|title=About AIGA|publisher=}}</ref> | addnl_location =73 chapters across the country<ref name="AIGA-chapters">{{cite web|url=http://www.aiga.org/chapters/|title=Find a chapter|publisher=}}</ref> | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | origins = | key_people =Board President Dana Arnett<ref name="AIGA-board">{{cite web|url=http://www.aiga.org/board-of-directors/|title=AIGA board of directors|publisher=}}</ref> | area_served =[[United States]] | products = | services = | focus = | mission = | method = | revenue = | disbursed = | expenses = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = over 22,000<ref name="AIGA-about"/> | affiliations = | subsid = | languages =[[English language|English]] | owner = | motto = | formerly = | website = {{url|aiga.org}} | footnotes = }} '''The American Institute of Graphic Arts (AIGA)''' is a [[professional organization]] for [[design]].<ref name="AIGA-about"/><ref name="aiga_name_history">{{cite web | url = http://www.aiga.org/content.cfm/about-name | title = AIGA name}}</ref> Its members practice all forms of [[communication design]], including [[graphic design]], [[typography]], [[interaction design]], branding and identity. The organization's aim is to be the standard bearer for professional ethics and practices for the design profession.<ref name="AIGA-about"/><ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vupkAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA182&lpg=PA182&dq=aiga+history&source=bl&ots=RJmQFAlbAY&sig=XL7NVUPaZl9O2l4TDjF9NZWnyHI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi0uIra7ezPAhWoxYMKHf9lDao4MhDoAQg7MAY#v=onepage&q=aiga%20history&f=false|title=History of the Mass Media in the United States: An Encyclopedia|last=Blanchard|first=Margaret A.|date=2013-12-19|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135917425|language=en}}</ref> There are currently over 22,000 members and 73 chapters, and more than 200 student groups around the United States.{{fact|date=February 2017}}
==History== In 1911, [[Frederic Goudy]], [[Alfred Stieglitz]], and [[William Addison Dwiggins|W. A. Dwiggins]] came together to discuss the creation of an organization that was committed to individuals passionate about communication design.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://madmuseum.org/series/aiga|title=AIGA|website=madmuseum.org|access-date=2016-10-21}}</ref> In 1913, president of the [[National Arts Club]], [[John G. Agar (lawyer)|John G. Agar]], announced the formation of The American Institute of Graphic Arts during the eighth annual exhibition of “The Books of the Year.” The National Arts Club was instrumental in the formation of AIGA in that they helped to form the committee to plan to organize the organization.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1913/11/13/104788833.html|title=ARTS CLUB WARNED OF 'THOUGHT TRUST'; While It Plans for Graphic Arts, Bacheller Also Warns of Our Europeanization. NEW THEMES FOR NOVELS Getting Away from Work, He Finds Butcher's Daughter Cultivates Only Ease and the Graces Now.|access-date=2016-11-30}}</ref> The committee formed included [[Charles DeKay]] and [[William Bailey Howland|William B. Howland]] and officially formed the American Institute of Graphic Arts in 1914.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.aiga.org/How-Our-Quarter-Century-Began/|title=How Our Quarter Century Began|newspaper=AIGA {{!}} the professional association for design|access-date=2016-11-30}}</ref> Howland, publisher and editor of ''The Outlook'', was elected president.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Steven Heller|author2=Nathan Gluck|title=Seventy-five years of AIGA|url=http://www.aiga.org/about-history-75thanniversary/|website=aiga.org|accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref> The goal of the group was to promote excellence in the graphic design profession through its network of local chapters throughout the country.<ref name=":0" />
In 1920, AIGA began awarding [[List of AIGA medalists|medals]] to "individuals who have set standards of excellence over a lifetime of work or have made individual contributions to innovation within the practice of design." Winners have been recognized for design, teaching, writing or leadership of the profession and may honor individuals posthumously.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.aiga.org/medal|title=AIGA Medalists List|newspaper=AIGA {{!}} the professional association for design|access-date=2016-10-21}}</ref>
In 1982, the New York Chapter was formed and the organization began creating local chapters to decentralize leadership.<ref name=":1" />
Represented by Washington, D.C. arts advocate and attorney, James Lorin Silverberg, Esq., The Washington, D.C. Chapter of AIGA, was organized as the American Institute of Graphic Arts, Incorporated, Washington, D.C. on September 6, 1984.<ref>{{cite web|title=District of Columbia Corporate Records|url=http://corp.dcra.dc.gov/BizEntity.aspx/ViewEntityData?entityld=2787251|publisher=The District of Columbia}}</ref>
==Symbol sign project== {{main article|DOT pictograms}} The AIGA, in collaboration with the [[US Department of Transportation]], produced 50 standard symbols to be used on signs "in airports and other transportation hubs and at large international events". The first 34 symbols were published in 1974, receiving a [[Presidential Design Award]]. The remaining 16 designs were added in 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aiga.org/content.cfm/symbol-signs|title=Symbol Signs|year=2009|publisher=AIGA|accessdate=September 2, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091010215420/http://www.aiga.org/content.cfm/symbol-signs| archivedate= October 10, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
== Annual competitions ==
===Cased=== In 2012, AIGA replaced all its competitions with a single competition called "Cased"<ref name="Cased-competition">{{cite web|url=http://www.aiga.org/cased/|title=Cased, AIGA's annual design competition|publisher=}}</ref> (formerly called "Justified"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aiga.org/justified/#about |title=Justified: AIGA Annual Design Competition |author=AIGA |accessdate=June 3, 2014 }}</ref>). The stated aim of the competition is to demonstrate "the collective success and impact of the design profession by celebrating the best in contemporary design through case studies".<ref name="Cased-competition" />
===50 Books/50 Covers=== Between 1941 and 2011 AIGA sponsored a juried contest for the 50 best designed books published in the previous year, entitled "50 Books/50 Covers". Jurors included booksellers, book publishers, and designers such as [[George Salter]].<ref>''Fifty Books of the year 1963'', The American Institute of Graphic Arts, New York, 1964.</ref>
On February 17, 2012, AIGA announced that it would cease organizing the contest and that future contests would be organized by [[Design Observer]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aiga.org/AIGA-and-Design-Observer-partner-on-50-Books-50-Covers/ |title=AIGA and Design Observer Partner on "50 Books/50 Covers" |date=February 17, 2012 |author=AIGA |accessdate=June 3, 2014 }}</ref> This move has been criticized.<ref name=Unjustified>{{cite web |url=http://www.printmag.com/featured/aiga-unjustified/ |title=AIGA: Unjustified |first=Paula |last=Scher |authorlink=Paula Scher |work=[[Print (magazine)|Print Magazine]] |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=June 3, 2014 }}</ref>
===365=== The 365 was an annual design competition for all graphic design other than book design.<ref name=Unjustified /> The last “365” competition was organized in 2011,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aiga.org/about-365/ |title=<nowiki>365 | Design Effectiveness Competition</nowiki> |author=AIGA |accessdate=June 3, 2014 }}</ref> after which it was replaced by the "Cased" competition.
==Conferences== AIGA organized two conferences, the AIGA Design Conference and GAIN: AIGA Design and Business Conference. Both conferences were held biennially and the two were held in alternating years. Beginning in 2016, the AIGA Design Conference will be held annually with the 2016 conference held in Las Vegas.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://designconference.aiga.org/#!/|title=AIGA Design Conference|website=designconference.aiga.org|access-date=2016-08-14}}</ref>
===AIGA Design Conference===
The first AIGA Design Conference took place in Boston, Massachusetts in 1985.
Past AIGA Design Conferences include:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://designconference2009.aiga.org/timeline/|title="A Tradition Over Time". AIGA. Retrieved October 1, 2009.|publisher=|access-date=2009-10-02|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091009041909/http://designconference2009.aiga.org/timeline/|archive-date=2009-10-09|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
*2017 - Minneapolis *2016 - Las Vegas *2015 - New Orleans *2013 - Minneapolis *2011 - Phoenix *2009 - Memphis *2007 - Denver *2005 - Boston *2003 - Vancouver *2001 - Washington *1999 - Las Vegas *1997 - New Orleans *1995 - Seattle *1993 - Miami *1991 - Chicago *1989 - San Antonio *1987 - San Francisco *1985 - Boston
The 2016 and 2017 conferences was hosted by [[Roman Mars]].<ref name="Design-conference-2015">{{cite web|url=http://www.aiga.org/AIGA-design-conference-2015/|title=Join us in New Orleans for the AIGA Design Conference|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aiga.org/board-of-directors/|title=AIGA board of directors|publisher=}}</ref>
==National board members== As of 2018, the national board consists of<ref name="AIGA-board"/> {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *Dana Arnett (President) *Terry Marks (Treasurer) *Justin Ahrens *Helen Armstorng *Ashleigh Axios *Antionette Carroll *Sarah Brooks *Sara Frisk *Karin Hibma *Rich Hollant *Randy J. Hunt *Jamie Myrold *Christine Taylor *Richard Ting *Hugh Weber *Gage Mitchell (Presidents council representative) {{div col end}}
== Affiliations == Between 2005 and 2009, AIGA was briefly a member of Icograda (now called [[Ico-D]]). In 2010, it withdrew from the international organization, citing financial reasons.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aiga.org/why-has-aiga-withdrawn-from-icograda/ |title=Why has AIGA withdrawn from Icograda? |first=Richard |last=Grefe |date=January 25, 2010 |accessdate=July 15, 2014}}</ref>
== International membership == AIGA opened up membership beyond local chapters in 2014, benefiting creative professionals living and working outside of the USA.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}}
==Publications==
===Journals===
In 1947 AIGA started publishing the ''AIGA Journal of Graphic Design'' (ISSN 0736-5322),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aiga.org/history-timeline/ |title=AIGA History Timeline |author=AIGA |accessdate=July 18, 2014}}</ref> which in 2000 was renamed ''Trace: AIGA Journal of Design'' (ISSN 1471-3497).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ipac.ocad.on.ca/ipac20/ipac.jsp?uri=link=3100006~!90266~!3100001~!3100002 |title=AIGA journal of graphic design / [Periodical] |website=OCAD U Library Catalogue |quote=Name changed to Trace: AIGA Journal of Design after v.18 no.2 (2000) |accessdate=July 18, 2014}}</ref> The journal ceased publication in 2003.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ipac.ocad.on.ca/ipac20/ipac.jsp?uri=link=3100006~!11624~!3100001~!3100002 |title=Trace / [Periodical] |quote=Subtitled: AIGA Journal of Design. Publication ceased as of April 2003. |website=OCAD U Library Catalogue |accessdate=July 18, 2014}}.</ref>
Between 2000 and 2003 AIGA published ''Loop: AIGA Journal of Interaction Design Education'', an “interactive, web-based” research journal on interaction and visual interface design co-sponsored by [[Virginia Commonwealth University]]’s Center for Design Studies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://loop1.aiga.org/content.cfm?alias=aboutloop |title=About Loop |publisher=AIGA |date=June 2013 |issue=7 |journal=Loop |accessdate=July 18, 2014}}</ref>
Between 2004 and 2011 AIGA published ''Voice: AIGA Journal of Design'', “an online publication for the discussion of design matters” listing [[Steven Heller (graphic design)|Steven Heller]] as its editor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://voice.aiga.org/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040328225409/http://voice.aiga.org/ |archivedate=March 28, 2004 |title=Voice: AIGA Journal of Design |accessdate=July 18, 2014 |quote=Consulting Editor Steven Heller}}.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://voice.aiga.org/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110515080542/http://voice.aiga.org/ |archivedate=May 15, 2011 |title=Voice: AIGA Journal of Design |accessdate=July 18, 2014 |quote=Editor Steven Heller}}.</ref> Although the journal was stated in “What AIGA is doing and why”<ref name="AIGA-what-why"/> and had been cited in scholarly research,<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Business Communication Quarterly |date=June 2008 |volume=71 |issue=2 |publisher=[[Sage Publications]] |pages=241–246 |title=Smiling With Customers |first=Clive |last=Muir |doi=10.1177/1080569908317320}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Urban Designscapes and the Production of Aesthetic Consent |journal=Urban Studies |first=Guy |last=Julier |volume=42 |issue=5/6 |date=May 2005 |pages=869–887 |publisher=Routledge |doi=10.1080/00420980500107474}}</ref> after AIGA revamped its website in May 2011<ref name="AIGA-org">{{cite web |url=http://www.aiga.org/faqs-about-aigaorg/ |title=FAQs: About aiga.org |author=AIGA |accessdate=July 18, 2014}}</ref> it was subsumed under AIGA’s main site and ceased to exist as a distinct entity.
===Books=== As part of its strategy to “publish critical thinking about design and designing”, AIGA also “copublishes selected works by thought leaders in design”<ref>{{cite book |title=Designing with Web Standards |edition=2nd |first=Jeffrey |last=Zeldman |publisher=New Riders |date=July 6, 2006 |isbn=0-321-38555-1 |page=xx}}</ref> under the imprint of “AIGA Design Press”.<ref name="AIGA-what-why">{{cite web |url=http://www.aiga.org/planning-for-aigas-future/#what-AIGA-is-doing-and-why |title=What AIGA is doing and why: 2011 |format=PDF |author=AIGA |page=35 |accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref> Published titles include * ''The Open Brand: When Push Comes to Pull in a Web-Made World'' (Kelly Mooney and Nita Rollins, 2008) * ''Digital Foundations: Intro to Media Design with the Adobe Creative Suite'' (Xtine Burrough and [[Michael Mandiberg]], 2008), which was released under a [[Creative Commons]] license<ref>{{cite web |url=https://creativecommons.org/tag/aiga-design-press |title=AIGA Design Press: Digital Foundations, CC-Licensed Media Design Instruction |first=Cameron |last=Parkins |date=December 22, 2008 |publisher=Creative Commons |accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref> * ''Designing for Interaction: Creating Smart Applications and Clever Devices'' (Dan Saffer, 2006) * ''Designing With Web Standards'' ([[Jeffrey Zeldman]], 2006) * ''Inside/Outside: From the Basics to the Practice of Design'' ([[Malcolm Grear]], 2006) * ''ZAG: The Number-One Strategy of High-Performance Brands'' ([[Marty Neumeier]], 2006) * ''Do Good: How Design Can Change the World'' (David B. Berman, 2008) * ''Writing for Visual Thinkers: A Guide for Artists and Designers'' (Andrea Marks, 2011)
AIGA has also published the periodically updated ''AIGA professional practices in graphic design''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n81-32755/ |title=American Institute of Graphic Arts |website=OCLC WorldCat Identities |publisher=[[OCLC]] |accessdate=July 18, 2014}}</ref> including a translation to simplified Chinese.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://china.staging.aiga.org/content.cfm/design-business-and-ethics_res |title=Design Business & Ethics, Chinese Edition |author=AIGA China |accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref>
===Other publication activities=== AIGA also maintains the AIGA Design Archives, which was identified as a publishing activity.<ref name="AIGA-what-why"/>
==See also== * [[List of AIGA medalists]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{official website|www.aiga.org}}
{{Design}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Aiga}} [[Category:Design institutions]] [[Category:Professional associations based in the United States]] [[Category:Graphic design]] [[Category:Communication design]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1914]]

{{Infobox film | name = Appropriate Behavior | image = Appropriate Behavior poster.png | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Desiree Akhavan]] | producer = Cecilia Frugiuele | writer = Desiree Akhavan | starring = {{unbulleted list|Desiree Akhavan|Rebecca Henderson|[[Scott Adsit]]|[[Halley Feiffer]]}} | music = [[Josephine Wiggs]] | cinematography = Chris Teague | editing = Sara Shaw | studio = Parkville Pictures | distributor = [[Peccadillo Pictures]] | released = {{film date|2014|1|18|[[2014 Sundance Film Festival|Sundance]]|2015|3|6|UK}} | runtime = 90 minutes | country = United Kingdom | language = English | budget = }} '''''Appropriate Behavior''''' is a British-produced comedy film set in [[New York City]], which premiered on January 18, 2014 at the [[2014 Sundance Film Festival]].<ref>[https://variety.com/2014/film/news/sundance-desiree-akhavan-appropriate-behavior-1201063786/ "Sundance: Why Desiree Akhavan Could be the Next Lena Dunham"]. ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', January 18, 2014.</ref> Written and directed by [[Desiree Akhavan]], the film stars Akhavan as Shirin, a [[bisexual]] [[Persian American]] woman in [[Brooklyn, New York|Brooklyn]] struggling to rebuild her life after breaking up with her girlfriend Maxine (Rebecca Henderson).<ref>[http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/exclusive-clip-from-sundance-film-appropriate-behavior-writer-director-star-desiree-akhavan-talks-personal-filmmaking-20140115 "Exclusive: Clip From Sundance Film 'Appropriate Behavior,' Writer/Director/Star Desiree Akhavan Talks Sex Scenes & More"]. ''[[Indiewire]]'', January 15, 2014.</ref>
The film's cast also includes [[Scott Adsit]], [[Halley Feiffer]], [[Anh Duong]], Hooman Majd, [[Arian Moayed]] and [[Aimee Mullins]]. The film had a theatrical release on January 16, 2015 in the US<ref>[http://www.ioncinema.com/movies/appropriate-behavior "Appropriate Behavior"] ''Ioncinema'', January 13, 2015.</ref> and was released on March 6, 2015 in the UK.<ref>[http://www.filmdates.co.uk/films/8592-appropriate-behaviour/ "Appropriate Behavior Release date"] ''Ioncinema'', January 13, 2015.</ref>
==Plot== Brooklynite Shirin, the daughter of well-off Persian immigrants, is left homeless and jobless after her girlfriend Maxine breaks up with her. With the encouragement of her friend Crystal she moves in with strange roommates and gets a new job teaching 5 year old [[Park Slope]] children the art of movie making.
Shirin's parents are confused as to why Shirin moved out of her old apartment as Shirin has never told them she was bisexual and dating a woman. Determined to get her life back on track, Shirin begins trying to follow Maxine, hoping to rekindle their relationship. Maxine begins dating Tibet, a fellow teacher at the [[Park Slope]] school where she works. Shirin devotes herself to her work and comes out to her brother, who is mostly supportive, and her mother, who is in denial.
On the subway, Shirin tells Crystal that she again plans to bring up the issue of her sexuality with her mother in a month. She sees Maxine outside the subway car on the platform and the two women wave to one another.
==Cast== *[[Desiree Akhavan]] as Shirin *[[Scott Adsit]] as Ken *Rebecca Henderson as Maxine *[[Halley Feiffer]] as Crystal *[[Anh Duong]] as Nasrin *[[Hooman Majd]] as Mehrdad *[[Arian Moayed]] as Ali *[[Aimee Mullins]] as Sasha
==Reception== Review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports a 98% of positive responses from the critics.<ref name=rt>{{cite web |title=APPROPRIATE BEHAVIOR (2015)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/appropriate_behavior/|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=September 26, 2014}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[weighted mean]] rating out of 100 reviews from film critics, the film holds an average score of '75', based on 16 reviews, indicating a 'generally favorable' response.<ref>[http://www.metacritic.com/movie/appropriate-behavior Metacritic]</ref>
David Rooney in his review for ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' praised the film by saying that "The promise of fresh cultural perspectives gives way to a more amorphous slice of contemporary romantic angst comedy."<ref>{{cite web |title=Appropriate Behavior: Sundance Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/appropriate-behavior-sundance-review-672264|accessdate=May 7, 2014}}</ref> Ryan Gilbey wrote in the ''New Statesman'' that Akhavan is "a whiz at writing characters whose life seems to extend beyond their brief screentime."<ref name=rt/> Katie Walsh of ''[[Indiewire]]'' grade the film B+ by saying that "Funny, unique, and entirely inappropriate, Appropriate Behavior is a supremely satisfying and irreverent take on the New York rom-com."<ref>{{cite web |title=Sundance Review: 'Appropriate Behavior' Is A Funny, Irreverent, & Unique Take On The New York Rom-Com|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/sundance-review-appropriate-behavior-is-a-funny-irreverent-and-unique-take-on-the-new-york-rom-com-20140118|accessdate=May 7, 2014}}</ref>
==Accolades== {{Anchor|Awards}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 99%;" |- ! Year ! Group/Award ! Category ! Recipient ! Result ! scope="col" class="unsortable"| Ref. |- | rowspan="2"|2014 | [[30th Independent Spirit Awards]] | [[Independent Spirit Award for Best First Screenplay#2014|Best First Screenplay]] | rowspan="2"|[[Desiree Akhavan]] | {{nom}} | align="center"|<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2014/11/film-independent-spirit-awards-nominations-2015-list-1201295941/|title=Film Independent Spirit Award Nominations 2015 – Full List|accessdate=January 13, 2015}}</ref> |- | [[San Diego Asian Film Festival]] | Grand Jury Prize | {{won}} | align="center"|<ref>{{cite web|url=http://festival.sdaff.org/2014/2014/2014-sdaff-winners-announced/|title=2014 SDAFF winners announced!|accessdate=January 13, 2015}}</ref> |}

{{italic title}} [[Image:Maciejowski Tower of Babel.jpg|thumb|right|A high medieval construction site from the [[Maciejowski Bible]].]] '''''Artes Mechanicae''''' or '''mechanical arts''', are a medieval concept of ordered practices or skills, often juxtaposed to the traditional seven liberal arts [[Artes liberales]]. Also called "servile" and "vulgar",<ref>See for instance Cicero's''De Officiis'', Book I, xxlii.</ref> from antiquity they had been deemed unbecoming for a free man, as ministering to baser needs.
==Overview== [[Johannes Scotus Eriugena]] (9th century) divides them somewhat arbitrarily into seven parts: *''vestiaria'' ([[tailor]]ing, [[weaving]]) *''agricultura'' ([[agriculture]]) *''architectura'' ([[architecture]], [[masonry]]) *''militia'' and ''venatoria'' ([[war]]fare and [[hunting]], Military education, "[[martial arts]]") *''mercatura'' ([[trade]]) *''coquinaria'' ([[cooking]]) *''metallaria'' ([[blacksmithing]], [[metallurgy]])<ref>In his commentary on Martianus Capella's early fifth century work, ''The Marriage of Philology and Mercury'', one of the main sources for medieval reflection on the liberal arts.</ref>
In his ''[[Didascalicon]]'', [[Hugh of St Victor]] (12th century) includes [[navigation]], [[medicine]] and [[theatre|theatrical arts]] instead of commerce, agriculture and cooking.<ref>Hugues de Saint-Victor, ''Libri septem eruditiones didascaliae'', ch.26 (PL 176, col.760): lanificium, armaturum, navigationem, agriculturem, venationem, medicinam, theatricam</ref> Hugh's treatment somewhat elevates the mechanical arts as ordained to the improvement of humanity, a promotion which was to represent a growing trend among late medievals.<ref>See Georges Legoff, ''Time, Work and Culture in the Middle Ages'', (Chicago, University of Chicago Press) 116.</ref><ref name="Invention of Art">{{cite book | last = Shiner | first = Dr. Larry | year = 2003 | pages = 28–30 |title=[[The Invention of Art: A Cultural History]] |publisher=The University of Chicago Press}}</ref>
The classification of the ''Artes Mechanicae'' as applied [[geometry]] was introduced to Western Europe by [[Dominicus Gundissalinus]] (12th century) under the influence of his readings in Arabic scholarship.
In the 19th century "mechanic arts" referred to fields of which some are now known as [[engineering]]. Use of the term was apparently an attempt to distinguish these fields from creative and artistic endeavors like the [[performing arts]] and the [[fine arts]] which were for the upper class of the time, and the [[intelligentsia]]. The mechanic arts were also considered practical fields for those that did not come from good families.
Related phrases, "[[useful arts]]," or "applied arts" probably encompass the mechanic arts as well as craftsmanship in general.
The most famous usage of the term "mechanic arts" (and the one in which it is most commonly encountered today) is in the [[Morrill Land-Grant Colleges Act]].
== See also == *[[Artes liberales]] *[[Medieval technology]]

{{About|the literary device|"back-stories" of consumer goods|Back-story (production)|the book by [[David Mitchell (comedian)|David Mitchell]]|David Mitchell: Back Story}} A '''backstory''', '''background story''', '''back-story''', or '''background''' is a set of events invented for a [[Plot (narrative)|plot]], presented as preceding and leading up to that plot. It is a [[literary device]] of a [[narrative history]] all chronologically earlier than the narrative of primary interest.
In [[acting]], it is the history of the [[character (arts)|character]] before the drama begins, and is created during the actor's preparation.
It is the history of characters and other elements that underlie the situation existing at the main narrative's start. Even a purely historical work selectively reveals backstory to the audience.<ref>[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/backstory Backstory at Merriam Webster online]</ref><ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/backstory Backstory at Dictionary.com]</ref>
==Usage<!--'Main story' redirects here-->== As a [[literary device]], backstory is often employed to lend depth or believability to the '''main story'''<!--boldface per WP:R#PLA-->. The usefulness of having a [[Discovery (fiction)|dramatic revelation]] was recognized by [[Aristotle]], in [[Poetics (Aristotle)|''Poetics'']].
Backstories are usually revealed, partially or in full, chronologically or otherwise, as the main narrative unfolds. However, a story creator may also create portions of a backstory or even an entire backstory that is solely for their own use.<ref> [http://www.helpingwritersbecomeauthors.com/2009/08/backstory-importance-of-what-isnt-told.html Backstory: The Importance of What Isn't Told]</ref>
Backstory may be revealed by various means, including [[Flashback (narrative)|flashback]]s, [[dialogue]], [[Narrative|direct narration]], [[:wikt:summary|summary]], [[recollection]], and [[Exposition (literary technique)|exposition]]. The original ''[[Star Wars (film) | Star Wars]]'' movie and its first two [[sequels]] are examples of a work with a preconceived backstory, which was later released as the "prequel" second set of three movies.
== Recollection == [[Recollection]] is the [[Fiction-writing modes|fiction-writing mode]] whereby a character calls something to mind, or remembers it. A character's memory plays a role for conveying backstory, as it allows a fiction-writer to bring forth information from earlier in the story or from before the beginning of the story. Although recollection is not widely recognized as a distinct fiction-writing mode, recollection is commonly used by authors of fiction.
For example, Orson Scott Card observes that "If it's a memory the character could have called to mind at any point, having her think about it just in time to make a key decision may seem like an implausible coincidence . . . ." Furthermore, "If the memory is going to prompt a present decision, then the memory in turn must have been prompted by a recent event."<ref>Card, Orson Scott (1988), "Character & Viewpoint", p. 113. Cincinnati, OH: Writer's Digest Books. {{ISBN|0-89879-307-6}}.</ref>
== Shared universe == In a [[shared universe]] more than one author may shape the same backstory. The later creation of a backstory that conflicts with a previously written main story may require the adjustment device known as [[retroactive continuity]], informally known as "[[retcon]]".
==Acting== Actors may create their own backstories for characters, going beyond the sometimes meager information in a script. Filling in details helps an actor interpret the script and create fully imagined characters.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Homan |first1=Sidney |last2=Rhinehart |first2=Brian |title=Comedy Acting for Theatre: The Art and Craft of Performing in Comedies |date=2018 |publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing |isbn=9781350012783 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oMVIDwAAQBAJ&dq=backstory+acting&source=gbs_navlinks_s |accessdate=26 November 2018 |chapter=3}}</ref>
== See also ==
* [[Characterization]] * [[Flashback (narrative)]] * [[Origin story]] * [[Prequel]]

{{Infobox Website | name = Basenotes | url = {{URL|basenotes.net}} | alexa = {{DecreasePositive}} 36,002 ({{as of|2018|5|28|alt=May 2018}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/basenotes.net |title= Basenotes.net Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate=28 May 2018 }}</ref><!--Updated monthly by OKBot.--> | commercial = Yes | type = [[Online]] [[Fragrance|perfume]] [[database]] | language = [[English language|English]] | registration = Optional | author = Grant Osborne | launch date = August 2000 | current status = Online |num_users=194,640 ({{as of|2015|5|28|alt=May 2018}})<ref>{{cite web|title=Basenotes Forums|url=http://www.basenotes.net/forum.php|website=Basenotes.net|accessdate=28 May 2018}}</ref>}}
'''Basenotes''' is a [[United Kingdom]]-based online [[fragrance]] resource which includes a fragrance database, message boards and editorial. The site was launched in August 2000 by Grant Osborne as an information site for men's fragrance and grooming. In 2004, the site expanded to include feminine fragrances.<ref>[http://nowsmellthis.blogharbor.com/blog/_archives/2005/10/17/1303340.html Basenotes: an interview with Grant Osborne :: Now Smell This<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907211839/http://nowsmellthis.blogharbor.com/blog/_archives/2005/10/17/1303340.html |date=7 September 2008 }}</ref> {{Expand section|Basic company data (country, funding/business model, number of employees, revenue & profits)|date=June 2008}}
==The Basenotes Fragrance Directory== The Basenotes Fragrance Directory contains over 20,000 fragrances and over 90,000 fragrance reviews by the site's visitors. Users of the site can search for fragrances by name, house, year of launch, gender, notes (ingredients), [[perfumer]] or bottle designer. Visitors to the site can submit information to be included in the directory.<ref>Women's Wear Daily 1 September 2007 http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-179313929.html</ref>
The consumer reviews on the site have been described as "admirably prosaic"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2006/nov/25/fashion1|title=Alexis Petridis: I smell a rat in men's fragrance|last=Petridis|first=Alexis|date=25 November 2006|website=[[The Guardian]]|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=28 May 2018}}</ref> by [[Alexis Petridis]] in ''[[The Guardian]]''.
==The Basenotes community== Basenotes has a lively fragrance forum, described by ''[[The New York Times]]'' as "the rialto for [[perfume talk]]",<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/16/magazine/16wwln-medium-t.html|title=Virginia Heffernan - The Medium - Television - Internet Video - Media|last=Heffernan|first=Virginia|date=16 March 2008|work=The New York Times|access-date=28 May 2018|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> where registered members can discuss fragrances and trade fragrances in the Basenotes Marketplace.
==The Basenotes Fragrance Awards== Each year Basenotes asks visitors to the site to vote for their favorite fragrances that year.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.perfumerflavorist.com/networking/news/company/19099669.html|title=Basenotes.net Award Winners|last=Frederick|first=Kelly|date=10 November 2008|work=Perfumer & Flavorist|access-date=28 May 2018|language=en}}</ref> Regular winners include [[Old Spice]], [[Shalimar (perfume)|Shalimar]], [[Vetiver]] de [[Guerlain]], [[Chanel No.5]], YSL [[M7 fragrance|M7]], [[Green Irish Tweed]] and A*Men. There are also categories for the best new fragrance and best celebrity fragrance.
==Other features== The site also has regularly updated industry news, user blogs, articles<ref>[http://technology.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/tech_and_web/article1554639.ece The click - Times Online<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and interviews with figures in the fragrance industry.
==Awards and recognition== Basenotes has won five awards for its editorial content at [[The Canadian Fragrance Awards]] in 2007,<ref>[http://newsblaze.com/story/2007050310040200005.cc/topstory.html Coty Canada, Prestilux Inc., Estee Lauder and Lancome: Big Winners At The 2007 Canadian Fragrance Awards-Shelley Rozenwald Awarded Lifetime Achievement Award<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> 2008<ref>[http://nowsmellthis.blogharbor.com/blog/_archives/2008/4/26/3661406.html German Duftstars, Canadian Fragrance Awards ~ the 2008 winners :: Now Smell This<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080720183111/http://nowsmellthis.blogharbor.com/blog/_archives/2008/4/26/3661406.html |date=20 July 2008 }}</ref> and 2009. All three of these winning articles were written by Marian Bendeth, a regular contributor and fragrance expert.
In 2009, the website won a prize for Best Web Editorial at the [[Jasmine Awards]] for an article by the writer, Liz Upton. The following year, the same prize was won by the Basenotes writer, Walker Minton. In 2018, Claire Vukcevic won the Best Practical Guide Award for her guide to summer fragrances on Basenotes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thejasmineawards.co.uk/the-fragrance-foundation-jasmine-awards-2018-winners|title=The Fragrance Foundation Jasmine Awards 2018 Winners {{!}} The Jasmine Awards|last=|first=|date=|website=thejasmineawards.co.uk|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=28 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.basenotes.net/features/3482-summer-fragrances-for-people-who-hate-summer-and-also-summer-fragrances|title=Summer Fragrances for People Who Hate Summer & Also Summer Fragrances ~ by Claire Vukcevic — Basenotes.net|last=|first=|date=|website=www.basenotes.net|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=28 May 2018}}</ref>
In August 2008, Basenotes was one of 50 websites recommended by ''[[Men's Vogue]]'' in a best-of-the-web round-up which also featured [[IMDB]], [[Slashdot]], [[Boing Boing]] and [[eLuxury]].<ref>[http://www.mensvogue.com/design/articles/best_websites_hub 50 Recommended Web sites: Tech: mensvogue.com<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080811192318/http://www.mensvogue.com/design/articles/best_websites_hub |date=11 August 2008 }}</ref>
==Controversy==
Much suspicion surrounds the censorship process on the site, whereby opinions which differ from the orthodoxy as presented by the site moderators are removed. Frequently, this results in the banning of members who express non-compliant views. It has been suggested that there are commercial motives behind this censorship.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://basenotessucks.blogspot.co.uk|title=No To Basenotes Censorship|last=|first=|date=|website=basenotessucks.blogspot.co.uk|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=28 May 2018}}</ref> Fragrance house O'Driu, who apparently suffered as a result of this perceived bias, famously responded by releasing a fragrance called "Basenotes Kiss My Ass", which won an award at the Cafleurebon 2015 fragrance awards.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cafleurebon.com/cafleurebon-best-and-worst-perfumes-of-2015-best-fragrance-best-perfumer-and-hall-of-fame-draw|title=best fragrances of 2015|last=|first=|date=2015-12-27|work=Cafleurebon - Perfume and Beauty Blog|access-date=28 May 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{about|the slang term|the "bogan" dark side of The Force in Star Wars|The Force}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=April 2011}} [[File:Stereotypical Bogan.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Street art in Melbourne|Melbourne street art]] of a stereotypical male bogan. He is depicted as a repulsive character with a cigarette in his mouth, a tomato sauce-covered [[Meat pie (Australia and New Zealand)|meat pie]] in one hand and a [[Beer bottle#"Darwin Stubby"|stubby]] of [[Melbourne Bitter]] in the other. On his arm is a tattoo of [[bushranger]] and outlaw [[Ned Kelly]].]]
'''Bogan''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|oʊ|ɡ|ən}} {{respell|BOHG|ən}}<ref>{{cite web|title=bogan noun - Definition, pictures, pronunciation and usage notes {{!}} Oxford Advanced Learner's Dictionary at OxfordLearnersDictionaries.com|url=https://www.oxfordlearnersdictionaries.com/definition/english/bogan|website=www.oxfordlearnersdictionaries.com|accessdate=26 February 2017|language=en}}</ref>) is [[Australian English|Australian]] and [[New Zealand English|New Zealand]] [[slang]] for a person whose speech, clothing, attitude and behaviour are considered unrefined or unsophisticated. Depending on the context, the term can be pejorative or [[Self-deprecation|self-deprecating]].<ref>{{cite news| last=Lauder| first=Simon| title=Bogan Pl residents lobby for name change| publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]]| date=12 April 2008| url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/04/12/2215081.htm| accessdate=12 April 2008}}</ref> The prevalence of the term bogan has also been associated with changing social attitudes towards [[social class]] in Australia. Specifically, the term has been related to the decline of masculine conceptions of meritocracy in Australia, and a growing ambivalence towards traditional sites of [[working class]] culture.<ref>Paternoster, H.J., Warr, D. and Jacobs, K., 2018. The enigma of the bogan and its significance to class in Australia: A socio-historical analysis. Journal of Sociology, p.1440783318769752.</ref>
Since the 1980s, the bogan has become a very well-recognised subculture, often as an example of [[Taste (sociology)|bad taste]].<ref name="Griffith">{{cite web |title='Bogan' Polite or not? Cultural implications of a term in Australian slang |url=http://www.griffith.edu.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0019/72901/Issue1-kay-bartolo-boga-in-ausE.pdf |publisher=[[Griffith University]] |author=Kay Frances Bartolo |accessdate=8 November 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title='Bogan Hunters: A Field Guide' |url=https://nz.entertainment.yahoo.com/tv/blogs/b/-/25566791/bogan-hunters-a-field-guide/# |publisher=[[Yahoo!]] NZ |author=Melenie Parkes |date=20 November 2014 |accessdate=25 November 2014 }}</ref> It has antecedents in the Australian [[larrikin]] and [[ocker]], and various localised names exist that describe the same or very similar people to the bogan.<ref name="BBSB">Moore, Bruce: [https://web.archive.org/web/20110312000346/http://www.anu.edu.au/ANDC/pubs/ozwords/November_98/2._regionalisms.htm Of Boondies, Belgium Sausages and Boguns], (archive of [http://www.anu.edu.au/andc/pubs/ozwords/November_98/2._regionalisms.htm dead link] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110312000346/http://www.anu.edu.au/andc/pubs/ozwords/November_98/2._regionalisms.htm |date=12 March 2011 }}) [http://www.anu.edu.au/andc/pubs/ozwords/index.php Ozwords] ([[Australian National University]]), November 1998.</ref>
==Etymology== The origin of the term ''bogan'' is unclear; both the ''[[Macquarie Dictionary]]'' and the ''[[Australian Oxford Dictionary]]'' cite the origin as unknown.<ref name="newsOxf">{{cite web |title=Bogan breaks into Oxford dictionary|publisher=News Limited|date=19 June 2012|url=http://www.news.com.au/news/bogan-breaks-into-oxford-dictionary/story-fncvfxcm-1226400724944|accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref> Some Sydney residents' recollection is that the term is based on the concept that residents of the Western Suburbs (stereotyped as "Westies") displayed what are now termed "bogan" characteristics and that an individual who displayed these characteristics to a strong extent was as "west" as the Bogan River in western New South Wales. According to another anecdote, the term emerged in [[Melbourne]]'s outer-western and outer-eastern suburbs in the late 1970s and early 1980s.<ref name="newsDM">{{cite web |title=Don't call us uncouth say 'Bogans': Anger as Australian term similar to 'Chav' is included in Oxford Dictionary|last=Miller |first=Daniel|work=[[Daily Mail|The Daily Mail Australia]] |date=21 June 2012 |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2162191/Bogan-fury-Anger-Australian-term-similar-Chav-included-Oxford-Dictionary.html |accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref>
The term became widely known in the late 1980s when the teenage character Kylie Mole (played by [[Mary-Anne Fahey]]), in the Australian [[sketch comedy]] television series ''[[The Comedy Company]]'', frequently used the term to disparage anyone she disliked.<ref name="ANDC">{{cite web |url=http://andc.anu.edu.au/australian-words/meanings-origins?field_alphabet_value=71 |title=Meanings and origins of Australian words and idioms |publisher=Australian National Dictionary Centre |accessdate=1 May 2012}}</ref> The same program included a sketch about a magazine called ''Bogue'' (a parody of ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]''), which featured traditional bogans. [[Merrick and Rosso]] (from Melbourne) also used the term on their [[Triple J]] national radio show.
The [[Australian National Dictionary Centre]] (ANDC) included the word in its Australian dictionary project<ref name="ANDC"/> in 1991 and said the earliest use they found was in the September 1985 issue of surfing magazine ''[[Tracks (magazine)|Tracks]]'': "So what if I have a [[Mohawk hairstyle|Mohawk]] and wear [[Dr. Martens]] (boots for all you uninformed bogans)?"<ref name="ANDC" />
There are places in western [[New South Wales]] that contain ''bogan'' in their name—for example [[Bogan Shire]], the [[Bogan River]] and the rural village of [[Bogan Gate]]. Bogan Gate, for example, is derived from the local Aboriginal word meaning "the birthplace of a notable headman of the local tribe".<ref name="ANDC"/> Residents of streets such as Bogan Place and Bogan Road have been moved to action by the negative connotations of their street names and lobbied to rename them, prompting [[Ku-ring-gai]] mayor Nick Ebbeck to joke that he was a bit of a bogan himself.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/story/0,22049,23533259-5013110,00.html |title=Not the place for bogans |work=Daily Telegraph |date=14 April 2008 |accessdate=28 December 2009|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080416154534/http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/story/0,22049,23533259-5013110,00.html|archive-date=16 April 2008}}</ref> The 1902 poem "City of Dreadful Thirst" by Australian poet [[Banjo Paterson]] makes reference to a "Bogan shower" as a term meaning "three raindrops and some dust", although this is likely a reference to the dry area around the Bogan River. Makeshift gates in a rural fence in northwest NSW were known as ''bogan gates'' at least as early as the 1960s.
==Concept== {{See also|Strine}} Some features regularly associated with the bogan stereotype include residing in the outer suburbs of larger cities, having teeth that haven't had dental care due to cost, having an anti-authoritarian or jingoistic stance, as well as being interested in classic rock music, [[hooning|hoon driving]] and excessive alcohol consumption.<ref name="bogans">{{cite web |title=Do bogans know they’re bogans? We put this and other effin’ important questions to Bogan Hunters creator Paul Fenech |url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/tv/do-bogans-know-theyre-bogans-we-put-this-and-other-effin-important-questions-to-bogan-hunters-creator-paul-fenech/story-e6frfmyi-1226915756387 |publisher=News Limited |date=13 May 2014 |accessdate=8 November 2014 }}</ref>
Certain types of clothing are stereotypically associated with bogans, including [[flannel]]ette shirts, hoodies, [[Stubbies (brand)|Stubbies]] shorts, [[Pacific Brands|King Gee]] workwear, [[ugg boots]],<ref>{{cite web |last=Katz |first=Danny |title=The uggly side of life |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/danny-katz/the-uggly-side-of-life/2006/09/27/1159337216912.html |work=The Age |accessdate=6 March 2014 |date=27 September 2006}}</ref> [[jeans]] and black [[leggings]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Demasi |first=Laura |title=Anatomy of a trend - leggings |date=5 October 2006<!--guessed from URL--> |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/fashion/anatomy-of-a-trend--leggings/2006/10/05/1159641427417.html |work=The Age |accessdate=6 March 2014}}</ref>
Vehicles such as the [[Holden Commodore]] and [[Ford Falcon (Australia)|Ford Falcon]], particularly modified or poorly maintained examples, also have similar associations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bogan.com.au/definition/index.php |title=Definition |publisher=BOGAN.com.au |accessdate=28 December 2009}}</ref>
A person described as a bogan may refuse to conform to middle-class standards of taste, dietary habits, leisure activities, styles of dress and ways of speaking,<ref>{{cite web |title=Bogans and hipsters: we’re talking the living language of class |url=http://theconversation.com/bogans-and-hipsters-were-talking-the-living-language-of-class-23007 |publisher=[[The Conversation (website)|The Conversation]] |date=24 February 2014 |accessdate=8 November 2014 }}</ref> and might be looked down upon by some groups due to preconceived perceptions and biases which can often make the lives of disadvantaged people much tougher.<ref name="biases">{{cite web|url=http://theconversation.com/bogans-from-the-burbs-confronting-our-hidden-biases-11661|title=Bogans from the ‘burbs: confronting our hidden biases|date=8 February 2013|publisher=[[The Conversation (website)|The Conversation]]|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref>
[[Mel Campbell]] argued in a 2006 article in the ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'' that bogan (including "cashed-up bogan") is a nebulous, personal concept that is frequently used in a process by which "we use the idea of the bogan to quarantine ideas of Australianness that alarm or discomfort us. It's a way of erecting imaginary cultural barriers between 'us' and 'them'." Campbell argues that though many people believe they know exactly what a bogan is and what their characteristics might be, there is no defined set of characteristics of a bogan: the speaker imagines the denoted person to be different from, and less cultured than, themselves. Campbell considered "cashed-up bogan" to be a "stupid term".<ref>{{cite web |last=Campbell|first=Mel|title=Perhaps there's a little bogan in everyone |work=Sydney Morning Herald |publisher=Fairfax |date=8 June 2006|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/opinion/perhaps-theres-a-little-bogan-in-everyone/2006/06/07/1149359814143.html|accessdate=5 September 2008}}</ref> A similar argument is made by David Nichols, author of ''The Bogan Delusion'' (2011), who says that people have "created this creature that is a lesser human being to express their interclass hatred".<ref>Chris Johnston, [http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/class-war-festers-in-hated-bogan-zeroes-20110603-1flc7.html Class war festers in hated bogan zeroes], ''The Age'', 4 June 2011. See also [http://www.affirmpress.com.au/the-bogan-delusion ''The Bogan Delusion''], Affirm Press</ref>
==Non-pejorative usage== By the 21st century, the term bogan came to be employed more favourably to indicate a pride in being rough around the edges. In 2002, Michelle Griffin discussed the fact that 'bogan' is no longer just being used as an insult, but is in fact a way to identify with the 'Aussie' culture that many Anglo‐Saxon Australian citizens are proud of.<ref name="Griffith"/> In the past, bogan was a term of disdain, but nowadays it has become 'cool' to be a bogan.<ref name="bogans"/> Radio station [[Triple J]] held a "National Bogan Day" on 28 June 2002, which they commemorated by playing music by rock bands such as [[Cold Chisel]], [[Midnight Oil]], [[Rose Tattoo]] and [[AC/DC]].<ref>Griffin, Michelle: [http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2002/07/15/1026185158244.html Bogansville: meet the new in-crowd], ''[[The Age]]'', 16 July 2002.</ref> In a 2011 study, [[linguistics]] students at the [[University of Auckland]] found that the term was likely to be thought of as positive by people under the age of 30, compared with over-30s who generally felt it was more of a negative term.<ref name="newsOxf"/>
==Representation==
===Television=== The typical bogan has been portrayed on television in shows such as ''[[Outrageous Fortune (TV series)|Outrageous Fortune]]'', ''[[Bogan Hunters]]'', ''[[Pizza (TV series)|Pizza]]'', ''[[Housos]]'', ''[[Bogan Pride]]'', ''[[Kath & Kim (Australian TV series)|Kath & Kim]]'', and ''[[Upper Middle Bogan]]''.<ref>{{cite web |title=Our fascination with ‘bogans’ will be televised |url=http://theconversation.com/our-fascination-with-bogans-will-be-televised-25262 |publisher=[[The Conversation (website)|The Conversation]] |date=4 April 2014 |accessdate=8 November 2014 }}</ref>
===Film=== In the 2016 film ''[[Suicide Squad (2016 film)|Suicide Squad]]'', DC Comics villain [[Captain Boomerang]]—a classically Australian character—has been reinvented as a bogan instead of his typical garish personality.
===Internet=== The popular website (and 2010 bestselling book) ''[[Things Bogans Like]]'' contains 250 articles on various things that bogans are claimed to like, and suggests that a "bogan today defies income, class, race, creed, gender and logic".<ref>{{cite web |last=Bogans Like|first=Things|title=What is a Bogan Today? |work=Things Bogans Like |publisher=Hachette Australia |date=October 2010| url=http://thingsboganslike.com/about/| accessdate=8 August 2012}}</ref>
In 2007 Microsoft deemed ''bogan'' to be one of twenty colloquialisms most relevant to Australian users when the word was added to the dictionary of [[Microsoft Office]] 2007.<ref>Press release: [http://www.microsoft.com/australia/presspass/post/Strewth!-Microsoft-Office-2007-will-recognise-more-dinky-di-words Strewth! Microsoft Office 2007 will recognise more dinky-di words], [[Microsoft Corporation]], 15 May 2006.</ref> The word entered the ''Oxford English Dictionary'' in June 2012.
The word ''bogan'' attracts negative attention online towards Anglo-Australians, and consequently [http://www.Boganbroadcast.com boganbroadcast] is actively campaigning to reclaim the term in a positive way.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://www.boganbroadcast.com/?page_id=2|title=about bogan broadcast|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=6/9/2016}}</ref>
===Apps=== An app known as "The Bogan Test" has been created to examine a person's likelihood to fall within the boundaries of the bogan category.<ref>{{cite web |title=You're a bogan too. Just take this test. |url=http://www.news.com.au/lifestyle/relationships/youre-a-bogan-too-just-take-this-test/story-fnet0he2-1226629950573 |publisher=News Limited |date=27 December 2013 |accessdate=8 November 2014 }}</ref>
===Music=== Australian [[ska-punk]] band [[Area-7]] achieved one of their biggest hits with the song "Nobody Likes A Bogan", released in 2002.
==Use in marketing== "CUB" or "cashed up bogan", was used by one marketing researcher in 2006 to describe people of a blue-collar background [[Nouveau riche|now earning a high salary]] and spending their earnings on expensive consumer items as a matter of [[conspicuous consumption]]. The media have cited [[tennis]] player [[Lleyton Hewitt]] and his actress wife, [[Bec Cartwright]], as examples.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2006/05/19/1147545524374.html |title=Snobbery alert: the 'Cub' is busy turning Melbourne into Boganville|work=Age |publisher=Fairfax |date=20 May 2006}}</ref> Subsequently, the Kaesler Winery, in the [[Barossa Valley wine district|Barossa Valley]], released a Shiraz wine under the name Bogan.
==Regional equivalent terms== Roz Rohen has described the term 'bogan' as peerless, and that it warrants acceptance as an Australian keyword.<ref name="Phd">{{cite web |title=Take our word for it: The Aussie Bogan is "in" |url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/questnews/east/take-our-word-for-it-the-aussie-bogan-is-in/story-fni9r0lo-1226763717481?nk=ed31c832430883f38db9da0aeaea89eb |publisher=[[The Courier-Mail|Courier Mail]] |date=20 November 2013 |accessdate=8 November 2014 }}</ref> {{Quote|text="There are plenty of other words purporting to describe the same social and cultural subset or behaviour, but 'bogan' really does stand alone"|sign=[[Roz Rohen]]|source=''[[The Courier-Mail|Courier Mail]]''.<ref name="Phd" />}}
Although the term "bogan" is understood across Australia and New Zealand, certain regions have their own slang terms for the same group of people. These terms include:
* "Bevan" or "Bev" in [[Queensland]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Smitz|first=Paul|title=Lonely Planet Australia|year=2004|publisher=Lonely Planet|isbn=978-1-74059-447-9|page=1064}}</ref> * "Booner" in [[Canberra]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ozwords.org/?p=3964 |title=Canberra Word: booner|work=Ozwords|publisher=Australian National Dictionary Centre|date=14 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://the-riotact.com/what-has-happened-to-canberra's-booners/9862 |title=What has happened to Canberra’s booners?|work=RiotACT|date=28 November 2008}}</ref> * "Chigger" (also "chigga" or "chig") in [[Tasmania]]. This appears to be a reference to the Hobart suburb of [[Chigwell, Tasmania|Chigwell]].<ref name="BBSB" /> * "Scozza" in [[Geelong]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia.<ref name="BBSB" />
"[[Westie (person)|Westie]]" or "westy" is not synonymous with bogan, although westies are often stereotyped as being bogans. "Westie" predates bogan,<ref name="BBSB"/> originating in [[Sydney, New South Wales|Sydney]] in the 1970s to refer to people from that city's western suburbs. As Sydney's western suburbs are predominantly working class blue collar areas, the term connotes a predominantly working class blue collar person – someone with little education, little taste, and very limited horizons. "Westie" is now in wide use in many cities and towns across both Australia and New Zealand, where it especially refers to the denizens of West Auckland.
== See also ==
===Other Australian and New Zealand stereotypes and subcultures=== * [[Bodgies and widgies]] * Dero (Australian slang for a derelict person) / [[Lad culture|Lad]] * [[Feral (subculture)|Feral]] * [[Hoon]] * [[Larrikin]] * [[Ocker]] * [[Sharpies (Australian subculture)|Sharpies]] * [[Westie (person)|Westie]] * [[Yobbo]]
'''International:''' {{div col|colwidth=30em}}
* [[Favela]]do, Maloqueiro ou Pé-Rapado ([[Brazil]]) * Baraki ([[Belgium]]) * Ñero ([[Colombia]]) * [[Hoser]] ([[Canada]]) * [[Flaite]] ([[Chile]]) * [[Beauf]] ([[France]]) * [[:de:Prolet|Prolet]] ([[Germany]], page in German) * [[Alay]] ([[Indonesia]]) * [[Skanger]] ([[Ireland]]) * [[Ars (slang)|Ars]] or [[ערס]] ([[Israel]]) * [[Naco (slang)|Naco]] ([[Mexico]]) * [[Tokkie]] ([[Netherlands]]) * [[Spide]] ([[Northern Ireland]]) * [[wiktionary:tambay|Tambay]] [[Jejemon]] [[wiktionary:jologs|Jologs]] ([[Philippines]]) * [[Dres (Polish subculture)|Dres]] ([[Poland]]) * Chunga ([[Portugal]]) * [[Mârlan (Romanian Subculture)|Mârlan]] ([[Romania]]) * [[Gopnik]] (Russia and Ukraine) * [[Ned (Scottish)|Ned]] ([[Scotland]]) * [[Ah Beng]] ([[Singapore]]/[[Malaysia]]) * [[Zef]], similar to "cashed up bogan" ([[South Africa]]) * [[Raggare]] ([[Sweden]]) * [[Chav]] ([[UK]]) * [[Wiktionary:pikey|Pikey]] ([[UK]]) * [[wiktionary:pleb | Pleb]] ([[UK]]) * [[Scally wag|Scally]] ([[UK]] and [[Ireland]]) * [[Redneck]] or [[white trash]] ([[United States]], [[Canada]] and [[New Zealand]]) * [[Yarpie]] ([[South Africa]]) * [[Skid row|Skid]] ([[United States]] and [[Canada]]) * [[Skeet (Newfoundland)]] ([[Newfoundland]], [[Canada]]) * [[Harry (derogatory term)]], Norway {{div col end}} '''Concepts:''' * [[Classism]] * [[Class conflict]] * [[Peasantry]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [https://itunes.apple.com/au/tv-season/bogan-hunters-series-1-raw/id897401474?showLC=true Bogan Hunters] (Comedy TV Series, documents the extent of bogan culture in [[Australia]]) * [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0417496/ Bogans - The Movie] (New Zealand short film, featuring [[Peter Jackson]]) * [https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/speak-bogan-comprehensive/id654537516 Speak Bogan] (Comedy Parody Language Learning Course by comedian [[Xavier Susai]])
[[Category:Australian slang]] [[Category:Fashion aesthetics]] [[Category:New Zealand slang]] [[Category:Pejorative terms for people]] [[Category:Social class subcultures]] [[Category:Social class in Australia]] [[Category:Stereotypes of the working class]] [[Category:Working-class culture]] [[Category:Working class in Australia]] [[Category:Working class in New Zealand]]

{{multiple image|perrow = 2|total_width=250 | image1 = Müjde UZMAN (cropped).jpg | image2 = BusinessCasual.jpg | footer = Business Casual: woman in sleeveless top (''left''), women in trousers and skirt (right). }}
{{about||the albums|Business Casual (Beep Beep album)|and|Business Casual (Chromeo album)}} {{Western dress codes}} '''Business casual''' is an ambiguously defined [[dress code]] adopted by some [[White-collar worker|white-collar]] workplaces in [[Western world|Western countries]], comprising more [[casual wear]] than [[informal wear]] ("dress clothes"), but less casual than [[smart casual]].
Widespread acceptance of business casual attire was preceded by [[Casual Friday]]s which originated [[California]], [[United States]], in the 1990s, in turn inspired by the [[Hawaii]]an 1960s casual custom of [[Aloha Friday]].<ref name="BrownArthur2002">Brown & Arthur 2002, p. 78-79.</ref><ref name="HopeTozian2002">Hope & Tozian 2000, p. 45.</ref>
==Definition== There is no generally agreed definition of "business casual". One definition of business casual states that it includes [[khaki]] pants, [[slacks]], and [[skirts]], as well as short-sleeved [[polo shirt]]s and long-sleeved shirts, but excludes jeans, tennis shoes, tight or short skirts, T-shirts, and sweatshirts.<ref name="Interviewing">{{cite web|url=http://www.marquette.edu/csc/undergraduate/interviewing.shtml|title = Interviewing {{!}} Career Services Center {{!}} Marquette University| website = Marquette University Career Services Center | accessdate = 26 September 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130906180709/http://www.marquette.edu//csc/undergraduate/interviewing.shtml |archive-date=6 September 2013}}</ref> Another source, an American university careers service, states that business casual consists of neutral colors more towards the dark shades of black, gray, navy, but can include white and off white, and reminds that the clothing should be pressed and have clean, crisp seams.<ref name="Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University">{{cite web|title=Business casual attire|url=http://www.career.vt.edu/JobSearchGuide/BusinessCasualAttire.html#ATTIREMENWOMEN|publisher=Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University|accessdate=12 March 2014}}</ref> The "Dress for Success" advice from the University of Toronto sums up business casual as "a classic, clean cut, and put together look where a full suit is not required," which means slacks, khakis, or skirts; [[blouse]]s, polo shirts, or shirts with collar but no [[necktie]]; some [[sweaters]]; and closed-toe shoes.<ref name=UTM/> The Canadian university ends with the warning that "it is not clothing you would wear to a club or for athletic purposes.... Don’t let the word casual mislead you. You still need to look professional."<ref name=UTM>{{cite web | url = http://www.utm.utoronto.ca/careers/business-formal-professional-or-business-casual | title = Business formal/professional or business casual? | publisher = [[University of Toronto Mississauga]] | accessdate = 28 January 2015}}</ref>
Another author wrote in the ''[[Financial Times]]'' that "Ordinarily business casual for guys seems fairly clear. It is a pair of [[chinos]], a [[blazer]] and a good shirt, no tie."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/5eec3cd6-8bf2-11e0-854c-00144feab49a.html#axzz2kbppAQhD|title=Why business casual makes me smart|last=Shrimsley|first=Robert|date=3 June 2011|work=[[Financial Times]]|accessdate=14 November 2013}}</ref>
A [[BBC]] article suggested that a "safe global standard" consists of "a button down shirt," "jackets or blazers, khaki or gray slacks, and leather shoes."<ref name=BBC-2011>{{cite news | url = http://www.bbc.com/travel/feature/20111118-business-casual-attire-around-the-world | date = 22 November 2011 | title = ‘Business casual’ attire around the world | work = BBC Business | first = Chris | last = McGinnis | publisher = [[BBC]] | accessdate = 28 January 2015}}</ref> It warned, however, that great variation exists between countries and regions within countries.<ref name=BBC-2011/> A U.S. menswear retailer advises men to wear a collared shirt, chinos, navy blazer, and brown shoes, while making sure to look "clean and well-groomed."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://blog.paulfredrick.com/2010/05/25/rules/10-tips-for-todays-business-casual-wardrobe | title = 10 Tips for Today’s Business Casual Wardrobe | publisher = Paul Fredrick | location = Fleetwood | accessdate = 11 November 2016}}</ref>
A contributor to ''[[Forbes]]'' asked her Facebook friends to define business casual, and found a slightly more casual apparent consensus not forcibly including a jacket: "For men: trousers/khakis and a shirt with a collar. For women: trousers/knee-length skirt and a blouse or shirt with a collar. No jeans. No athletic wear." A response to that was "I disagree. No khakis." She states that "there’s a lack of consensus in what actually defines a business casual wardrobe. All most people know is they don’t want to see too much of a colleague’s body, including feet."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/reneesylvestrewilliams/2012/05/09/what-is-business-casual/|title=What is Business Casual?|last=Sylvestre-Williams|first=Renee|date=9 May 2012|work=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref>
