revision.text:
{{Infobox museum | name = Byzantine Fresco Chapel | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = | logo_upright = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = ByzantineFrescoChapelMuseum.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = The exterior of the Byzantine Fresco Chapel in Houston | map_type = USA Texas | map_relief = | map_size = | map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|29.7364|-95.3953|type:landmark_region:US-TX|display=inline}} | former_name = | established = {{Start date|1997|09}}, reopened {{Start date|2015}} | dissolved = {{End date|2011}} | location = [[Houston]], Texas, U.S. | type = | accreditation = | key_holdings = | collections = | collection_size = | visitors = | founder = | director = | president = | ceo = | chairperson = | curator = | architect = | historian = | owner = | publictransit = | car_park = | parking = | network = | website = {{URL|http://www.byzantinefrescochapel.org/}} | embedded = }} The '''Byzantine Fresco Chapel''' is a part of the [[Menil Collection]] in [[Houston, Texas]], near the [[University of St. Thomas (Texas)|University of St. Thomas]]. From February 1997 to February 2012, it displayed the only intact [[Byzantine]] [[frescoes]] of this size and importance in the entire western hemisphere. The Byzantine frescoes had been taken from the church of [[Church of Saint Evphemianos, Lysi|St. Evphemianos]] in [[Lysi]], [[Cyprus]] in the 1980s. In September 2011, the collection announced that the frescos would be permanently returned to Cyprus in February 2012, following the conclusion of a long-term loan agreement with the [[Church of Cyprus|Greek Orthodox Church of Cyprus]].<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424053111903703604576587072924927678 "From Texas at Age 700"]. ''Wall Street Journal'', September 24, 2011. Retrieved January 8, 2017. {{paywall}}</ref> The frescoes had been presented at the museum by agreement with the Church of Cyprus, their owners, but the church decided not to extend the loan further. They will not return to their original home as Lysi is now in [[Northern Cyprus]], but will be displayed at the Byzantine Museum in [[Nicosia]].<ref>[http://houston.culturemap.com/newsdetail/09-23-11-20-43-menil-returning-byzantine-frescoes-to-cypress/ "See them while you can: Menil returning Byzantine frescoes to Cyprus in February 2012"]. ''Houston Culturemap'', September 23, 2011. Retrieved September 26, 2011</ref> On March 4, 2012, the Byzantine Fresco Chapel closed, but re-opened in 2015 for the first in a series of site-specific projects.
==History== The chapel was opened in February 1997, and displayed masterworks from the 13th century—a dome with [[Christ Pantocrator]] and an [[apse]] depicting the [[Virgin Mary]] the [[Panayia]]. The frescoes had been stolen from a chapel near Lysi in the [[Turkish invasion of Cyprus|Turkish-occupied]] section of [[Cyprus]] in the 1980s, cut into 38 pieces, and shipped to Germany by thieves to sell them in the arts black-market.<ref name="Slessor, Christine 1998">Slessor, Christine. "Out of this world – Chapel Museum, Houston, Texas – Glass and Transparency." ''The Architectural Review''. May, 1998.</ref> The 38 fresco fragments were bought from the thieves by the Houston-based Menil Foundation on behalf of the Church of Cyprus, the rightful owner of the frescoes. The Menil Foundation then funded a careful restoration of the paintings.<ref name="Menil Collection website">[https://www.menil.org/exhibitions/226-byzantine-fresco-chapel Byzantine Fresco Chapel]. ''www.menil.org''.</ref> These intact frescoes were unique in the western hemisphere.<ref name="Menil Collection website" />
==The original collection== [[File:Lysi-dome.jpg|thumb|left|Dome from church in Lysi, Cyprus depicting Christ the Pantokrator]] The major part of the collection consisted of the frescoes of the dome and apse. According to the guide to the museum, "the Lysi dome represents Christ Pantokrator, 'All sovereign'. It defines a space with no beginning and no end."<ref name="ReferenceA">Guide to the Byzantine Fresco Chapel Museum.</ref> The depiction of Christ gazing directly forward "has driven time out of space. His gaze is transworldly: not looking but all-seeing."<ref name="ReferenceA" /> By not depicting the Lord below the bust, he is "universal and ubiquitous."<ref name="ReferenceA" /> Surrounding the figure of Christ is a double row of angels moving towards the throne prepared by God the Father for the [[Second Coming of Christ]]. The throne is guarded by the [[Archangel Michael]] and [[Archangel Gabriel]] and two [[seraphim]]. The [[Virgin Mary]] leads one line of angels to the throne, while [[John the Baptist]] leads the other.
In the apse, the Virgin was depicted as flanked by the two archangels with a medallion on her breast of the infant Christ, symbolizing the [[Incarnation]] of Christ.<ref name="ReferenceA" />
==Later exhibits== ''The Infinity Machine''. This rotating work by [[Janet Cardiff]] & [[George Bures Miller]] incorporates an array of antique mirrors suspended from above, accompanied by sonic elements made from [[NASA]] recordings of solar winds interacting with planetary ionospheres.<ref>Glentzer, Molly. [http://www.houstonchronicle.com/entertainment/arts-theater/article/Menil-s-new-Inifinity-exhibit-is-a-great-place-6051563.php "Menil's new Infinity exhibit is a surreal space experience."] ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'', January 30, 2015. Retrieved 2 May 2015</ref><ref>[http://houston.culturemap.com/news/arts/02-06-15-menil-byzantine-chapel-is-reborn-as-iinfinity-machinei-with-dazzling-mirrors-voices-from-the-planets/#slide=0 "Menil Byzantine Chapel is reborn as Infinity Machine with dazzling mirrors & voices from the planets"]. ''http://houston.culturemap.com'', February 6, 2015. Retrieved January 8, 2017.</ref>
==Architecture== [[File:ByzantineChapelMuseum.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Church within a Museum; the glass and wood chapel that housed the only intact Byzantine frescoes in the Western hemisphere]] The {{convert|4000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} $4 million building was designed by architect [[François de Menil]]. The interior combines rough stone, opaque glass, and rich woods, to create a space that is both art museum and spiritual space.<ref>[http://www.houstonmuseumdistrict.org/default/museumpages/museumpage.asp?MID=15 "Byzantine Fresco Chapel"]. ''Houston Museum District''. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208080959/http://www.houstonmuseumdistrict.org/default/museumpages/museumpage.asp?MID=15 |date=February 8, 2012}}. Retrieved January 8, 2017.</ref> The suspended-glass "walls" are not replicas of the chapel that the frescoes were removed from, but created a new context for displaying the icons. In order not to simply replicate the original chapel, de Menil designed "a mediating external building with an embedded steel structure – a 'reliquary box' – which forms a neutral enclosure for a freestanding chapel," according to Christine Slessor in ''The Architectural Review''.<ref name="Slessor, Christine 1998" />
{{quote|"The Byzantine Chapel Museum is a religious building whose purpose is to restore spiritual significance and function to two thirteenth-century Byzantine Frescoes, a dome and an apse, rescued and restored by the owner ... The materiality of the original chapel is shattered and made ephemeral through the fragmented, freestanding sandblasted laminated glass structure which is an abstracted evocation of the original chapel. The infinite is evoked through the play of darkness and light." François de Menil, May 1997<ref>[http://www.dupont.com/safetyglass/lgn/stories/0802.html "Byzantine Fresco Chapel Museum uses sandblasted laminated glass to restore spiritual significance"]. ''Laminated Glass News'', E.I. Dupont de Nemours Company. August 2002.</ref>}}
The Byzantine chapel is oriented to face the cardinal directions – the facades face directly north, south, east and west. The enclosed space measures approximately {{convert|116000|cuft|m3}}. There are no windows on the surface area of the building, except for a skylight of {{convert|1012|sqft|m2}} of clear, double glazed glass, which permits natural light to pervade the interior.<ref>Allan V. Co. [http://www.owlnet.rice.edu/~arch316/byz.pdf Byzantine Fresco Chapel - climatology]. ''[[Rice University]]'', 2002. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040919162203/http://www.owlnet.rice.edu/~arch316/byz.pdf|date=September 19, 2004}} Retrieved January 8, 2017.</ref> A rough limestone wall on the outside of the building evoked the rough construction of the original chapel in Cyprus.<ref name="Slessor, Christine 1998" />
==See also== *[[John de Ménil|John de Menil]] *[[Dominique de Ménil|Dominique de Menil]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Byzantine Fresco Chapel}}
*[http://www.byzantinefrescochapel.org/ Official website] *[https://www.menil.org/exhibitions/226-byzantine-fresco-chapel Menil Collection information page]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Byzantine Fresco Chapel}} [[Category:Art and cultural repatriation]] [[Category:Art museums in Texas]] [[Category:Byzantine art]] [[Category:Cypriot culture]] [[Category:Museums in Houston]] [[Category:Religious museums in Texas]] [[Category:Stolen works of art]]

page.title: Casavant Frères Ltée. Opus 1841 (Highland Arts Centre Organ)

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10) ([[User:Hayholt|Hayholt]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox musical artist <!-- For groups; see Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = Casavant Frères Ltée. Opus 1841 | image = HAT HDR2.jpg |image_size = 250px | alt = Highland Arts Theatre Organ | caption = Casavant Frères Ltée. Opus 1841 | background = group_or_band | origin = [[Sydney, Nova Scotia]], [[Canada]] | genre = [[Classical music|classical]], [[Folk music|folk]], [[Popular music|popular]], [[Worship music|worship]] | years_active = {{Start date|1911}}–present | label = [[Highland Arts Theatre]] | associated_acts = | website = [http://www.highlandartstheatre.com/ www.highlandartstheatre.com] }}
'''Casavant Frères Ltée. Opus 1841''' is a [[pipe organ]] [[Organ building|built]] by the famous [[Casavant Frères]] of [[Saint-Hyacinthe]], [[Quebec]]. The organ was first completed in 1911 as '''Casavant Brothers - Opus 452''' for '''St. Andrew's Presbyterian Church''' at 40 Bentinck Street, [[Sydney, Nova Scotia]], [[Canada]]. '''St. Andrew's''' later became '''St. Andrew's United Church''' and is now the '''[[Highland Arts Theatre]]'''.
'''Opus 1841''' is presently composed of 33 [[organ stop|speaking stops]] spread over three [[Manual (music)|manuals]] and [[Pedal keyboard|pedals]]. The 2,045 [[Organ pipe|pipe]] organ is the largest such instrument on [[Cape Breton Island]].<ref name="St. Andrew's United Church Sydney">{{cite web |url = http://www.sydneypresbytery.ca/venueevents/14-st-andrews-united-church-sydney.html |title = St. Andrew's United Church Sydney |publisher = Sydney Presbytery of the United Church of Canada |accessdate = April 17, 2016 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160624162412/http://www.sydneypresbytery.ca/venueevents/14-st-andrews-united-church-sydney.html# |archive-date = 2016-06-24 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> Its facade, [[Pipe organ#Casing|casing]], pipes, [[Swell box|swell and chorus boxes]] completely fill the [[apse]] of the [[Theater (building)|theatre]].
==History== '''Opus 1841''' was purchased for the new church, then under construction, in 1911 for $5,395.<ref name = "St. Andrews United Church named a municipal heritage property">{{cite web | url = http://www.capebretonpost.com/Living/2008-05-26/article-775359/St.-Andrews-United-Church-named-a-municipal-heritage-property/1 | title = Cape Breton Post, St. Andrews United Church named a municipal heritage property | publisher = Cape Breton Post | accessdate = April 17, 2016 }}</ref><ref name = "Casavant Brothers, Ltd., Opus 452, 1911">{{cite web | url = http://database.organsociety.org/SingleOrganDetails.php?OrganID=48983 | title = OHS Database, Casavant Brothers, Ltd., Opus 452, 1911 | publisher = The Organ Historical Society | accessdate = April 18, 2016 }}</ref> The original specification was for three manuals, 4 divisions, 29 stops, 27 registers, 29 ranks, 1843 pipes. A Stoplist for the 1911 instrument copied from the factory specifications for '''Casavant Opus 452''' 1911 3/29, courtesy of the Casavant Frères Archives, St. Hyacinthe, Québec, Canada is available by following this link: [http://database.organsociety.org/SingleOrganDetails.php?OrganID=48983 Original Stoplist]
The organ was rebuilt, including electrification, in 1946 by Casavant Frères Ltée. as '''Opus 1841''', at a cost of $7,600.00. Work included three new Choir stops, a new traditional style [[Organ console|console]] with [[Rolltop desk|roll top]], three manuals, 4 divisions, 33 stops, 30 registers, 32 ranks, 2045 pipes. Manual compass is 61 notes, pedal compass is 32 notes. Equipped with [[Electro-pneumatic action|electro-pneumatic (EP)]] chests, drawknobs in vertical rows on angled jambs, [[Expression pedal#Balanced swell pedal|balanced swell shoes/pedals]] at standard [[American Guild of Organists|AGO placement]], adjustable [[Combination action|combination pistons]], AGO Standard (concave radiating) pedalboard, reversible full organ/tutti toe stud, combination action thumb pistons, combination action toe studs, coupler reversible thumb pistons, coupler reversible toe studs.
In 1962 further work was undertaken, the Clarion 4' replaced the Vox Humana, the Trompette 8' replaced the Cornopean, & the Hooded Harmonic Trumpet replaced an earlier Trumpet on the Great Organ, with tonal changes (new pipework supplied) made by Casavant via Ledoux & MacDonald Organ Service Co., Halifax. [[Pipe organ#Wind system|Wind]] is supplied by a 3 [[Horsepower|hp]] electric [[Centrifugal fan|blower]] located in the basement directly below the organ.
The 18-ton organ underwent $15,000 in repairs to its bellows in 2008, with the sheep skin seams being replaced by rubberized bellows cloth. The repairs were undertaken by Maritime Pipe Organ Builders Ltd. of [[Moncton]], [[New Brunswick]].<ref name = "Famed church organ getting a five-figure overhaul">{{cite news | last = Pottie | first = Erin | date = 28 January 2008 | title = Famed church organ getting a five-figure overhaul | url = | newspaper = [[Cape Breton Post]] | type = [[Daily newspaper]] | format = [[Broadsheet]] | location = [[Sydney, Nova Scotia]] | publisher = Anita DeLazzer | editor = Carl Fleming }}</ref> The tubular chimes in the Swell Organ, now disconnected, were donated in about 1929 by the Lady's Aid group of the Church. They were activated by an electro-pneumatic action and were dis-connected from the wind supply during repairs to the bellows.
In February 2017 [[Pipe organ tuning|Organ Tuner]] Jean-François Mailhot of Sydney Mines spent a week refurbishing Opus 1841, revoicing the reed stops (cleaning the reed tongues and shallots) of the swell organ: the 8' Trompette, the 8' Oboe, and the 4' Clarion, as well as the 16' Trombone of the Pedal Organ. At this time he also repaired a damaged facade pipe, part of the 8' Open Diapason stop of the Great Organ.
[[File:20150415 HAT Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Organ 0028.JPG|thumb|right|upright=1.35|The Organ Façade, the rank of 61 pipes that make up the visible face of the organ upstage in the apse of the theatre. While a number of theses are dummy pipes solely for decoration, 29 are sounding pipes, making up part of two stops of the Great Organ, 12 as part of the Open Diapason 8' and 17 as part of the Violin Diapason 8'.]]
==Basic specification== *Builder: Casavant Frères Ltée, St. Hyacinthe, Québec, Canada **Opus No: 1841, Originally built by Casavant Brothers - Opus 452, 1911 *Console: traditional style console with roll top **3 manuals **shoes/pedals, standard AGO placement **AGO Standard (concave radiating) pedalboard *Stop controls: drawknob *Speaking stops: 33 *Registers: 30 *Ranks: 32 *Pipes: 2045 *Wind: **Power: 3 hp electric blower<ref>Casavant Frères Archives:"[http://database.organsociety.org/SingleOrganDetails.php?OrganID=46148 Casavant Frères Ltée., Opus 1841, 1946. Specification]"</ref>
==Stoplist since 1962 tonal work== {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="10" width="100%" style="border-collapse:collapse;" |- | width="25%" style="vertical-align:top" | {| border="0" | colspan=2 | '''I - GREAT''' (5<sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub>" wind) |} ---- {| border="0" |- |Open [[Flue pipe#Diapasons|Diapason]] || 8′ |- |Violin Diapason || 8' |- |Doppelflöte || 8′ |- |Dolce || 8′ |- |Principal || 4' |- |Super Octave || 2' |- |Harmonic [[Trumpet (organ stop)|Trumpet]] || 8' |- |} ---- {| border="0" |- |''Great Super'' |- |''Chimes'' |} | width="25%" style="vertical-align:top" | {| border="0" | colspan=2 | '''II - CHOIR''' (5<sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub>" wind) (Enclosed) |} ---- {| border="0" |- |Salicional || 8′ |- |Melodia || 8' |- |Viole d'Orchestre || 8′ |- |Waldflöte || 4′ |- |Nazard || 2 <sup>2</sup>/<sub>3</sub>' |- |Piccolo || 2' |- |Clarinet || 8' |- |} ---- {| border="0" |- |''[[Tremulant]]'' |- |''Choir Sub'' |- |''Choir Super'' |- |''[[Tubular bells|Chimes]]'' |} | width="25%" style="vertical-align:top" | {| border="0" | colspan=2 | '''III - SWELL''' (5<sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub>" wind) (Enclosed) |} ---- {| border="0" |- |[[Bourdon (organ pipe)|Bourdon]] || 16′ |- |Open Diapason || 8' |- |Stopped Diapason || 8' |- |[[Flue pipe#Strings|Viola di Gamba]] || 8′ |- |Viole céleste || 8' |- |Aeoline || 8′ |- |Traverse [[Flue pipe#Flutes|Flute]] || 4' |- |Piccolo || 2' |- |[[Mixture (music)|Mixture III]] || |- |Trompette || 8' |- |Oboe || 8' |- |Clarion || 4′ |- |} ---- {| border="0" |- |''Tremulant'' |- |''Swell Sub'' |- |''Swell Super'' |- |''Chimes'' |} | width="25%" style="vertical-align:top" | {| border="0" | colspan=2 | '''PEDAL''' (5<sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub>" wind) |} ---- {| border="0" |- |Open Diapason || 16' |- |Bourdon || 16' |- |[[Gedackt|Gedeckt]] (Swell) || 16' |- |Flute || 8' |- |Stopped Flute || 8' |- |Trombone || 16' |- |} |}
* Couplers: I Great to Pedal, II Swell to Pedal, III Choir to Pedal, IV Great Super to Pedal, V Swell Super to Pedal, VII Choir Super to Pedal, VIII Swell Sub to Great, IX Swell to Great, X Swell Super to Great, XI Choir Sub to Great, XII Choir to Great, XIII Choir Super to Great, XIV Swell Sub to Choir, XV Swell to Choir, XVI Swell Super to Choir.
[[File:St Andrews Church Interior circa 1928.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.35|St. Andrew's Church Interior circa 1928 showing the prominent organ facade.]]
==Organists== * W. D. Fife was the organist when the church was being built, & signed the contract for the organ, but moved away before it was completed. Other organists over the years were: * A. F. MacKinnon * Fred Liscombe * Edward Stuart * H. W. Sparrow * William Raines * John B. Neild just after WW I & at least well into 1925, (he was a Conference delegate to the first Maritime Conference meeting in 1925) * William E. Fletcher * R. MacK. Wiles * A. J. McKnight * Mrs. Frank Crossen * W. D. Fife came back during WWII, signed the contract for the electrification & enlargement, then retired & moved to New Glasgow before it was finished. He was succeeded by: * Clifford L. Gates in 1946 * Vernon H. Atkinson in 1951 * S. Peter Fraser in 1964 <ref name = "The Story of Saint Andrew's Church - 1967">{{cite book |year= 1967 |editor= The United Church Women of Saint Andrew's Church |title= The Story of Saint Andrew's Church |format= booklet |publisher= Saint Andrew's Church, Sydney, NS |pages= 14–15 }}</ref><ref name = "Past-Present-Future, Saint Andrew's Congregation">{{cite book |year= 1948 |last= McFayden |first= E. D. |title= Past, present, future : Saint Andrew's congregation, United Church of Canada, Sydney, Nova Scotia : A Symposium |format= booklet |location= Sydney, Nova Scotia |publisher= Lewis R. Macdonald Printing |pages= 20–21 }}</ref>
==Concerts== [[File:20160415-CBC - ECMW at the HAT31.JPG|thumb|alt=Opus 1841, enclosed in the apse, a quarter dome at the end of the acoustic Barrel Vaulted Ceiling.|Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Opus 1841 enclosed in the quarter dome of the apse at the end of the acoustic Barrel Vaulted Ceiling]] While still serving as a church, St. Andrew's was considered to be perhaps the finest concert venue in the city of Sydney. Before its rebirth as an arts centre, the building had a distinguished background as a performance space. St. Andrew's Choir presented many [[cantata]]s over the years and massed [[choir]]s from eight of Sydney's churches assembled in St. Andrew's to sing as individual choirs and as a group the new and old Christmas carols. Radio broadcasts of Classical musicians regularly held recitals and concerts there over the years because of the building's outstanding [[Architectural acoustics|acoustical properties]] and its Casavant Freres organ.<ref name = "Cape Breton Post, Curtain ready to rise on new Sydney performance space">{{cite web | url = http://www.capebretonpost.com/News/Local/2014-05-28/article-3741977/Curtain-ready-to-rise-on-new-Sydney-performance-space/1 | title = Cape Breton Post, Curtain ready to rise on new Sydney performance space | publisher = Cape Breton Post | accessdate = April 17, 2016 }}</ref> In the mid 1950s St. Andrew's was a regular stop for one of the incarnations of the [[Symphony Nova Scotia|Halifax Symphony Orchestra]] whose performances at St. Andrew's were broadcast regionally and even nationally by [[CBC Radio]]. Thomas Mayer was the conductor. He would often invite local performers to join them, at the time there were several [[Soprano|operatic sopranos]] and [[mezzo-soprano]]s from Cape Breton who gained a national following because of these broadcasts. More recently, due to its seating capacity of over 1,000, and excellent acoustics it was sought after by organizations such as [[Celtic Colours]], [[The Barra MacNeils]],<ref name = "Cathedral marks a new journey for Barra MacNeils">{{cite web | url = http://www.cathedralshow.ca/news.htm | title = Cathedral marks a new journey for Barra MacNeils | publisher = The Inverness Oran | accessdate = April 19, 2016 }}</ref> and the Cape Breton Chorale.<ref name = "St. Andrew's United Church Sydney" />
==Gallery== <gallery class=center caption="Highland Arts Theatre 2,045 pipe, three-manual Casavant Frères Opus 1841 Pipe Organ" widths=180 heights=180 style="font-size:95%; line-height:130%"> File:20150415 HAT Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Organ 0011.JPG|alt=Choir and Swell Stops to the left of the manuals.|The Choir and Swell Stops to the left of the manuals File:20150415 HAT Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Organ 0009.JPG|alt=Casavant Frères Organ Console, showing the Stops and the three Manuals.|The Console, showing the stops, the three manuals, and the pedals File:20150415 HAT Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Organ 0013.JPG|alt=Casavant Frères Organ Great and Pedal Stops to the right of the manuals.|The Great and Pedal Stops to the right of the manuals File:20150415 HAT Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Organ.jpg|alt=Casavant Frères view of the Pedalboard, Swell, Chorus and Crescendo Pedals and Toe Studs.|The Pedalboard, Choir, Swell, and Crescendo Pedals and Toe Studs File:20150415 HAT Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Organ 0039.JPG|alt=A view of the pipes of the Great Organ showing square stopped wooden pipes, part of the Doppelflöte 8', a wooden stop with two mouths per pipe and metal pipes with a right angle bend, part of the Harmonic Trumpet 8'. |Pipes of the Great Organ. The square stopped wooden pipes are part of the Doppelflöte 8', a wooden stop with two mouths per pipe. The metal pipes with a right angle bend are part of the Harmonic Trumpet 8' stop. File:20150415 HAT Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Organ 0076.JPG|alt=Casavant Frères ranks of round, grey metal pipes and square wooden pipes of all sizes inside one of the swell boxes inside the organ.|Pipes and Chimes of the Swell Organ. The ranks of metal and wooden pipes inside the upper swell box inside the organ. File:20150415 HAT Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Organ 0077.JPG|alt=view of the chimes and several of the ranks of wooden and metal pipes inside one of the upper swell box inside the organ.|Pipes and Chimes of the Swell Organ. The tubular chimes and several of the ranks of wooden and metal pipes inside the upper swell box inside the organ. The small pipes of the 3 rank Mixture III fill much of the centre of the image. File:20150415 HAT Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Organ 0035.JPG|alt=Casavant Frères ranks of round, grey metal pipes and square wooden pipes of all sizes inside the organ.|Pipes of the Swell Organ. The ranks of metal and wooden pipes inside the lower swell box inside the organ. File:20150415 HAT Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Organ 0001.JPG|alt=Ranks of 12 square wooden pipes of all sizes inside the organ. These pipes are the extension to the pedal Bourdon 16’ that created the Stopped Flute 8’.|Pipes of the Pedal Organ. These 12 wooden pipes are the extension to the pedal Bourdon 16’ that created the Stopped Flute 8’. File:20150415 HAT Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Organ 0002.JPG|alt=A view of the foot, cap, block and mouth of several of the large wooden pipes of the Open Diapason 16'.|Pipes of the Pedal Organ. The foot, cap, block and mouth of several of the large pipes of the Open Diapason 16'. The middle pipe shown sounds FFF{{music|sharp}} (23.125 Hz). These are the organ's largest wooden pipes with nine pipes grouped together on their own wind chest, each pipe with double air valves to accommodate the large amount of air they require to sound. File:20150415 HAT Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Organ 0066.jpg|alt=looking down from above at several of the ranks of square wooden and round tapered metal pipes inside the organ.|Pipes of the Pedal Organ. Looking down from above at the ranks of square wooden pipes of the Bourdon 16' and round tapered metal pipes of the Trombone 16' File:20150415 HAT Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Organ 0079.JPG|alt=view of one of the ranks of round tapered metal pipes inside the organ.|One of the ranks of round tapered metal pipes inside the organ. File:20150415 HAT Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Organ 0029.JPG|alt=view of the organ and console in the theatre.|The 2,045 pipe, three-manual pipe organ made by the famous Casavant Frères in Quebec. File:20150415 HAT Highland Arts Theatre Casavant Frères Organ 0007.JPG|alt=engraved nameplate of Casavant Frères Ltée. Opus 1841 (Highland Arts Centre Organ) built in 1946.|Nameplate of Casavant Frères Ltée. Opus 1841 (Highland Arts Centre Organ) rebuilt in 1946 from 1911 - Opus 452. </gallery>
==Further reading== {{main|List of pipe organ stops}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.highlandartstheatre.com Official Highland Arts Theatre Site] * [http://database.organsociety.org/SingleOrganDetails.php?OrganID=48983 Casavant Brothers, Ltd., Opus 452, 1911.] * [http://database.organsociety.org/SingleOrganDetails.php?OrganID=46148 Casavant Frères Ltée., Opus 1841, 1946.] * [http://www.casavant.ca/ Casavant Frères website] * {{Commons category-inline|Highland Arts Theatre}}

Opus 1841 (Highland Arts Centre Organ)}} [[Category:Individual pipe organs]] [[Category:Arts centres in Canada]] [[Category:Theatres in Nova Scotia]] [[Category:Community theatre]] [[Category:Music venues in Nova Scotia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in the Cape Breton Regional Municipality]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Cape Breton County, Nova Scotia]] [[Category:Former churches in Canada]]

revision.text:
{{hatnote|Not to be confused with [[Cindy Williams (EastEnders)]], the daughter of Cindy Beale}} {{Infobox soap character | series= EastEnders | image= Cindy Beale99.jpg | imagesize= 200px | name= Cindy Beale | portrayer= [[Michelle Collins]] | introducer= {{plainlist| *{{nowrap|[[Julia Smith]] (1988)}} *{{nowrap|[[Leonard Lewis]] (1992)}} *{{nowrap|[[Jane Harris (producer)|Jane Harris]] (1997)}}}} | years= {{nowrap|1988–1990,}} {{nowrap|1992–1998}} | first= Episode 340
{{start date|1988|5|10|df=y}} | last= Episode 1599
{{end date|1998|4|10|df=y}} | occupation= [[Entrepreneur]] | spinoffs= ''[[Children in Need 2014|The Ghosts of Ian Beale]]'' (2014) | classification= [[List of past EastEnders characters#Last appeared in 1998|Former; regular]] | family = [[Beale family|Beale]] | husband = [[Ian Beale]] (1989–1997) | father= Tom Williams | mother= [[Bev Williams]] | sisters= [[Gina Williams]] | sons= [[Steven Beale]]
[[Peter Beale]] | daughters= [[Lucy Beale]]
[[Cindy Williams (EastEnders)|Cindy Williams]] | grandsons = [[Louie Beale]] | granddaughters = [[Abi Branning (2017 character)|Abi Branning]]
[[Beth Williams (EastEnders)|Beth Williams]] }} '''Cindy Beale''' (also '''Williams''') is a fictional character from the [[BBC]] soap opera ''[[EastEnders]]'', played by [[Michelle Collins]] who made her first appearance on 10 May 1988 before leaving in 1990, returning in 1992 and making her final appearance on 10 April 1998. Cindy always has an eye for the lotharios of Walford and despite trying to settle down repeatedly with the more reliable [[Ian Beale]] ([[Adam Woodyatt]]), she is unable to remain faithful to him. She has a selfish streak, often more concerned about her own needs than her family's. She often lies and schemes, particularly where men are concerned. ==Storylines== [[File:Cindy222.jpg|left|thumb|180px|Cindy as she appeared in 1990.]] Cindy arrives in [[Albert Square]] in May 1988, working on her mother's market stall selling hats. She dates barman [[Simon Wicks]] ([[Nick Berry]]), who is also seeing [[Donna Ludlow]] ([[Matilda Ziegler]]), leading Cindy and Donna to fight for Simon's attention. However, Cindy grows tired of Simon's womanising, and despite his feelings for her, she moves on to [[Ian Beale]] ([[Adam Woodyatt]]), who is becoming a successful entrepreneur. Initially she only wants to make Simon jealous but she and Ian start dating and by February 1989, they announce their engagement. Meanwhile, Simon retaliates by reconciling with [[Sharon Watts]] ([[Letitia Dean]]). However, while working together late one night at [[The Queen Victoria]] [[public house]], Cindy and Simon have sex and Cindy becomes pregnant. She suggests leaving Ian for Simon but he refuses, not wanting to be tied down or upset his family so Cindy marries Ian, letting him think he is the baby's father, giving birth to [[Steven Beale|Steven]] in December 1989. However, Simon decides he wants to be a father to his son and convinces Cindy to leave Ian, devastating him with the news that Steven is not his son and a feud erupts when he realises Simon is the father. Ian's behaviour grows erratic; after attempting suicide and failing, he chooses to ruin Simon's life instead so Simon decides to leave Walford with Cindy and Steven, leaving Ian heartbroken. In 1992, Ian discovers that Simon has abandoned Cindy and Steven. Ian persuades her to return to Walford so he can help her bring Steven up. They reunite and Cindy gets pregnant in 1993. [[Richard Cole (EastEnders)|Richard Cole]] ([[Ian Reddington]]) is romantically interested in Cindy but she rejects him, so Richard tells people that he is the father of her twins. Everyone believes him, and Ian and Cindy almost separate but the truth emerges, just before [[Lucy Beale|Lucy]] and [[Peter Beale|Peter]] are born in December. Married life and motherhood takes its toll on Cindy and she has two affairs, first with Matt, a lifeguard, in 1994, and then with Simon's half-brother, [[David Wicks]] ([[Michael French]]), also Ian's half-brother, in 1995. Cindy and David meet secretly for a year and she falls in love with David, growing less and less tolerant of Ian. Suspecting Cindy is cheating, Ian hires a private investigator, who films Cindy and David in a clinch. Ian vows to take Cindy to court for custody of their children. David loses interest in Cindy so she takes drastic action and in October 1996, she hires a hitman to kill Ian. Although she changes her mind, it is too late and Ian is shot, collapsing in a pool of blood in front of Cindy. The police suspect Cindy is involved and when David is called in for questioning, Cindy knows she will soon be arrested, so decides to flee with her children. Assisted by David and [[Barry Evans (EastEnders)|Barry Evans]] ([[Shaun Williamson]]), she collects her sons, but is unable to get Lucy, and is forced to leave without her. David also stays behind, promising Cindy that he will try to get Lucy and join her later, but he never does. Ian's private investigator tracks Cindy to Italy in 1997. Ian, [[Phil Mitchell]] ([[Steve McFadden]]) and [[Grant Mitchell (EastEnders)|Grant Mitchell]] ([[Ross Kemp]]) find her, and Phil and Grant abduct Steven and Peter while Ian claims he still loves Cindy and will forgive her. Desperate to get her daughter back, Cindy goes along with him but grows suspicious and calls the police, but it is too late. Despite a police chase, Ian brings his sons back to Walford. Cindy soon follows Ian back to Walford with her new boyfriend, [[Nick Holland (EastEnders)|Nick Holland]] (Dominic Taylor). She takes Ian to court for custody of the children and wins. However, moments after the verdict, Cindy is arrested for attempted murder when Ian's associates persuade the hitman to tell the police about Cindy's involvement, so she loses and Ian wins full custody of the children and Cindy is charged and held on remand while she is pregnant by Nick. After realising Cindy is guilty, Nick leaves her in prison without any money for a lawyer. On 5 November 1998, Ian receives news that Cindy has died in childbirth. Her daughter survives and is named [[Cindy Williams (EastEnders)|Cindy]] by Ian, in her mother's honour. Custody is given to Cindy's sister, [[Gina Williams]] ([[Nicola Cowper]]). ==Creation== Cindy was introduced in 1988 in a minor role as a love-interest for [[Simon Wicks]] ([[Nick Berry]]). She was due to appear in only eleven episodes but the character evolved.{{cite news|title=Michelle can't hold back the years; Ex-EastEnders stars turns 40... but she is in no mood to celebrate|date=25 October 2003|work=Evening Times}} Writer [[Colin Brake]] has suggested that Cindy was "the most important character for the future" to be introduced in 1988, despite her low-key entrance.{{cite book |last=Brake|first= Colin|authorlink= Colin Brake|title= [[EastEnders spin-offs#Non-fiction books|EastEnders: The First 10 Years: A Celebration]] |year=1995|publisher=BBC Books|isbn=0-563-37057-2}} Actress Michelle Collins was asked to audition for the part by the soap's co-creator, [[Julia Smith]], who saw her perform on stage.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a200750/michelle-collins-avoids-cindy-look.html|title=Michelle Collins avoids 'Cindy look'|date=2 February 2010|work=Digital spy|accessdate=2010-04-25}} Collins had previously auditioned for the role of original character [[Mary Smith (EastEnders)|Mary Smith]], but at the time Julia Smith had decided they did not want that character to be from London, so that role went to [[Linda Davidson]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wgazette.com/spr05-cindydead.html|title=Cindy May Be Long Dead, But Michelle Collins Remembers her NY Fans|work=Walford gazette|accessdate=2010-04-25}} Three years on, Collins won the role of Cindy. She has commented, "Cindy arrived for 11 episodes, working on a hat stall and as a tease for Wicksy, but evolved into a much juicier character. [EastEnders creator] Julia Smith said it would change my life. I didn't believe her - how wrong I was." ==See also== *[[List of soap opera villains]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == *{{EEcharlink|cindy-beale}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110930210156/http://www.orange.co.uk/entertainment/television/pics/674_6.htm?linkfrom=entertainment_television_pics_674_5&link=link_next&article=top10tvbadgirlsentertainment Entry on orange.co.uk's Top 10 TV bitches] *[http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a270972/michelle-collins-glad-cindy-beale-died.html "Michelle Collins 'glad Cindy Beale died'."] {{EastEnders characters|past}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Beale, Cindy}} [[Category:EastEnders characters]] [[Category:Fictional criminals on soap operas]] [[Category:Fictional businesspeople]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1988]] [[Category:Female characters in television]] [[Category:Beale family (EastEnders)]]

[[Image:Manuel Chrysoloras - Imagines philologorum.jpg|thumb|right|Manuel Chrysoloras]]
The '''Erotemata''' are the first printed basic [[Greek language|Greek]] [[grammar]] in use in Western Europe, written by [[Manuel Chrysoloras]] who was a pioneer is spreading [[Greek literature]] in [[Western Europe]].
Chrysoloras' ''Erotemata'' were first published almost certainly in 1471 in [[Venice]] by Adam de Ambergau. It can be considered the first Greek book ever printed, since it bears a Greek title-page and the text contains large parts in Greek. It enjoyed immediate and considerable success in Italy, but also among later leading humanists, being studied by [[Thomas Linacre]] at [[Oxford]] and by [[Desiderius Erasmus]] at [[Cambridge]].<ref> CHRYSOLORAS, Manuel. Erotemata (In Greek).<sup>[http://www.ilab.org/db/detail.php?lang=fr&booknr=305378712][http://www.abebooks.fr/servlet/BookDetailsPL?bi=243219486&searchurl=an%3DCHRYSOLORAS%252C%2BManuel%253B][http://www.forumrarebooks.com/Chrysoloras-Manuel-In-greek.html]</sup></ref>

{{Use British English|date=December 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{unreferenced|date=May 2015}} [[File:Entrance to the Mall Galleries.JPG|thumb|The Mall Galleries building]] The '''Federation of British Artists''' (FBA) consists of nine art societies, and is based at '''Mall Galleries''' in [[London]] where the societies' Annual Exhibitions are held. The societies represent living artists working in the [[United Kingdom]] who create contemporary [[figurative art]]. Mall Galleries aim to ‘promote, inspire and educate audiences about the [[visual arts]].’
==Description==
The FBA has over 500 artist-members, who regularly exhibit their work and also accept open submissions from the public. In addition to the member societies, other societies and individual artists also stage shows at Mall Galleries. Over 100 prizes and awards are administered each year by the societies.
The gallery also has a commissions department and Friends organisation. The galleries' education department runs a Schools Programme, which includes gallery based workshops for Primary and Secondary school students.
Gallery projects include a drawing school and summer courses run by the [[New English Art Club]], as well as The [[Hesketh Hubbard Art Society]], the largest life drawing society in London, who meet to draw from life models.
The FBA is a registered charity, number 200048, and was established in 1961.
In February 2011 the Mall Galleries mounted an exhibition, "Pure Gold: 50 Years of the Federation of British Artists", curated by Anthony J Lester, Hon.RMS, FRBA, FRSA. An illustrated, 100 page catalogue ({{ISBN|978-0-9560219-3-9}}) was published to accompany the show.
==Societies in the FBA==
*[[Royal Institute of Painters in Water Colours]] *[[Royal Society of British Artists]] *[[Royal Society of Marine Artists]] *[[Royal Society of Portrait Painters]] *[[Royal Institute of Oil Painters]] *[[New English Art Club]] *[[The Pastel Society]] *[[Society of Wildlife Artists]] *[[Hesketh Hubbard Art Society]]
==Other exhibiting societies== <!--NOTE TO EDITORS: ALPHABETICAL ORDER--> Societies that have exhibited at Mall Galleries include: *Armed Forces Art Society *East Anglian Group of Marine Artists *[[Free Painters and Sculptors]] *[[The Guild of Aviation Artists]] *The Royal Society of Miniature Painters, Sculptors and Gravers *Society of Equestrian Artists *The [[Society of Women Artists]] *The Society for Art of Imagination *The Wapping Group of Artists
==Prizes== Prizes which are awarded at Mall Galleries include: *[[The Columbia Threadneedle Prize for painting and sculpture]] *The Sunday Times Water Colour competition *ING Discerning Eye
==See also== *[[Ken Howard (artist)|Ken Howard]] *[[William Bowyer (artist)|William Bowyer]] *[[Charles Williams (artist)|Charles Williams]]

[[Image:J-Dryden.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[John Dryden]], who formulated and wrote the heroic drama in the 1670s.]] '''Heroic drama''' is a type of [[Play (theatre)|play]] popular during the [[English Restoration|Restoration]] era in [[England]], distinguished by both its verse structure and its subject matter.<ref>Eugene M. Waith, ''Ideas of Greatness: Heroic Drama in England'', London, Routledge, 1971.</ref><ref>John Douglas Canfield, ''Heroes and States: On the Ideology of Restoration Tragedy'', Lexington, KY, University Press of Kentucky, 2000.</ref> The subgenre of heroic drama evolved through several works of the middle to later 1660s; [[John Dryden]]'s ''[[The Indian Emperour]]'' ([[1665 in literature|1665]]) and [[Roger Boyle, 1st Earl of Orrery| Roger Boyle's]] ''[[The Black Prince (play)|The Black Prince]]'' ([[1667 in literature|1667]]) were key developments.
==Dryden in 1670== The term "heroic drama" was invented by Dryden for his play, ''[[The Conquest of Granada]]'' ([[1670 in literature|1670]]). For the ''Preface'' to the printed version of the play, Dryden argued that the drama was a species of ''[[epic poetry]]'' for the stage, that, as the epic was to other poetry, so the heroic drama was to other plays. Consequently, Dryden derived a series of rules for this type of play.
First, the play should be composed in [[heroic verse]] (closed couplets in iambic pentameter). Second, the play must focus on a subject that pertains to national foundations, mythological events, or important and grand matters. Third, the hero of the heroic drama must be powerful, decisive, and, like [[Achilles]], dominating even when wrong. ''The Conquest of Granada'' followed all of these rules. The story was that of the national foundation of [[Spain]] (and [[Charles II of England|King Charles II]] was known to be fond of Spanish plays), and the hero, Almanzor, was a man of great martial prowess and temperament.
Dryden's ''Conquest of Granada'' is often considered one of the better heroic tragedies, but his highest achievement is his adaptation (which he called ''All for Love'', 1678) of Shakespeare's ''Anthony and Cleopatra'' to the heroic formula. Other heroic dramatists were Nathaniel Lee (''The Rival Queens'') and Thomas Otway, whose ''Venice Preserved'' is a fine tragedy that transcends the usual limitations of the form. We also owe indirectly to heroic tragedy two very amusing parodies of the type: the Duke of Buckingham's ''The Rehearsal'' and Henry Fielding's ''The Tragedy of Tragedies, or the Life and Death of Tom Thumb the Great''
==Other dramatists== "Those who associate 'heroic drama' primarily with the use of the 'heroic couplet' usually set as its extent the years from 1664 to 1678. This, certainly, is its period of fullest development and authority. Those who prefer to accentuate the elements suggested by the very term 'heroic' rather than the strict rhymed verse form are willing to admit wider limits."<ref>George Henry Nettleton, ''English Drama of the Restoration and Eighteenth Century, 1642–1780'', New York, Macmillan, 1914; p. 23.</ref> Restoration plays by Sir [[William Davenant]], [[Thomas Otway]], [[Nathaniel Lee]], [[John Crowne]], [[Elkanah Settle]], and [[John Banks (playwright)|John Banks]], and later works by [[Nicholas Rowe (writer)|Nicholas Rowe]] and [[Joseph Addison]], have been included in tighter or looser definitions of heroic drama.<ref>Nettleton, pp. 24-9; Waith, pp. 235-86.</ref>
==Heroic drama in literary criticism== Today, drama is divided up into numerous subgenres; Dryden, however, worked from [[Classical literature|Classical]] critics. There was little dramatic critical theory for him to appeal to, and the new rules brought over from [[France]] (particularly those of [[Pierre Corneille|Corneille]] and [[Nicolas Boileau-Despréaux|Boileau]]) did not match English theatrical history or practice. The emphasis on unities and on maintaining only Classically proscribed dramatic forms also came from [[Thomas Rymer]], who condemned the heterogeneity of the stage. [[Aristotle]] had only spoken of [[satire]], [[Epic poetry|epic]], and [[tragedy]], and [[Horace]] also wrote only of [[comedy]], tragedy and satire, and so Dryden was seeking to square actual theatrical practice with an ancient framework for literature. He was attempting his own neo-classicism. The [[First Folio]] of [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] had divided Shakespeare's plays into "history," "tragedy," and "comedy," but these terms were stretched. Dryden, therefore, implicitly recognizes that drama had moved into the territory of other types of poetry, but he strives to restrain that freedom by reforming the stage to a true and epic subject matter.
==Satirical response== [[George Villiers, 2nd Duke of Buckingham]] and others satirized heroic drama in ''[[The Rehearsal (play)|The Rehearsal]]''. The satire was successful enough that heroic drama largely disappeared afterward. Buckingham attacked the stupidity of blustering, military heroes, as well as the apparent self-importance of attempting a dramatic entertainment about the serious subjects of military and national history.
Buckingham's criticism of Dryden in ''[[The Rehearsal (play)|The Rehearsal]]'' is partly Dryden's bombastic verse but, more pointedly, Dryden's ''personal'' interest in creating a "pure" drama. The character of Bayes is ludicrous more for his hubris in damning actual plays in favor of imagined ones than he is for being a poetaster.
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=August 2015}} {{Underlinked|date=August 2015}} }} '''Hyperdrama''' is a dramatic performance generated by playscripts written in [[hypertext]]. The performance is noted for its split narrative with scenes branching to play simultaneously in an expanded performance space. The audience is mobile, able to follow actors and watch scenes as each individual chooses. According to [[Astrid Ensslin]] in her book ''Canonizing Hypertext''{{Cite book|title = Canonizing Hypertext|last = Ensslin|first = Astrid|publisher = Continuum|year = 2007|isbn = 978-0-8264-9558-7|location = |pages = 27}}(Continuum, London, 2007), the term hyperdrama "was coined by hyperdramatist and theorist Charles Deemer,{{Cite web|url = http://www.ibiblio.org/cdeemer/hdrama.htm|title = Hyperdrama|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} who understands 'traditional drama as a special case of hyperdrama' (p27)." Ensslin places Deemer's one-act hyperdrama ''The Last Song of Violeta Parra''{{Cite web|url = http://www.ibiblio.org/cdeemer/chile-m.html|title = The Last Song of Violeta Parra|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} in the canon of "first generation hypertext." Deemer also has written a hyperdrama expansion of Chekhov's ''The Seagull''.{{Cite book|title = The Seagull Hyperdrama|last = Deemer|first = Charles|publisher = Sextant Books|year = 2004|isbn = |location = |pages = }} In 2009, Harvard’s The American Repertory Theater and [[Punchdrunk]] performed ''[[Sleep No More (2009 play)|Sleep No More]],'' "a [http://www.ibiblio.org/cdeemer/newhype.htm hyperdrama] rendition of ''Macbeth'' with a creepy, Hitchcock feel."{{Cite web|url = http://htlit.com/archives/October2009/SleepNoMore.html|title = Sleep No More|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} Dr Hannah Rudman, who wrote "[http://www.consultrudman.com/benefactor-play/ The Benefactor: a Hyperdrama]" in 1998 with Dr Billy Smart, describes the form this way: "A hyperdrama is a play that is written in hypertext, that is performed as a promenade and that is realised on multiple levels. Scenes happen simultaneously throughout a performance space. In this hyperdrama, there are five different locations where the action takes place. The scripts for the different locations are divided into levels which represent the time span of the piece (about 45 minutes real time). All the characters and locations in this hyperdrama are of equal importance. As a reader, you could follow the path of one character through the play by clicking on their hypertext links; read all the separate scripts in a linear fashion; or explore the hyperdrama more randomly by swapping between rooms via the hotlinks."{{Cite web|url=http://www.consultrudman.com/benefactor-play/|title=The Benefactor: a Hyperdrama|last=Rudman|first=Hannah|date=|website=|publisher=|accessdate=}} Russell Anderson, author of ''Woyzeck: a Hyperdrama,'' calls his play "a performance in the ‘hyperdrama’ format: that is, where multiple elements of performance occur in multiple locations simultaneously."{{Cite web|url = https://www.academia.edu/10351971/Woyzeck_a_Hyperdrama|title = Woyzeck: a Hyperdrama|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} Tegan Zimmerman uses the presentation software [[Prezi]] to explore "Hypertext and Hyperdrama" and their relationship online.{{Cite web|url = https://prezi.com/3bj3w8y4eq2d/hypertext-and-hyperdrama/|title = Hypertext and Hyperdrama|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} Other hyperdrama works of note are ''[[Tamara (play)|Tamara]]'' by John Krizanc, which had a long run in Los Angeles in the 1980s, and ''[[Tony and Tina's Wedding]]'', perhaps the most widely produced and popular hyperdrama. A number of universities have added the study of Hyperdrama to their hypertext and electronic media studies: the University of Virginia,{{Cite web|url = http://www2.iath.virginia.edu/courses/ensp481/syllabus.html|title = Syllabus|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} Tunxis Community College,{{Cite web|url = http://www.tunxis.edu/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/Hyperdrama08-syllabus-14-22.pdf|title = Course Syllabus|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} New York University,{{Cite web|url = http://www.nyu.edu/classes/keefer/TimeSpace/timespace.html|title = Writing: Time and Space|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} among them. Discussion of hyperdrama is included in the book ''Theatre In Cyberspace'' (Peter Lang, 1999): "theatre practitioners are increasing their potential audiences with online technology while attempting to discover how to present theatre in an interactive yet non-corporeal way. Also fascinating is how educators and practitioners can collaborate, creating online performance spaces that can be adapted for teaching, and creating online teaching techniques that can be adapted for performance. This volume of essays presents information from some of the pioneers in the field of cyberspace theatre who write of their work in both theoretical and practical terms, thus creating a kind of ''Theatre and Its Double'' for computers and theatre."{{Cite web|url=http://www.peterlang.com/index.cfm?event=cmp.ccc.seitenstruktur.detailseiten&seitentyp=produkt&pk=44689 |title=Peter Lang Publishers |date= |accessdate= |website= |publisher= |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222151510/http://www.peterlang.com/index.cfm?event=cmp.ccc.seitenstruktur.detailseiten&seitentyp=produkt&pk=44689 |archivedate=2015-12-22 |df= }} ==See also== *[[Dramatic theory]] *[[Tamara (play)]] *[[Punchdrunk]] **[[Sleep No More (2009 play)|Sleep No More]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * ''Changing Key: a video hyperdrama lecture-demonstration.''[http://www.ibiblio.org/cdeemer/ChangingKey.htm] part of an MA Thesis on Hyperdrama [http://drepository.asu.edu.eg/xmlui/bitstream/handle/123456789/146973/G7382.pdf?sequence=1] [[Category:Drama]]

revision.text:
{{primary sources|date=January 2018}}
{{Infobox magazine | logo = | logo_size = | image_size = | image_file = | image_alt = | image_caption = Ibraaz logo | editor_title = Editor-in-Chief | editor = Anthony Downey | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | photographer = | category = [[art magazines]] | frequency = Monthly | circulation = | publisher = | founder = Kamel Lazaar, Lina Lazaar, Anthony Downey | founded = 2011 | firstdate = | company = | country = [[UK]] | based = [[London]] | language = English/Arabic | website = {{URL|http://www.ibraaz.org}} | issn = | oclc = }} '''''Ibraaz''''' is an [[online]] forum for [[visual culture]] in [[North Africa]] and the [[Middle East]].
== Publication == ''Ibraaz'' publishes an annual online platform that focuses on research questions conceived through a network of editorial contributors based in the Middle East and beyond.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibraaz.org/platforms/|title=Where to Now? Shifting Regional Dynamics and Cultural Production in North Africa and the Middle East|website=Ibraaz|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> Its key editorial aim is to publish emerging writers and artists, alongside work by internationally renowned writers, academics, curators, activists, and filmmakers.
''Ibraaz'' works by posing annual ‘platforms’ where a question is put to writers, thinkers and artists about an issue relevant to the [[MENA]] region. This platform is sent to respondents both within and beyond the MENA region. Content is added to the website every month. Contributions are archived every twelve months when a new platform begins.
''Ibraaz ''also publishes a series of books, edited by Anthony Downey, under the 'Visual Culture in the Middle East' title. To date, these have included ''Future Imperfect: Contemporary Art Practices and Cultural Institutions in the Middle East ''(Sternberg Press, 2016); ''Dissonant Archives: Contemporary Visual Culture and Contested Narratives in the Middle East ''([[I.B. Tauris]], 2015); and ''Uncommon Grounds: New Media and Critical Practices in North Africa and the Middle East'' (I.B. Tauris, 2014).
== History == ''Ibraaz'' was set up from discussions between Anthony Downey, Kamel Lazaar and Lina Lazaar. It was founded as a research platform to rethink stereotypical frames of reference that have defined discussions around cultural production from within and beyond the Middle East.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibraaz.org/essays/8|title=Beyond the Former Middle East|website=Ibraaz|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> The inaugural platform was launched as part of the 54th [[Venice Biennale]] in June 2011,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibraaz.org/news/1|title=Ibraaz Launch Venice|website=Ibraaz|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> alongside the exhibition ''The Future of a Promise'', the largest Pan-Arab exhibition to be held at the Venice Biennale. ''Ibraaz'' Platform 001 responded to regional developments across North Africa and the Middle East, the so-called ‘[[Arab Spring]]’ and its effects upon the visual culture of the region.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibraaz.org/platforms/1|title=What do we need to know about the MENA region today?|website=Ibraaz|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> ''Ibraaz'' is an initiative of the [[Kamel Lazaar Foundation]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.kamellazaarfoundation.org/project/ibraaz|title=Ibraaz|date=2016-09-19|work=Kamel Lazaar Foundation|access-date=2017-11-03|language=en}}</ref>
== Scope of coverage and activities == ''Ibraaz''’s content covers mostly contemporary visual culture from or about the Middle East and its [[diaspora]]. However, it can also include non-visual culture, such as [[Sound art|sound-based art]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibraaz.org/projects/53|title=98weeks: Our Lines Are Now Open|website=Ibraaz|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> and other periods, such as [[Modern art]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibraaz.org/reviews/39|title=Re-Framing Modernism|website=Ibraaz|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> The content consists of essays, interviews, reviews, artists' projects, platform responses and video contributions in its online channel.
In addition to the online platform and publications, ''Ibraaz'' organize and co-host events relating to visual culture in the Middle East. These include book launches,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://delfinafoundation.com/whats-on/book-launch-uncommon-grounds-with-ibraaz-and-ib-tauris/|title=Delfina Foundation — Book Launch: Uncommon Grounds with Ibraaz & I.B. Tauris|website=delfinafoundation.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> panel discussions<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibraaz.org/channel/57|title=Ibraaz Talks: 13th Istanbul Biennial|website=Ibraaz|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> and the annual JAOU Tunis conference.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibraaz.org/news/120|title=JAOU Tunis 2015|website=Ibraaz|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> In 2013, ''Ibraaz'' held the conference ''Future Imperfect: Cultural Propositions and Global Perspectives'' at [[Tate Modern]], [[London]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/whats-on/tate-modern/conference/future-imperfect|title=Future Imperfect: Cultural propositions and global perspectives – Conference at Tate Modern {{!}} Tate|last=Tate|website=Tate|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> The event featured contributors including [[Douglas Coupland]], [[Raqs Media Collective]], [[Joana Hadjithomas]] & [[Khalil Joreige]], [[Zineb Sedira]], and others.
''Ibraaz'' periodically collaborates with a range of international artists and organisations, frequently publishing online exhibition catalogues and audiovisual content. Such partnerships have included with [[Asia Contemporary Art Week]]'s FIELD MEETING Take 4: Thinking Practice,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibraaz.org/publications/129|title=FIELD MEETING Take 4: Thinking Practice|website=Ibraaz|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> held at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] and [[Asia Society]], [[New York City]], [[United States|USA]] in 2016; the [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] [[wikt:biennial|biennial]] [[Qalandiya International (QI)|Qalandiya International]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibraaz.org/publications/121|title=Qalandiya International 2016|website=Ibraaz|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref>; the [[Delfina Foundation]], London<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibraaz.org/publications/38|title=A Prologue to the Past and Present State of Things|website=Ibraaz|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref>; [[Hayward Gallery]], London, and [[Maraya Art Centre|Maraya Art Center]], [[Sharjah]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibraaz.org/publications/25|title=Echoes & Reverberations|website=Ibraaz|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref>; and [[The Jerusalem Show]], [[Jerusalem]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibraaz.org/publications/3|title=The Jerusalem Show|website=Ibraaz|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref>
== Contributors == Notable contributors to Ibraaz include: {{colbegin|colwidth=20em}} *[[Lawrence Abu Hamdan]] *[[John Akomfrah]] *[[Wafaa Bilal]] *[[Shezad Dawood]] *[[Okwui Enwezor]] *[[Monir Shahroudy Farmanfarmaian]] *[[Coco Fusco]] *[[Hans Haacke]] *[[Mona Hatoum]] *[[Emily Jacir]] *[[Gulf Labor]] *[[Walter D. Mignolo]] *[[Mosireen]] *[[Michael Rakowitz]] *[[Beatrix Ruf]] *[[Hassan Sharif]] *[[Wael Shawky]] *[[Adam Szymczyk]] *[[Ala Younis]] {{colend}}

Tauris blog, ''7 questions for Ibraaz’s Anthony Downey''] * [http://www.anthonydowney.com/2017/02/17/interview-with-anthony-downey-divan-journal-december-2016/ anthonydowney.com, ''Interview with Anthony Downey, Di'van Journal, December, 2016''] [[Category:Contemporary art]] [[Category:Contemporary art magazines]] [[Category:Art magazines]] [[Category:Monthly magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 2011]] __FORCETOC__

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox Magazine | image_file = | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = Andrew Mast | editor_title = Managing Editor | frequency = Weekly | circulation = | category = [[Arts]] | company = | publisher = [[Street Press Australia]] | firstdate = | finaldate = 14 August 2013 | country = Australia | based = [[Melbourne]] | language = [[English language|English]] | website = [http://www.inpress.com.au/ Official site] | issn = }} '''''Inpress''''' was a free weekly [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]]-sized music magazine ([[street press]]) that was published in [[Melbourne]],<ref name=sbel>{{cite news|author=Sarah Bella|title=Drum Media, Inpress and Time Off to be Rebranded|url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/news/drum-media-inpress-time-off-to-be-rebranded/|accessdate=23 November 2015|work=Music Feeds|date=1 August 2013}}</ref><ref name=appd>{{cite web|title=Inpress magazine|url=http://www.appdata.com/uapps/ios/2580401-inpress-magazine|work=AppData|accessdate=23 November 2015}}</ref> and was released in the [[Geelong]] and [[Mornington Peninsula]] areas of [[Victoria, Australia]]. The magazine was published by [[Street Press Australia]]<ref name=appd/> on a weekly basis every Wednesday.
The magazine comprised three main sections: All music news, features and reviews fall under the ''Inpress'' banner, arts and film is covered by ''Interval'', and the central section is [[dance music]]/[[urban music]] and [[Nightclub|nightclubbing]] magazine ''Zebra'', which is also distributed separately from ''Inpress''. The editors of the paper were Andrew Mast (Managing Editor), Shane O'Donohue (Editor), Kris Swales (''Zebra'' Editor) and Daniel Crichton-Rouse (''Interval'' Editor). [[Myf Warhurst]] is a former editor.
''Inpress'' also frequently published 'special features', such as their yearly [[Melbourne International Comedy Festival]] guide.
''Inpress'' contained many popular features, including local cartoonist and musician [[Fred Negro]]'s weekly cult comic strip, ''Pub''. Other notable features within ''Inpress'' included ''Finish Line'' (industry news column), Sugarfoot's ''SoDa Pop'' (pop gossip/news column - a differently named version of which had previously appeared in ''Beat Magazine''<ref>{{cite web|title=Beat|url=http://www.beat.com.au/|work=Beat|accessdate=23 November 2015}}</ref> until early 2004; [[Jeff Jenkins]]' ''Howzat!'' (indie rock and pop news), [[Clem Bastow]]'s ''Singled Out'' (singles reviews column) and [[Anthony Carew]]'s (some would say) notorious film reviews column in ''Interval'', ''Film Carew''.
in 2006, Interests associated with ''Inpress'' publishers Craig and Leigh Treweek bought the influential [[Sydney]] street press ''[[Drum Media]]''.<ref>{{cite news|author=Monika Lackmann|title=Sydney’s Drum Media Bought By Melbourne’s Inpress Magazine|url=http://www.fasterlouder.com.au/news/aust/3967/|accessdate=23 November 2015|work=Faster Louder|date=8 February 2006}}</ref> Craig Treweek said at the time that "This is a great opportunity to build a strong music media outlet that is supportive of the local music scene at a grass roots level."
In August 2013 ''Inpress'' and other two magazines of the company, ''Drum Media'' and ''[[Time Off]]'', were merged under a new title, ''The Music''.<ref name=sbel/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.inpress.com.au/ Official website] (no content except advertising specifications)
