revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Theatre companies based in New York City to [[:Category:Theatre companies in New York City]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
The '''Jewish Theater of New York''' is a theatre company founded in 1994, with the production of ''[[One Hundred Gates]]'' by playwright/director [[Tuvia Tenenbom]].
{{As of|2003}}, The Jewish Theater of New York is the only [[English language|English-speaking]] [[Jew]]ish theatre company in [[New York (state)|New York state]].
The Theater normally presents between one and two new shows a year in [[New York City]]. {{As of|2001}}, its productions are also mounted yearly in [[Europe]] [http://jewishtheater.org/Jewish%20Theater/International%20Partners.htm (link)]. Starting 2013, the Jewish Theater combines action and word in a program it calls, Redefining Theater Through Literature, uniting [http://jewishtheater.org/Jewish%20Theater/Presentations-Abroad-2013.htm stage and literature], acting and books, into one unit.
The Theater, [[avant-garde]] and [[Experimental theatre|experimental]] at times, has been highly acclaimed by local and international critics. Some of its shows, such as ''Father of the Angels,'' ''Love Letters to Adolf Hitler,'' ''Diary of Adolf Eichmann,'' ''The Suicide Bomber,'' ''Love in Great Neck,'' ''The Last Virgin,'' ''Last Jew in Europe'' and others, have been written about in much of the Western press [http://jewishtheater.org/Jewish%20Theater/reviews.htm (link)] and are also studied in universities.
The Jewish Theater of New York was founded by [[Tuvia Tenenbom]], a former [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]] [[rabbi]].
==External links==
* [http://www.jewishtheater.org/ Jewish Theater of New York] *http://theater2.nytimes.com/mem/theater/treview.html?_r=1&html_title=&tols_title=FATHER%20OF%20THE%20ANGELS%20(PLAY)&pdate=19971027&byline=By%20D.%20J.%20R.%20BRUCKNER&id=1077011429944&oref=slogin *http://theater2.nytimes.com/mem/theater/treview.html?html_title=&tols_title=LAST%20VIRGIN,%20THE%20(PLAY)&pdate=20030116&byline=By%20ANITA%20GATES&id=1077011432582 *http://www.e-teatr.pl/pl/artykuly/53289.html
[[Category:Jewish-American history]] [[Category:Jews and Judaism in New York City]] [[Category:Theatre companies in New York City]] [[Category:Jewish theatres]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1994]]

[[Image:Byzantine - Chalice with Apostles Venerating the Cross - Walters 57636 - Profile.jpg|thumb|An example piece from the Kaper Koraon Treasure.]] The '''Kaper Koraon Treasure''' is a [[Byzantine silver]] treasure consisting of 56 individual [[silver]] items originating from [[Syria]] in the sixth and seventh centuries.
==History== The treasure was re-discovered between 1908 and 1910. It was originally believed to have belonged to the church in [[Antioch]], a thriving Roman city on the Mediterranean It can now be argued that the items come from a larger collection of silver from the church of Saint Sergios in modern-day [[Kurin]], [[Syria]] or that the pieces belonged to a small local church.<ref name="JSTOR">{{cite journal|last1=Evans|first1=Helen|title=The Arts of Byzantium|journal=The Metropolitan Museum of Art Bulletin|date=2001|volume=58|issue=4|pages=1–68|jstor=3269176}}</ref> The final items of the collection were likely interred at the site in the seventh century as the [[Byzantine Empire]] subsequently lost this area of Syria to the [[Persian Empire|Persian]] army. The later conquering by the Muslim Arab army permanently removed the area from Byzantine control.<ref name="JSTOR"/>
It is believed that the Persian and Muslim Arab take-overs were relatively peaceful as historic sites around the area show little to no damage that could be attributed to that time. Though religion began to shift following the change of power and [[Christian]] artifacts were increasingly stored away from public viewing, the area did continue to benefit from relative wealth and prosperity, creating many [[secular]] works. The real halt to production of silver treasures is thought to have followed a plague throughout the area from 542 to 544. This had a lasting impact on the economic status of the region.<ref name="Dumbarton">{{cite journal|last1=Foss|first1=Clive|title=Syria in Transition, A. D. 550-750: An Archaeological Approach|journal=Dumbarton Oak Papers|date=1997|volume=51|pages=189–269|jstor=1291765}}</ref>
There is evidence that this accumulation of local wealth in silver objects was common throughout the area leading up to the Persian control and the sixth century plague. Similar treasures have been found at [[Stuma]], [[Ariha|Riha]], [[Hama]], and Antioch to name a few.<ref name="Dumbarton"/>
The objects found in the Kaper Koraon treasure were not originally prestigious [[shrine]] gifts but were likely relatively cheap [[imitations]] made specifically for a village [[Church (building)|church]]. This can be clearly seen from recent investigations into the pieces which have shown high quantities of [[copper]] and other metals melted in with the silver to increase malleability and decrease production costs. It is estimated that these items were the collective donations from five local families over a period of at least three decades. Many of the stamps present on the pieces are believed to have been added after production and some note the specific [[donor]]s of each piece.<ref name="Walters">{{cite book|last1=Mango|first1=Marlia Mundell|title=Silver from Early Byzantium: the Kaper Koraon and Related Treasures|date=1986|publisher=Walters Art Gallery|location=Baltimore, Maryland}}</ref>
==Notable pieces== The Kaper Koraon treasure consists of 56 total silver objects including: eight [[chalice]]s, seven [[paten]]s, five crosses, one [[cross]] [[revetment]], two lamp stands, three lamps, three ewers, one flask, one bowl, one mirror, one box, eleven spoons, one ladle, two strainers, two fans, and four plaques. The other three objects are only partial pieces of broken fragments likely from other [[wikt:plaque|plaque]]s. Many of the items are religious in nature including images of the cross and Jesus's disciples.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Byzyntine Legacy: Kaper Koraon Treasure|url=http://www.thebyzantinelegacy.com/walter-kaperkoraon|publisher=Walters Art Museum|accessdate=8 January 2018}}</ref> Some are believed to be secular but were stored with the church collection either for safe-keeping on behalf of the owner or stores of wealth for the [[parish]].<ref name="Walters"/>
Most of the silver pieces shown here still show evidence of hammering either visibly or through careful machine investigation. Due to the limited skill level of local workers and the overworking of [[malleable]] metal, many items featured here have stress fractures or chips that were original to the piece. Any repairs visible, such as the re-welding of a handle onto an [[ewar]], are likely original and occurred before the [[internment]] of the treasure. Many of the chalices were hammered, welded together, and then lathed to smooth out the seams between the cup and the stem. Some chalices shows signs of wear at these seams and around the top rim due to the method of their construction.<ref name="Walters"/>
Since their discovery, the items of the Kaper Koraon treasure have dispersed into public and private collections throughout the world including [[The Walters Art Museum]].
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Byzantine art]] [[Category:Silver objects]] [[Category:Syrian art]]

{{EngvarB|date=March 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Laura Bayley | image = Kiss in the Tunnel frame.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = Bayley (at right), with George Albert Smith, in ''[[The Kiss in the Tunnel]]'' (1899) | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1862|02|04}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1938|10|25|1862|02|04}} | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_co-ordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | other_names = {{ubl|Laura Eugenia Smith|Mrs. George Albert Smith}} | nationality = British | occupation = Actress, filmmaker | spouse = [[George Albert Smith (film pioneer)|George Albert Smith]] | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = }}
'''Laura Eugenia Bayley''' (4 February 1862 – 25 October 1938) was a British actress and filmmaker, active in the [[Brighton School (filmmaking)|Brighton School]] of early cinema pioneers. Born in [[Ramsgate]], Bayley performed onstage in [[Victorian burlesque]]s, [[revue]]s, and [[pantomime]]s, often with her three sisters. After marrying the showman [[George Albert Smith (film pioneer)|George Albert Smith]], she entered the world of early experiments with motion picture film; she played main roles in many of the most important films Smith made between 1897 and 1903, including ''[[The Kiss in the Tunnel]]'' (1899) and ''[[Mary Jane's Mishap]]'' (1903).
Behind the camera, Bayley likely played a significant hand in the creative development of Smith's fiction films, and may have directed some of those currently credited to him. She also directed and supervised numerous other films on her own, including a series for an early show-at-home projector design. Film historians have highlighted her prolific career as a film performer as well as the creative talent she brought to filmmaking.
==Early life and stage career== [[File:Brighton aquarium photochrom.jpg|thumb|left|The Brighton Aquarium, where Bayley and her sisters performed in [[Victorian burlesque]]s]] Bayley was born on 4 February 1862 in the English seaside town of [[Ramsgate]].<ref>{{citation|title=Cinema-by-Sea: Film and Cinema in Brighton & Hove since 1896|first=David|last=Fisher|location=Brighton|publisher=Terra Media|year=2012|page=17}}</ref> She and her sisters Blanche, Florence, and Eva worked together as performers for J. D. Hunter's Theatre Company, which produced a "[[Victorian burlesque|burlesque]]" extravaganza every year at the Brighton Aquarium.<ref name=FG/> ''The Brighton Society'', in 1887, praised "the Misses Bayley … who, by their charming vocal selections added so considerably to the success of the burlesque ''Brown and the Brahmins''".<ref name=FG/>
Bayley's three sisters also performed without her for some Aquarium productions, such as in the [[pantomime]]s ''[[Cinderella]]'' and ''[[Dick Whittington]]'' in August 1890 and again in the latter in 1892, but the four sisters were reunited at the Aquarium for ''[[Babes in the Wood]]'' in 1894, about which the ''[[Brighton Herald]]'' commented that "The Robin Hood of Miss Laura Bayley is a distinctly comely and cheery Robin Hood".<ref name=FG/>
On 13 June 1888, at the Congregational Church in Ramsgate, Bayley married [[George Albert Smith (film pioneer)|George Albert Smith]]. Smith, known as "Bertie" among his professional colleagues,<ref name=EraWedding>{{citation|title=Provincial Theatricals|newspaper=[[The Era (newspaper)|The Era]]|date=16 June 1888|number=2595|page=18}}</ref> was a young stage entertainer, performing [[Stage hypnosis|hypnosis act]]s and [[second sight]] routines in local venues, including the Brighton Aquarium.<ref name=FG/> Bayley and Smith married in a double wedding: the other couple was Bayley's sister Florence and the Bayleys' theatrical colleague J. D. Hunter.<ref name=EraWedding/>
Bayley and Smith had two children, Harold Norman and Dorothy Eugenie, in 1889 and 1890, respectively.<ref name=WFPP/> In 1892, Smith acquired a lease on St. Ann's Well and Wild Garden, a [[pleasure garden]] in Brighton; it reopened under his management the following spring. Together, Bayley and Smith mounted summer [[Fancy dress party|fancy dress parties]], attended by as many as 2,000 costumed patrons, at the garden. Smith also gave [[magic lantern]] performances and [[Diorama|dioramic lectures]], and exhibited the newly invented [[Phonograph|Edison phonograph]], as part of the garden's entertainments.<ref name=FG/>
==Film career== [[File:Mary Jane's Mishap portrait.jpg|thumb|Bayley in costume for ''[[Mary Jane's Mishap]]'' (1903)]] Smith's interest in novel forms of entertainment led him toward early experiments with motion picture film, and in 1897 he began making short films on the St. Ann's Well grounds.<ref name=FG/> By the time of Smith's foray into filmmaking, Bayley had had wide experience in comic acting for [[pantomime]] and [[revue]]s, and Smith drew extensively on her knowledge of visual humour and audience tastes.<ref name=BFIsmith/> She played lead roles in many of his most significant films, including ''[[Hanging out the Clothes]]'' (1897), ''[[Santa Claus (1898 film)|Santa Claus]]'' (1898), ''[[Cinderella (1898 film)|Cinderella]]'' (1898), ''[[The Kiss in the Tunnel]]'' (1899), ''[[As Seen Through the Telescope]]'' (1900), ''[[Let Me Dream Again]]'' (1900), ''[[Dorothy's Dream]]'' (1900), and ''[[Mary Jane's Mishap]]'' (1903).<ref name=FG/> In at least one instance, Smith and Bayley mixed their theatrical and film work together: when J. D. Hunter's company toured ''Dick Whittington'' in early 1897, Bayley and her sister Blanche performed live onstage, while Smith came along on the tour to exhibit his "animated photographs" as part of the entertainment.<ref>{{citation|title=Suburbia, seaside and sensation: showing films in London and the south-east, 1896–1897|pages=45–46|first=Amy Louise|last=Bethel|type=PhD thesis|publisher=University of York|year=2015|url=http://etheses.whiterose.ac.uk/17808/1/Amy%20Bethel%20Thesis_Suburbia%2C%20Seaside%20and%20Sensation.pdf|accessdate=15 January 2018}}</ref>
Other members of Bayley's family also became involved in Smith's filmmaking; all three of her sisters probably appeared in his films,<ref name=DR/> as did her two children;<ref name=WFPP/> notably, the film historian Frank Gray suggested that Harold and Dorothy Smith probably both appear in ''Santa Claus'' and ''[[The House That Jack Built (1900 film)|The House that Jack Built]]'', and that Harold also plays the grandson in ''[[Grandma's Reading Glass]]''.<ref name=FG/>
During her acting career, Bayley also worked on her own as a filmmaker, making numerous short films that were designed and marketed for a home projector, the [[Biokam]].<ref name=WFPP/> Smith and Bayley probably worked in creative collaboration to devise the fiction films Smith directed;<ref name=LM/> Bayley may also have directed some of the films currently credited to Smith, as his records indicate that she supervised the "facials" (comic short films emphasising facial expression).<ref name=DR/> Bayley handled sales of the Biokam films and related materials,<ref name=WFPP/><ref name=EC/> and may also have participated in the process of making cameras.<ref name=DR/>
Later in the decade, after the series of Biokam films, Bayley also appeared in some of Smith's 1906–1908 tests of the colour-film process [[Kinemacolor]].<ref name=WFPP/> Bayley died at home at 7 Melville Road, Hove, on 25 October 1938.<ref>{{citation|title=Laura E Smith|work=Death Records|publisher=Brighton & Hove Register Office|year=1938}}</ref>
==Legacy== Bayley's work was usually overlooked in twentieth-century assessments of the [[Brighton School (filmmaking)|Brighton School]], with some film historians simply calling her "Smith's wife" or "Mrs. Smith". Several twenty-first-century film historians have drawn attention to this neglect and to her contributions, though she remains relatively little-known in the field.<ref name=EC/> The [[British Film Institute]]'s [[Screenonline]] database ranks Bayley as "the most prolific British actress" in turn-of-the-century cinema.<ref name=MD/> In program notes for the [[Pordenone Silent Film Festival]], where three Bayley films were shown in 2002, the film historian David Robinson cited Bayley and her sisters as the first known comediennes in British film.<ref name=DR/> The film writer Ellen Cheshire, in a 2016 study of women working behind the camera in early film, identified Bayley as film history's first woman cinematographer.<ref name=EC/>
In a discussion of Bayley's collaboration with Smith, the film historian Frank Gray wrote: "Laura Bayley brought to this creative work a keen understanding of popular texts, an unself-conscious and dynamic style of acting and a rich sense of humour. Audiences which still laugh at her winking at the camera when watching ''Mary Jane's Mishap'' are acknowledging her considerable achievement."<ref name=FG/> <!--The following table was intended as a filmography, but since sources differ dramatically as to what films feature Laura Bayley, I'm removing it for now. If reliable sources can be found for the roles, it can be revised and restored. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Title !! Role |- | 1897 || ''Hanging out the Clothes; or, Master, Mistress and Maid'' || The maid |- | 1897 || ''[[The X Rays]]'' || The young woman |- | 1897 || ''[[The Haunted Castle (1897 British film)|The Haunted Castle]]'' || |- | 1898 || ''Cinderella and the Fairy Godmother'' || Cinderella |- | 1898 || ''[[Santa Claus (1898 film)|Santa Claus]]'' || The mother |- | 1899 || ''[[The Death of Poor Joe]]'' || Poor Joe |- | 1899 || ''[[The Kiss in the Tunnel]]'' || The young woman |- | 1900 || ''[[Let Me Dream Again]]'' || The young woman |- | 1900 || ''Scandal over the Teacups'' || |- | 1902 || ''Robinson Crusoe'' || Robinson Crusoe |- | 1903 || ''[[Mary Jane's Mishap|Mary Jane's Mishap; or, Don't Fool with the Paraffin]]'' || Mary Jane |- | 1906 || ''Two Clowns'' || Clown |}-->
==References== [[File:G. A. Smith, Two Clowns.jpg|thumb|Bayley (at right) in the colour film ''Two Clowns'' (c.1907)]] {{reflist|refs= <ref name=BFIsmith>{{citation|title=Smith, G.A. (1864–1959)|first=Frank|last=Gray|work=[[Screenonline]]|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/people/id/449633/|accessdate=20 October 2016}}</ref> <ref name=DR>{{citation|first=David|last=Robinson|title=Funny Ladies: The Comediennes of the Silent Screen|work=[[Pordenone Silent Film Festival|Le Giornate del Cinema Muto]]|publisher=Cineteca del Friuli|year=2002|page=2 (Films, I–Y)|url=http://www.cinetecadelfriuli.org/gcm/ed_precedenti/edizione2002/Funny_Ladies2.html|accessdate=23 December 2016}}</ref> <ref name=EC>{{citation|editor1-last=Bridges|editor1-first=Melody|editor2-last=Robson|editor2-first=Cheryl|title=Silent Women: Pioneers of Cinema|location=Twickenham|publisher=Supernova|year=2016|first=Ellen|last=Cheshire|chapter=Who Was the First Female Cinematographer in the World?|pages=228–240}}</ref> <ref name=FG>{{citation|title=Smith the Showman: The Early Years of George Albert Smith|first=Frank|last=Gray|journal=Film History|volume=10|issue=1|year=1998|pages=8–20|jstor=3815398}}</ref> <ref name=LM>{{citation|first=Luke|last=McKernan|title=Women Silent Filmmakers in Britain|year=2007|work=''lukemckernan.com''|url=http://lukemckernan.com/wp-content/uploads/britishsilentwomen_v2.pdf|accessdate=31 December 2016|page=3}}</ref><!--while this is a privately published source, searches indicate it has been cited academically as a good resource, e.g. in Anthony Slide's ''A Special Relationship'' (UP of Mississippi, 2015) and on the East Anglian Film Archive site--> <ref name=MD>{{citation|title=Mary Jane's Mishap or, Don't Fool with the Paraffin (1903)|work=[[Screenonline]]|first=Mark|last=Duguid|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/film/id/438170/index.html|accessdate=20 October 2016}}</ref> <ref name=WFPP>{{citation|last=Fletcher|first=Tony|title=Laura Bayley|editor-first1=Jane|editor-last1=Gaines|editor-first2=Radha|editor-last2=Vatsal|editor-first3=Monica|editor-last3=Dall'Asta|work=Women Film Pioneers Project|publisher=Center for Digital Research and Scholarship, Columbia University Libraries|year=2013|url=https://wfpp.cdrs.columbia.edu/pioneer/ccp-laura-bayley/|accessdate=20 October 2016}}</ref> }}

{{Infobox person | name = Leo Castelli | image = Leo Castelli seated, Jasper Johns standing.jpg | alt = | caption = Leo Castelli seated with artist [[Jasper Johns]] standing behind, {{abbr|c.|circa}} 1970s | birth_name = Leo Krausz | birth_date = {{Birth date|1907|9|4|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Trieste]], [[Austrian Littoral]], [[Austria-Hungary]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1999|8|21|1907|9|4|mf=y}} | death_place = New York City, United States | nationality = Italian, American | other_names = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }}
'''Leo Castelli''' (born '''Leo Krausz'''; September 4, 1907 – August 21, 1999) was an Italian-American [[art dealer]].<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9407E2D61038F930A1575BC0A96F958260&sec=&spon=&partner=permalink&exprod=permalink Russel, John. "Leo Castelli, Influential Art Dealer, Dies at 91." New York Times, August 23, 1999.]</ref> His gallery showcased [[contemporary art]] for five decades.<ref>[http://www.salon.com/people/obit/1999/09/11/castelli/ DiEgidio, Tom. "Leo Castelli." Salon.com, September 11, 1999.]</ref> Among the movements which Castelli showed were [[Surrealism]], [[Abstract Expressionism]], [[Neo-Dada]], [[Pop Art]], [[Op Art]], [[Color field painting]], [[Hard-edge painting]], [[Lyrical Abstraction]], [[Minimal Art]], [[Conceptual Art]], and [[Neo-expressionism]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m1UEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA70 |first=David|last=Bourdon|publisher=Life Magazine|date=May 1970|title=Whats Up in Art, The Castelli Clan|accessdate=June 9, 2010}}</ref>
==Early life and career== Leo Castelli was born Leo Krausz,<ref name="Garner">Dwight Garner (May 18, 2010), [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/19/books/19book.html A Smooth Operator, at the Vanguard of the Gallery World in the 1960s] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref> in [[Trieste]], [[Austria-Hungary]], the second of three children of Italian and Austro-Hungarian Jewish origin.<ref name="Schjeldahl">[[Peter Schjeldahl]] (June 7, 2010), [http://www.newyorker.com/arts/critics/books/2010/06/07/100607crbo_books_schjeldahl Leo the Lion - How the Castelli gallery changed the art world] ''[[The New Yorker]]''.</ref> His father was Ernest Krauss, a Hungarian by birth, who had gone to Trieste as a young man and married wealthy heiress Bianca Castelli,<ref name="Oliver">Myrna Oliver (August 24, 1999), [http://articles.latimes.com/1999/aug/24/news/mn-3077 Leo Castelli; Influential Dealer Promoted Careers of Artists From Johns to Warhol] ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''.</ref> from a family of coffee importers<ref name="Clarke">Gerald Clarke (February 26, 1979), [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20073021,00.html Dealer Leo Castelli Sold the World on Pop Art, and Now He's Cleaning Up] ''[[People (magazine)|People]]''.</ref> which had long been based there.<ref name="Russell">John Russell (August 23, 1999), [https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/23/arts/leo-castelli-influential-art-dealer-dies-at-91.html Leo Castelli, Influential Art Dealer, Dies at 91] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref> After World War I, which the family spent in Vienna (where Leo Castelli learned perfect German), they returned to Trieste.<ref name="Russell"/> The family changed its name to "Krausz-Castelli" and then "Castelli" in the mid-1930s, when Mussolini's government required names to be Italianized.<ref name="Garner"/>
After earning a law degree at the [[University of Milan]] in 1924, Castelli returned to Trieste, where his father had secured a job for him with an insurance company.<ref name="Russell"/> In 1932, he went to work for an insurance company in Bucharest, where he married [[Ileana Sonnabend|Ileana Schapira]] one year later. After their marriage, the couple honeymooned in Vienna and bought their first artwork, a [[Henri Matisse|Matisse]] watercolor.<ref name="Oliver"/>
Castelli's father-in-law, Mihai Schapira, helped him to be transferred in 1935 to the [[Banca d'Italia]] in Paris. There, Ileana's taste and money helped him start his first gallery at [[Place Vendôme]] in Paris, which was named for its co-director, the decorator René Drouin,<ref name="Schjeldahl"/> and situated between the [[Hôtel Ritz Paris|Ritz Hotel]] and the couturier [[Elsa Schiaparelli]].<ref>Leo Castelli's FIRST STEPS in the art world: a "Surrealist" event in Paris in '39 – by Michèle C. Cone. [[Artnet]], July 21, 2010. http://www.artnet.com/magazineus/features/cone/leo-castelli-surrealist-design7-21-10.asp</ref> Specializing in surrealistic art,<ref name="Oliver"/> the gallery opened in July 1939, with a show of modern and antique furniture, including commissioned pieces by Drouin, [[Max Ernst]], [[Meret Oppenheim]], [[Leonor Fini]] (a former girlfriend of Castelli's from Trieste), [[Eugene Berman]], and other artists in the force field of Surrealism.<ref name="Schjeldahl"/>
Ileana's connections enabled the couple to flee to America at the start of World War II. Castelli's parents did not escape but died in Budapest, hounded by members of Hungary's fascist [[Arrow Cross Party]].<ref>Deborah Solomon (June 11, 2010), [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/13/books/review/Solomon-t.html Leo Castelli’s New York Story] ''New York Times''.</ref> The couple would remain married for more than 25 years, and were friends and partners even after their divorce, when Ileana married Michael Sonnabend and that couple opened its own gallery.<ref name="Garner"/> Castelli arrived in the United States in 1941, by way of Marrakesh, Tangier, Algeciras, Vigo and Havana.<ref name="Russell"/> He took graduate history courses in economic history<ref name="Schjeldahl"/> at [[Columbia University]]<ref name="Oliver"/> until volunteering for the Army, serving in the intelligence service in Europe. After the liberation of France, he was sent to Bucharest as an interpreter for the Allied commission that controlled the city. As a result of Castelli's military service, he was given American citizenship.<ref name="Russell"/> Returning to New York, Castelli took a managerial position with his father-in-law's clothing factory.<ref name="Schjeldahl"/>
==Leo Castelli Gallery== In New York, the Castellis were two of only three non-artist members (the other was dealer [[Charles Egan Gallery|Charles Egan]])<ref name="Schjeldahl"/> of the Club, an influential coterie founded in 1949 that included [[Willem de Kooning]], [[Robert Rauschenberg]], [[Franz Kline]], and [[Ad Reinhardt]]. Castelli's first exercise as a private dealer came through Drouin, in 1947: some hundred canvases by [[Wassily Kandinsky|Kandinsky]], consigned by his widow, Nina.<ref name="Schjeldahl"/> His first American curatorial effort was the [[Ninth Street Show]] of 1951, a seminal event in the emergence of Abstract Expressionism. He soon attached himself to the pioneering gallerist [[Sidney Janis]], one of the early proponents of the school.<ref>Mark Lamster (May 23, 2010), [http://articles.latimes.com/2010/may/23/entertainment/la-ca-leo-castelli-20100523 Book Review: A dealer and his galaxy of art stars in 'Leo and His Circle"] ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''.</ref> In 1957, he opened the Leo Castelli Gallery in a townhouse at 4 E. 77th Street between Madison and Fifth Avenues in New York City. From the mid-1960s through the 1970s, the gallery was perhaps the most prominent commercial venue for art in the world.<ref name="Grant">Daniel Grant (February 24, 2011), [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703960804576120434103905642 Leo Castelli's Cache Of Art-History Gold] ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''.</ref> Initially the gallery showcased European [[Surrealism]], [[Wassily Kandinsky]], and other European artists. However the gallery also exhibited American [[Abstract Expressionism]]. [[Jackson Pollock]], [[Willem de Kooning]], [[Cy Twombly]], [[Friedel Dzubas]], and [[Norman Bluhm]] were some artists who were included in group shows.
In 1958, [[Robert Rauschenberg]] and [[Jasper Johns]] joined the gallery, signaling a turning away from [[Abstract Expressionism]], towards [[Pop Art]], [[Minimalism]] and [[Conceptual Art]].[[File:Warhol Flowers, offset lithograph.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Castelli Gallery's first [[Andy Warhol|Warhol]] exhibition, ''Flowers'', November, 1964]] From the early 1960s through the late 70s, [[Frank Stella]], [[Larry Poons]], [[Lee Bontecou]], [[James Rosenquist]], [[Roy Lichtenstein]], [[Andy Warhol]], [[Robert Morris (artist)|Robert Morris]], [[Donald Judd]], [[Dan Flavin]], [[Cy Twombly]], [[Ronald Davis]], [[Ed Ruscha]], [[Salvatore Scarpitta]], [[Richard Serra]], [[Bruce Nauman]], [[Lawrence Weiner]] and [[Joseph Kosuth]] joined the stable of Castelli artists. He gave Johns, Stella and Lichtenstein their first one-man shows.<ref name="Russell"/> Castelli opened a temporary annex, the Castelli Warehouse, on West 108th Street, with a show organized by [[Robert Morris (artist)|Robert Morris]], of environmental sculpture by nine artists, including Nauman, Serra, and [[Eva Hesse]].<ref name="Schjeldahl"/> In 1971 Leo Castelli opened a downtown [[SoHo]] branch of the Leo Castelli Gallery at 420 West Broadway, in a building bought by the Hague Art Delivery Company and a cooperative of dealers: Castelli took the second floor; his former wife's [[Sonnabend Gallery]] the took the third floor, and [[André Emmerich]] (later replaced by [[Charles Cowles (art dealer)|Charles Cowles]]) took the top floor; while John Weber, (former director of the [[Virginia Dwan (art dealer)|Dwan Gallery]]) rented his gallery on the fourth floor. In the 1980s, Castelli opened a second larger downtown exhibition space at a 142 Greene Street also in [[SoHo]]. He later mounted joint shows with [[Mary Boone]], of [[Julian Schnabel]], in 1981, and [[David Salle]], in 1982.<ref name="Schjeldahl"/>
Castelli also pioneered a stipend system that was unknown in New York when he opened his gallery. He put his artists on a payroll whether or not their work sold. For this and other reasons, desertions were initially rare among his artists. When Castelli discovered Serra in 1967, for example, he offered him a guarantee of three years of monthly payments even though he did not expect to sell any of the unknown sculptor's lead-plate work in that time.<ref name="Russell"/> Castelli also was known for spotting new talent and insisting on European exposure for his American artists, leading to Rauschenberg in 1964 becoming the first American to win the [[Venice Biennale]]'s international grand prize in painting.<ref name="Oliver"/> His most important clients included [[Museum Ludwig|Peter Ludwig]] and [[Giuseppe Panza]].<ref name="Clarke"/>
Castelli's second wife, Antoinette Fraissex du Bost,<ref name="Schjeldahl"/> opened Castelli Graphics, an art gallery devoted to the prints and photographs of Castelli Gallery and other artists.<ref name="NYT87">[https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/04/obituaries/antoinette-castelli-58-dies-president-of-graphics-gallery.html Antoinette Castelli, 58, Dies; President of Graphics Gallery] ''New York Times'', September 4, 1987.</ref> The couple also had a son together, Jean-Christophe Castelli, but Antoinette Castelli died in 1987.<ref name="NYT87"/> In 1995 Leo Castelli married the Italian art historian Barbara Bertozzi Castelli.
In 2015, Bertozzi Castelli opened a one-room satellite gallery at 1046 Madison Avenue, near 80th Street, with [[Robert Morris (artist)|Robert Morris]]'s installation ''Lead and Felt'' (1969).<ref>Hilarie M. Sheets (September 24, 2015), [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/25/arts/design/richard-prince-takes-a-new-approach-to-cowboys.html Changing Galleries] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref>
==Recognition== Castelli received the rosette of the [[French Legion of Honor]], allegedly in exchange for donating works by Johns to the [[Centre Pompidou]].<ref name="Schjeldahl"/> The mayor of Trieste made him the honorary director of the [[Revoltella Museum]]. In 1998, the [[National Arts Club]] awarded Castelli its Centennial Medal of Honor. On this occasion, [[Dennis Hopper]] called Castelli "the godfather of the contemporary art world."<ref>[[Phoebe Hoban]] (March 29, 1998), [https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/29/style/the-night-a-pearl-beyond-price.html A Pearl Beyond Price] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref>
In 1982 a traveling exhibit honoring the 25th anniversary of Castelli Gallery visited the [[San Diego Museum of Contemporary Art|La Jolla Museum of Contemporary Art]]. The [[Museum of Art Fort Lauderdale|Museum of Art]], Fort Lauderdale, showed "Three Decades of Exploration: Homage to Leo Castelli", an exhibit of more than 30 works by artists discovered, shown and encouraged by Castelli in 1987.<ref>Rober Hurlburt (November 1, 1987), [http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1987-11-01/features/8702030168_1_leo-castelli-american-art-contemporary-art Exhibition A Tribute To Noted Art Dealer] ''[[South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]''.</ref> That same year, the [[Butler Institute of American Art]] presented "Leo Castelli: a tribute exhibition". In 1996, [[Gagosian Gallery]] mounted the exhibition "Leo Castelli: An Exhibition in Honor of His Gallery and Artists" in Beverly Hills.<ref name="Oliver"/>
==Legacy== Many artists have enshrined Castelli in their works. [[Elaine de Kooning]] and [[Richard Artschwager]] painted his portrait, Warhol made a silkscreen of him in a jacket and tie. Frank Stella named a work after him, in 1992 he posed for the French artist [[Klaus Guingand]] who immortalized his shadow, and a sculpture by [[Robert Morris (artist)|Robert Morris]], ''Leo'', places a brain at the center of a target.<ref>Carol Strickland (May 12, 1991), [https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/nyregion/leo-castelli-meets-film-maker-and-fan.html Leo Castelli Meets Film Maker and Fan] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref> In 1999, on the occasion of Castelli's death, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' published a eulogy by [[James Rosenquist]].
In 1988, when there were no tax deductions for gifts to museums, Castelli gave one of the icons of postwar American art, Robert Rauschenberg's ''Bed'' (1955) to the [[Museum of Modern Art]]. In 1992, amid rumors that Castelli was negotiating to sell his archives to the [[Getty Center]] in Los Angeles, his collection was said to be worth some $2 million.<ref name="CAG">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/19/arts/design/19voge.html|last=Vogel|first=Carol|title=Castelli Archives Going to Smithsonian|publisher=New York Times|date=19 October 2007}}</ref> In October 2007, Castelli's heirs – his widow, Barbara Bertozzi Castelli, and his two children, Jean-Christopher Castelli and Nina Castelli Sundell – announced the donation of the gallery's archives from 1957 through 1999 to the [[Smithsonian Institution]]'s [[Archives of American Art]]. Castelli had been interviewed for the archive's oral-history project in 1969, 1973 and 1997.<ref name="Grant"/>
The Leo Castelli Gallery continues to operate at 18 East 77th Street in New York under the direction of his wife showing many of the same artists from the gallery's past.<ref name="CAG" /> The Leo Award, presented annually by the [[Independent Curators International (ICI)|Independent Curators International]] (ICI), is named after the late Castelli.<ref>[http://artinfo.com/news/story/818024/is-dasha-zhukova-the-next-leo-castelli-possible-da-vinci-found-on-scottish-farm-and-more-must-read-art-news Is Dasha Zhukova the Next Leo Castelli?] ''ARTINFO'', August 7, 2012.</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book |authorlink=Annie Cohen-Solal |last=Cohen-Solal |first=Annie |title=Leo and His Circle: The Life of Leo Castelli |year=2010 |location=New York |publisher=Alfred A. Knopf |isbn=9781400044276 }}
==External links== * [http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/leo-castelli-gallery-records-7351 Leo Castelli Gallery records, circa 1880-2000], Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution *Oral History Interviews with the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution: **[http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/interviews/oral-history-interview-leo-castelli-12370 Oral history interview with Leo Castelli, 1969 May 14-1973 June 8] - includes audio excerpt **[http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/interviews/oral-history-interview-leo-castelli-11784 Oral history interview with Leo Castelli, 1969 July] **[http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/interviews/oral-history-interview-leo-castelli-11817 Oral history interview with Leo Castelli, 1997 May 22] * Portrait by [[Robert Mapplethorpe]] from ArtNews "Portrait of the Art World" exhibition [https://web.archive.org/web/20070205100441/http://www.npg.si.edu/cexh/artnews/castelli.htm]

page.title: Leonardo da Vinci World Award of Arts
List of painted churches in Cyprus

revision.text:
{{GeoGroupTemplate}} There are over sixty '''[[Eastern Orthodox church architecture|churches]]''' in '''[[Cyprus]]''' with [[Byzantine art|Byzantine]] and post-Byzantine '''[[Mural|wall paintings]]'''.{{cite book |title=The Painted Churches of Cyprus: Treasures of Byzantine Art |author1=Stylianou, Andreas |author2=Stylianou, Judith A. |publisher=[[Anastasios George Leventis|A. G. Leventis Foundation]] |edition=2 |year=1997 |isbn=9963-560-30-X}}{{cite book |title=Medieval Cyprus: A Guide to the Byzantine and Latin Monuments |author=der Parthog, Gwynneth |publisher=[[Moufflon Publications]] |edition=2 |year=2006 |isbn=9963-642-23-3}} Of these, ten that are situated in the [[Troodos Mountains]] have been inscribed jointly on the [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage List]] as the [[Painted Churches in the Troödos Region|Painted Churches in the Troodos Region]].{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/351 |title=Painted Churches in the Troodos Region |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=30 July 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/advisory_body_evaluation/351bis.pdf |title=Painted Churches in the Troodos Region: Evaluation |publisher=[[ICOMOS]] |accessdate=2 August 2012}} ==History== {{Main|History of Cyprus|Church of Cyprus}} The origins of [[Christianity]] on the island may be traced to the visit of [[Paul the Apostle|St. Paul]], [[Barnabas|St. Barnabas]] and [[Mark the Evangelist|St. Mark]] around AD 46. After the [[Fall of the Western Roman Empire|fall]] of the western Roman Empire, Cyprus came under the sway of [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantium]], although the timely discovery of Barnabas' [[relics]] helped the [[Church of Cyprus]] uphold its [[autocephaly]]. The crusader [[Kingdom of Cyprus]] outlived the [[Fall of Constantinople]] by a generation; the subsequent [[Catherine Cornaro|sale]] of the island to [[Republic of Venice|Venice]] led to a brief period of Italo-Byzantine painting. In 1571 Cyprus [[Ottoman Cyprus|fell to the Ottomans]] and the practice of ecclesiastic wall painting largely came to an end. ==Organization of space== Subject to the [[Eastern Orthodox church architecture|layout]] of each church, the [[Iconography#Christian iconography|iconographic]] schema typically accords with the classic Byzantine [[Wiktionary:tripartition|tripartition]], evident also in [[Byzantine mosaic|Byzantine mosaic decoration]], the three zones comprising: (1) the [[dome]] and [[Semi-dome|conch]] of the [[apse]]; (2) the [[pendentive]]s, [[squinches]] and upper [[Vault (architecture)|vaults]]; and (3) the lower, secondary vaults and walls. The first is reserved for depictions of the holiest persons, the [[Christ Pantocrator|Christ Pantokrator]] and the [[Madonna (art)|Virgin]]; the second for scenes from the [[Life of Christ in art|Life of Christ]] and the [[Great Feasts of the Orthodox Church|festival cycle]]; and the third for the choir of [[Intercession of saints|intercessory]] [[Saint#Eastern Orthodoxy|saints]].{{cite book |title=Byzantine Mosaic Decoration: Aspects of Monumental Art in Byzantium |author=[[Otto Demus|Demus, Otto]] |publisher=[[Kegan Paul]] |year=1947 |pages=14–30}} ==Preservation== Since the [[Turkish invasion of Cyprus]] in 1974, a number of churches in the [[Northern Cyprus|north]] have been [[Looted art|looted]] and their wall paintings [[Detachment of wall paintings|detached]] to supply the international [[antiquities trade]].{{cite book |title=War and cultural heritage: Cyprus after the 1974 Turkish invasion |author=Jansen, Michael E. |publisher=[[University of Minnesota Press]] |year=2005}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mcw.gov.cy/mcw/DA/DA.nsf/All/5C63072411078AB9C22572750055D67D |title=Looting of Cultural Heritage |publisher=Department of Antiquities |accessdate=2 August 2012}} Among them is the [[Church of Saint Evphemianos, Lysi|Church of St. Evphemianos]] in [[Lysi]]: the thirteenth-century [[Christ Pantocrator|Pantrokrator]] and surrounding angels were detached, leaving their feet behind; the paintings were then acquired for the [[Menil Collection]] and displayed at the [[Byzantine Fresco Chapel]] in [[Houston, Texas]] before their [[Art repatriation|repatriation]] to the south in 2012.{{cite book |title=A Byzantine Masterpiece Recovered: The Thirteenth-Century Murals of Lysi, Cyprus |author=Weyl Carr, Annemarie |publisher=[[Menil Collection]] |year=1991 |isbn=978-0-292-78118-4}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mcw.gov.cy/mcw/da/da.nsf/DMLnews_en/DMLnews_en?OpenDocument |title=The Repatriation of the Wall Paintings of the Church of Agios Euphemianos, Lysi |publisher=Department of Antiquities |accessdate=6 July 2012}} Meanwhile, many churches in the south been the subject of [[Conservation-restoration|conservation]] interventions, conducted by the Department of Antiquities, [[Dumbarton Oaks#Institutional Program|Dumbarton Oaks]] and the [[Courtauld Institute of Art]], aimed at reconciling the competing demands of stability, legibility and authenticity within the framework of ongoing devotional practice.{{cite web |url=http://www.iiconservation.org/es/node/1484 |title=The Byzantine and Post-Byzantine Wall Paintings of Cyprus: Conservation Practice in a Context of Continuing Religious Use, in: Conservation and the Eastern Mediterranean: Contributions to the 2010 IIC Congress |author1=Solomidou-Ieronymidou, Marina |author2=Rickerby, Stephen |publisher=[[International Institute for Conservation]] |year=2010 |pages=231–6}} ==Churches== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%;" |- !width="30%" align="left" | Church !width="10%" align="left" | Municipality !width="10%" align="left" class="unsortable"| Exterior !width="25%" align="left" class="unsortable"| Comments !width="10%" align="left" class="unsortable"| Interior !width="10%" align="left" class="unsortable"| Coordinates !width="10%" align="left" class="unsortable"| Ref. |- | align="center"|[[Panagia Kanakaria]]
Παναγία Κανακαριά
Our Lady Kanakaria || [[Lythrangomi]] || [[File:Panagia Kanakaria 3.jpg|150px]] || [[Looted art#Peg Goldberg and the Kankarian Mosaics|sixth-century wall mosaics]] were [[Looted art|looted]] in the 1970s; some have been recovered from [[art dealers]] || [[File:Panagia Kanakaria Decke.JPG|150px]] || {{coord|35.47846|N|34.166021|E|display=inline|format=dms|type:landmark_region:JP_scale:10000|name=Panagia Kanakaria, Lythrangomi}} || |- | align="center"|[[Panagia Aggeloktisti]]

St. Sozomenos || [[Galata (Cyprus)|Galata]] || || || || {{coord|34.997|N|32.898|E|display=inline|format=dms|type:landmark_region:JP_scale:10000|name=Galata (Agios Sozomenos)}} || [http://www.mcw.gov.cy/mcw/DA/DA.nsf/All/0AD4582311E8ECF4C22571990032797C?OpenDocument ] |- | align="center"|[[Panagia Theotokos (Galata)|Panagia Theotokos]]

Most Holy Mother of God or Archangel Michael || [[Galata (Cyprus)|Galata]] || [[File:Kirche des Erzengels Michael.JPG|150px]] || || [[File:Galata Theotokos Geburt.jpg|150px]] || {{coord|34.997|N|32.898|E|display=inline|format=dms|type:landmark_region:JP_scale:10000|name=Galata (Panagia Theotokos)}} || [http://www.galata.org.cy/english/churches_michael.shtm ] |- | align="center"|[[Panagia Podithou]]
Παναγία Ποδίθου

St. John Chrysostom || [[Koutsovendis]] || || the wall paintings in the chapel of the Holy Trinity, dating to c. 1100, were documented and [[Conservation-restoration|conserved]] by a team from [[Dumbarton Oaks#Institutional Program|Dumbarton Oaks]] under [[Cyril Mango]] in the 1960s; they have been [[whitewash]]ed and covered in large sheets of paper since 1974{{cite web |url=http://www.doaks.org/research/byzantine/byzantine-fellowship-reports/the-monastery-of-st.-chrysostomos-at-koutsovendis-cyprus-the-wall-paintings |title=The Monastery of St. Chrysostomos at Koutsovendis, Cyprus: The Wall-Paintings |author=Parani, Maria G |publisher=[[Dumbarton Oaks#Institutional Program|Dumbarton Oaks]] |accessdate=2 August 2012}} || || {{coord|35.274108|N|33.418436|E|display=inline|format=dms|type:landmark_region:JP_scale:10000|name=Agios Ioannis Chrysostomos, Koutsovendis}} || [http://www.doaks.org/research/byzantine/byzantine-fellowship-reports/the-monastery-of-st.-chrysostomos-at-koutsovendis-cyprus-the-wall-paintings ] |- | align="center"|[[Panagia Aphendrika]]

<!-- please do not add entries to this list unless you have a reliable source for them --> This is a list of notable '''[[game designer|video game designers]]''', past and present, in alphabetical order. The people in this list already have Wikipedia entries, and as such did significant design for notable computer [[computer game]]s, [[console game]]s, or [[arcade game]]s. It does not include people in managerial roles (which often includes titles like "Producer" or "Development Director") or people who developed a concept without doing actual design work on the game itself (sometimes applicable to "co-creator" or "creator" roles). Just because a game is listed next to a designer's name does not imply that person was the sole designer. As with films, the credits for video games can be complicated.
