'''Lucrecia Martel''' (born December 14, 1966) is an [[Argentina|Argentine]] film director, screenwriter and producer whose feature films have frequented [[Cannes Film Festival|Cannes]], [[Venice Film Festival|Venice]], [[Berlin International Film Festival|Berlin]], [[Toronto International Film Festival|Toronto]], and many other international film festivals.<ref>{{imdb name|0551506}}</ref> Film scholar Paul Julian Smith wrote in 2015 that she is “arguably the most critically acclaimed [[auteur]] in Spanish-language [[art cinema]] outside Latin America” and that her “[[transnational cinema|transnational]] auteurism and demanding features have earned her a hard-won reputation in the [[world cinema|world art cinema]] [[film festival#Notable festivals|festival circuit]].”<ref name="PJS">{{cite book |author1=Smith, Paul Julian |editor1-last=Parvati |editor1-first=Nair |editor2-last=Gutiérrez-Albilla |editor2-first=Julián Daniel |title=Hispanic and Lusophone Women Filmmakers: Theory, Practice and Difference |publisher=[[Manchester University Press]] |location=U.K. |pages=12–24 |isbn=9780719083570 |format=Print |chapter=Transnational Co-productions and Female Filmmakers: The Cases of Lucrecia Martel and Isabel Coixet|date=2013-01-22 }}</ref>. Similarly, film scholar Haden Guest has called her “one of the most prodigiously talented filmmakers in contemporary world cinema,”<ref name="HG">{{cite web |last1=Guest |first1=Haden |title=Lucrecia Martel by Haden Guest |url=https://bombmagazine.org/articles/lucrecia-martel/ |website=[[BOMB (magazine)|BOMB Magazine]] |accessdate=29 June 2018 |format=Web |date=1 January 2009}}</ref> and film scholar [[:es:David Oubiña|David Oubiña]] has called her body of work a “rare perfection.”<ref name="DO">{{cite web|last1=Oubiña|first1=David|authorlink1=:es:David Oubiña|title=''La Ciénaga'': What's Outside the Frame|url=https://www.criterion.com/current/posts/3444-la-cienaga-what-s-outside-the-frame|website=[[The Criterion Collection]]|accessdate=30 October 2017|date=26 January 2015}}</ref> In April 2018, ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' called her "one of the greatest directors in the world right now".<ref name="JP">{{cite web |last1=Powers |first1=John |title=Lucrecia Martel, One of the Greatest Directors in the World Right Now, Gets a Well Earned Retrospective at Lincoln Center |url=https://www.vogue.com/article/lucrecia-martel-retrospective-film-society-lincoln-center |website=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]] |accessdate=29 August 2018 |language=en |format=Web |date=9 April 2018}}</ref>
Her 2001 debut feature film ''[[La Ciénaga (film)|La Ciénaga]]'' ("The Swamp"), about an indulgent [[Bourgeoisie|bourgeois]] extended family spending the summertime in a decrepit vacation home in provincial [[Salta|Salta, Argentina]], was internationally highly acclaimed upon release and introduced a new and vital voice to Argentine cinema.<ref>{{cite web|title=La Ciénaga|url=https://www.criterion.com/films/28113-la-cienaga|website=[[The Criterion Collection]]|accessdate=30 October 2017|quote=The release of Lucrecia Martel’s ''La Ciénaga'' heralded the arrival of an astonishingly vital and original voice in Argentine cinema.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Poblete |first1=Joel |title=El cine argentino está muy vital |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070827031505/http://www.mabuse.cl/1448/article-74875.html |website=Mabuse Film Magazine |archiveurl=http://www.mabuse.cl/1448/article-74875.html |archivedate=27 August 2007 |location=Chile |format=Web |date=11 July 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Ebert|first1=Roger|authorlink1=Roger Ebert|title=La Cienaga Movie Review & Film Summary (2001)|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/la-cienaga-2001|website=[[RogerEbert.com]]|publisher=Ebert Digital LLC|accessdate=30 October 2017|date=19 October 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=McGavin|first1=Patrick Z.|title=Family tensions fill risky 'La Cienaga'|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2001-10-19/entertainment/0110190347_1_la-cienaga-family-argentinean|website=Tribune Digital|publisher=[[Tronc]]|accessdate=30 October 2017|date=19 October 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=La Cienaga (2001)|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/la_cienaga/|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]]|accessdate=30 October 2017}}</ref> David Oubiña called it "one of the highest achievements" of the [[Cinema of Argentina#Contemporary cinema|New Argentine Cinema]], a wave of contemporary filmmaking that began in the mid-1990s in reaction to decades of [[December 2001 riots in Argentina|political]] and [[1998–2002 Argentine great depression|economic crises]] in the country. The film, Oubiña wrote, is "a rare expression of an extremely troubled moment in the nation’s recent history. It is a masterpiece of singular maturity".<ref name="DO" />
Martel's succeeding three feature films received further international acclaim: the adolescent drama ''[[The Holy Girl]]'' (2004),<ref>{{cite web|last1=Scott|first1=A. O.|authorlink=A. O. Scott|title=Blessed Restraint|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/10/magazine/blessed-restraint.html|website=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|accessdate=30 October 2017|date=10 April 2005}}</ref> the psychological thriller ''[[The Headless Woman (2008 film)|The Headless Woman]]'' (2008),<ref>{{cite web|last1=Murat|first1=Pierre|title=La Femme sans tête|url=http://www.telerama.fr/cinema/films/la-femme-sans-tete,377935,critique.php|website=[[Télérama]]|publisher=Publications de la Vie Catholique|accessdate=30 October 2017|language=French|date=2 May 2009}}</ref> and the [[Historical period drama|period drama]] [[film adaptation|adaptation]] ''[[Zama (2017 film)|Zama]]'' (2017).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Brooks|first1=Xan|title=Zama review – Lucrecia Martel emerges from the wilderness with a strange, sensual wonder|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/aug/31/zama-review-lucrecia-martel-emerges-from-the-wilderness-with-a-strange-sensual-wonder|website=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|accessdate=30 October 2017|date=31 August 2017}}</ref>
==Early life== The second of seven children, Martel was born and raised in [[Salta|Salta, Argentina]]. Her father Ferdi owned and operated a paint shop, while her mother Bochi dedicated herself to the family. Her parents met in university (where Ferdi studied science and Bochi studied philosophy) and got married at 24 years old. Eventually they left their careers and settled in Salta.
In [[education in Argentina#Primary education|primary school]], Martel’s [[minister (Christianity)|minister]] uncle helped her develop interests in [[mythology]], [[Greek language|Greek]], and [[Latin]]. In fifth grade, she set her sights on gaining admission to the elite, "ultra-Catholic" [[education in Argentina#Secondary education|secondary school]] Bachillerato Humanista Moderno, because it was the only school in Salta that offered classes in dead languages. Her parents opposed the school because of its elitist tradition which they felt reinforced class differences, but, because of the [[:es:Categoría:Alumnado del Bachillerato Humanista Moderno de Salta|school's prominent alumni]] and Martel’s intellectual curiosity, they did not stop her from her pursuit. Eventually, Martel passed the demanding entrance exam and enrolled in the school in the sixth grade. Since she came from a “solidly middle class” family, as she stated in a revealing 2008 interview with ''[[Bomb (magazine)|BOMB Magazine]]'', Martel felt like an outsider at the school. Her peers, she said, attended the school because their families expected them to, while she only attended it so she could study Greek and Latin. In a 2018 interview with ''[[Gatopardo (magazine)|Gatopardo]]'' magazine, her mother said that at the school Martel was a “radical and challenging” honor roll student who excelled in science.
In her home, Martel says "there was a very deep devotion to [[storytelling]]." Her father, mother, and maternal grandmother Nicolasa were "very good storytellers" and would tell her and her six siblings "lots of stories" to keep them quiet in bed while the adults took their afternoon [[siesta]]. She was especially fascinated by the way her grandmother used different sounds, tones, and carefully selected pauses to establish "atmosphere" in her scary, fantastical stories. "As a child," Martel says, "and even today, I have always been captivated by the form not only of stories and storytelling, but also of conversation and the way people pause and leave space for someone to intervene. All the ways that, especially when you’re a child, you’re charmed and steered just by words alone." She says that her fascination with this "world of conversation" in oral storytelling is what fueled her passion for cinematic storytelling and the emphasis on [[Cinematic techniques#Sound|sound]] in her films.
Martel first used a video camera when she was "15 or 16" years old, she says, after her father bought one to store memories of their large family. "A very big investment for us," she says of the camera, nobody in the family used it but her. "I began recording conversations and everyday things: family stuff," she says. "My family got used to it because I was always filming…. There are two or three years in our family life where I don’t appear at all in videos or photos, because I was always behind the camera. It was the discovery of something that fascinated me, but it didn’t seem to me then that my future could be related to that."<ref name="LM">{{cite book|author1=Monteagudo, Luciano|editor1-last=Bernades|editor1-first=Horacio|editor2-last=Lerer|editor2-first=Diego|editor3-last=Wolf|editor3-first=Sergio|title=New Argentine Cinema: Themes, Auteurs and Trends of Innovation|date=2002|publisher=Ediciones Tatanka|location=Buenos Aires|isbn=9789879972830|pages=69–78|format=Print|chapter=Lucrecia Martel: Whispers at ''Siesta'' Time}}</ref>
When she was 17 years old, she accompanied her father to [[Buenos Aires]] and attended a cinema projection of ''[[Camila (film)|Camila]]'' (1984), a film written and directed by [[María Luisa Bemberg]] and produced by [[Lita Stantic]] about a real and tragic love story between a priest and a young lady of Buenos Aires high society. Impressed with the film’s women creators and mainstream success, Martel says that as a result of the viewing she “thought the cinema was a woman's job,” a “confusion,” as she describes it, that "stayed with [her]” for years.<ref name="HG" /><ref name="MY">{{cite web |last1=Yemayel |first1=Mónica |title=Lucrecia Martel: El ojo extraterrestre |url=https://gatopardo.com/reportajes/entrevista-lucrecia-martel/ |website=[[Gatopardo (magazine)|Gatopardo]] |accessdate=29 June 2018 |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |format=Web |date=3 June 2018}}</ref>
==Education==
Upon graduating from [[education in Argentina#Secondary education|secondary school]], Martel intended to study physics at the [[Balseiro Institute]], but she "started to have doubts" and instead enrolled in an art history course at the [[National University of Salta]], as well as in chemical engineering and zoology courses in [[Tucumán Province|Tucumán]], a nearby province. "Suffer[ing] uncertainty” and trying to decide “what to study or do with [her] life,”<ref name="LM" /> she [[pig farming|farmed pigs]] that year, too—breeding, raising, and selling them—and even considered making it her future livelihood.<ref name="NMF" /> However, poor sales of just two pigs per month proved it would not be a feasible career option for her.
At the end of that school year, Martel traveled to Buenos Aires to study [[advertising]] at the [[Pontifical Catholic University of Argentina|Catholic University]]. The program combined creativity and technique, so she and her family thought it could work for her. Although Martel says she lost her [[Catholicism|Catholic faith]] at 15 years old, at the university she volunteered with [[Catholic Action]] and spoke against [[abortion]]. Feeling uncomfortable, she decided to distance herself from the faith and leave the school to pursue the new [[communication sciences]] degree program at the [[University of Buenos Aires]]. She describes the program as “a typical post-transition-to-democracy program made to train journalists and media analysts. Of course, it was an area of Argentine culture that had been hit especially hard by the years of dictatorship. There were very interesting professors who were returning from exile at the time, people with more left-leaning ways of thinking. It was a good moment for the program because no one quite knew exactly what this career entailed.” She completed all of the degree requirements, she says, but “didn’t do any of the paperwork toward receiving the [actual] degree." However, she believes that her time at the school "helped [her] out a lot."
Not wanting to neglect her interests in the technical and the creative, while at the University of Buenos Aires she enrolled in a nighttime [[animation]] course at the [[:es:Instituto de arte cinematográfico de Avellaneda|Film Art Institute of Avellaneda (IDAC)]] located about 5.5 miles away, which Martel describes was a significant commute at the time. “Something of the scientific spirit in me remained,” she says regarding her decision to enroll in the school, “and I liked how animation was very technical, precise, and controlled.” At the school, she started to meet people who were studying film and began to produce short films.
While at IDAC, she decided to take the admission exam for Argentina’s only state-sponsored film school at the time—the [[:es:Escuela Nacional de Experimentación y Realización Cinematográfica|National School of Film Experimentation and Production (ENERC)]]. Since over 1,000 people signed up for the exam and only 30 vacancies existed at the school, applicants were required to take a “huge qualifying course,” which Martel says she spent months preparing for. After she “finally got in,” the school closed due to lack of funds.<ref name="ND">{{cite web |last1=Dawson |first1=Nick |title=Lucrecia Martel, ''The Headless Woman'' |url=https://filmmakermagazine.com/1382-lucrecia-martel-the-headless-woman/ |website=[[Filmmaker (magazine)|Filmmaker Magazine]] |publisher=Independent Filmmaker Project (IFP) |accessdate=29 June 2018 |format=Web |date=19 August 2009}}</ref> “When school was supposed to start,” she says, “the economic crisis was already so severe that there weren’t any professors or materials. We didn’t have classes. The only real possibility was to study [[autodidacticism|autodidactically]], to watch films and analyze them. I watched ''[[Pink Floyd – The Wall|Pink Floyd: The Wall]]'' 23 times, analyzing the montage. We would watch a film many times to learn how it was edited. I was learning in many different ways—participating in short films that friends were making, helping with production or photography, anything just to keep learning.”<ref name="HG" /><ref name="MY" /> Martel has maintained in interviews that she was self-taught.<ref name="ND" /><ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml;jsessionid=XT5YWS3SL104FQFIQMGCFFOAVCBQUIV0?xml=/arts/2001/10/04/bfsf4.xml ''Telegraph'']. Film review of ''La Ciénaga,'' October 2001.</ref><ref name="AMB">{{cite book|author1=Bahiana, Ana Maria|editor1-last=Kelly|editor1-first=Gabrielle|editor2-last=Robson|editor2-first=Cheryl|title=Celluloid Ceiling: Women Directors Breaking Through|date=2014|publisher=Supernova|location=London|pages=77–91|isbn=9780956632906|format=Print|chapter=Female Filmmakers in Latin America: Unsung Pioneers, Fierce Explorers}}</ref>
==Career==
===Early career===
While attending [[:es:Instituto de arte cinematográfico de Avellaneda|IDAC]], Martel directed the animated short films ''El 56'' ("The 56") in 1988 and ''Piso 24'' ("24th Floor") in 1989.
As a film student at [[:es:Escuela Nacional de Experimentación y Realización Cinematográfica|ENERC]], Martel directed ''No te la llevarás, maldito'' ("You Won’t Get Her, Bastard," 1989), a short film about a jealous boy who fantasizes about killing his mother’s boyfriend.<ref>{{cite web |title=You Won't Get Her, Bastard (1989) |url=https://letterboxd.com/film/you-wont-get-her-bastard/ |website=[[Letterboxd]] |accessdate=29 June 2018 |language=en |format=Web}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=No te la llevarás, maldito (C) (1989) |url=https://www.filmaffinity.com/es/film780001.html |website=[[FilmAffinity]] |accessdate=29 June 2018 |language=es |format=Web}}</ref> Film scholar Deborah Martin wrote that in the film, “there is an exploration of the subversive power of children that would become a crucial feature of [Martel’s] later work, as a little boy's murderous [[Oedipus complex|Oedipal feelings]] towards his mother's lover are fully unleashed in a fantasy he lives out through his drawings.”<ref name="DMCLM">{{cite book |last1=Martin |first1=Deborah |title=The cinema of Lucrecia Martel |date=2016 |publisher=[[Manchester University Press]] |location=U.K. |isbn=9780719090349 |format=Print}}</ref>
Another short film Martel directed as a student is ''La otra'' ("The Other," 1990), a documentary about a man who talks about the joys and sorrows of his life as a [[transvestism|transvestite]] as he dresses up as a woman to sing tangos at a nightclub.<ref name="MY" /><ref>{{cite web |title=La otra (1990) |url=https://letterboxd.com/film/la-otra-1990/ |website=[[Letterboxd]] |accessdate=29 June 2018 |language=en |format=Web}}</ref>
Next, Martel directed ''Besos rojos'' ("Red Kisses," 1991), a short film based on a real-life police case between three lovers caught in a love triangle.<ref name="NMF">{{cite web |title=Nueva mirada femenina para ver el cine argentino |url=https://www.lanacion.com.ar/73675-nueva-mirada-femenina-para-ver-el-cine-argentino |website=[[La Nación]] |accessdate=29 July 2018 |location=Argentina |language=es |format=Web |date=27 July 1997}}</ref>
Martel says that “just when [she] was starting to think that [a career in] film was impossible, that it was time for [her] to get a (real) job,” she entered a public script competition organized by the [[National Institute of Cinema and Audiovisual Arts|Argentine National Film Board (INCAA)]], the grand prize for which was the budget to produce a short film.<ref>{{cite web |title=Historias Breves 2017 |url=http://www.incaa.gov.ar/concursos/cerrados/historias-breves-2017 |website=[[National Institute of Cinema and Audiovisual Arts|Instituto Nacional de Cine y Artes Audiovisuales (INCAA)]] |accessdate=23 August 2018 |language=es |format=Web}}</ref> Martel won the contest and, as a result, was able to produce her breakout film ''[[:es:Rey Muerto (cortometraje)|Rey muerto]]'' ("Dead King," 1995), a violent western about a woman who escapes her abusive, alcoholic husband with her three children in a small town called Rey Muerto in provincial [[Salta|Salta, Argentina]].<ref name="MY" /> It went on to win Best Short Film at the 1995 [[Havana Film Festival]].
''Rey muerto'' was exhibited in Argentina as part of a larger omnibus film called ''[[:es:Historias breves|Historias breves]]'' ("Short Stories," 1995). Martel explains that this compilation film was “unprecedented in the country” and came about after all the directors of the other winning short films in the script contest banded together and visited the INCAA headquarters in Buenos Aires repeatedly to ask the contest organizers to premiere all the short films as a string of films in a theater. Martel says that she and her fellow filmmakers “sat for hours until [the contest organizers] would meet with us. We argued that it was a waste of state funding if they didn’t exhibit the finished films.” As a result, the films were exhibited on the dedicated screens of the national public circuit run by INCAA.<ref name="PJS" /> Martel says that the premiere of ''Historias breves'' was "very successful" and drew 10,000 viewers. "It also inspired people," she says, "to study filmmaking and to start making shorts. It was a really important phenomenon in spiritual terms. Curiously, many of the directors who began their careers at the time—’95 or ’96—are still making films today. That event inaugurated the activity of a lot of directors, and also a lot of young people’s interest in film." Film scholar Haden Guest says it helped inaugurate the [[Cinema of Argentina#Contemporary cinema|New Argentine Cinema]] and “is really where the [movement] began.”<ref name="HG" />
Martel says that “thanks to ''Rey muerto'', [she] started to get jobs in television.”<ref name="HG" /> From 1995 to 1999 she directed the unconventional children's program ''[[:es:Magazine For Fai|Magazine For Fai]]'', in which child actors performed in different sketch comedies.<ref>{{cite web |title=Magazine For Fai (Serie de TV) (1995) |url=https://www.filmaffinity.com/es/film660201.html |website=[[FilmAffinity]] |accessdate=29 June 2018 |language=es |format=Web}}</ref> In a 2013 interview with ''[[ABC Color]]'', Martel says the show “became a cult for children.... It was not commercially known, but there are a lot of young people who saw it. Many of its actors are now stars of Argentine cinema.”<ref>{{cite web |last1=Coronel |first1=Jorge |title=Lucrecia Martel: "La industria del cine se puso un poco torpe" |url=http://www.abc.com.py/especiales/fin-de-semana/lucrecia-martel-la-industria-del-cine-se-puso-un-poco-torpe-649470.html |website=[[ABC Color]] |accessdate=29 June 2018 |location=Paraguay |language=es |format=Web |date=13 December 2013}}</ref> She also made two documentaries for television: ''Encarnación Ezcurra'' (1998), about the [[Encarnación Ezcurra|eponymous wife]] of Argentine politician and army officer [[Juan Manuel de Rosas]], and ''Las dependencias (The Outbuildings)'' (1999), a reconstruction of the life of the celebrated Argentine short fiction writer [[Silvina Ocampo]], which draws on the testimonies of Ocampo's servants and friends.<ref name="IFFR">{{cite web |title=Lucrecia Martel |url=https://iffr.com/en/persons/lucrecia-martel |website=[[International Film Festival Rotterdam]] (IFFR) |accessdate=29 June 2018 |language=en |format=Web |date=4 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="DMCLM" />
===Salta trilogy===
In 1999, Martel's screenplay for her debut feature film ''[[La Ciénaga (film)|La Ciénaga]]'' ("The Swamp," 2011) won the Sundance Institute/NHK Award, which honors and supports emerging independent filmmakers "who contribute to the world's visual culture and promote cultural exchanges".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Berkshire|first1=Geoff|title=NHK, Sundance honor int'l filmmakers|url=http://variety.com/2003/film/markets-festivals/nhk-sundance-honor-int-l-filmmakers-1117878958/|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=6 May 2018|date=17 January 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=What is "Sundance Institute/NHK Award"? |url=http://www.nhk.or.jp/sun-asia/sundance/about/index_e.html |website=[[NHK|NHK (Japan Broadcasting Corporation)]] |accessdate=26 August 2018 |language=en |format=Web}}</ref> The jury recommended that she re-write the script to follow a more traditional structure around one or two protagonists, but Martel chose instead to retain the script's diffuse nature.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Martin|first1=Deborah|title=The cinema of Lucrecia Martel|date=2016|publisher=[[Manchester University Press]]|location=U.K.|pages=32|isbn=9780719090349|format=Print|chapter=''La Ciénaga'': Distanciation and Embodiment}}</ref> To cast the film's child actors, Martel held 2,400 auditions, 1,600 of which she recorded on video in a garage near her home in [[Salta]].<ref name="LM" />
In 2001, Martel was selected for the 3rd edition of the [[Cannes Film Festival]] [[Cinéfondation]] [[artist-in-residence]] program, designed to inspire and support young international filmmakers working on their first or second feature film. As part of the program, Martel lived in Paris for four and a half months, attended forums and worked with film industry professionals in developing her second feature film, ''[[The Holy Girl]]'', which premiered in 2004.<ref name="LMCFF">{{cite web |title=Lucrecia MARTEL |url=https://www.festival-cannes.com/en/artist/lucrecia-martel |website=[[Cannes Film Festival|Festival de Cannes]] |accessdate=26 August 2018 |language=en |format=Web}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=The Residence > Presentation |url=http://www.cinefondation.com/en/generalinformation |website=[[Cinéfondation]] – [[Cannes Film Festival|Festival de Cannes]] |accessdate=26 August 2018 |language=en |format=Web}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=The Residence > The Programme |url=http://www.cinefondation.com/en/residenceprogram |website=[[Cinéfondation]] – [[Cannes Film Festival|Festival de Cannes]] |accessdate=26 August 2018 |language=en |format=Web}}</ref>
Together with ''[[The Headless Woman (2008 film)|The Headless Woman]]'' (2008), Martel's first three feature films make up what [[Gatopardo (magazine)|''Gatopardo'' magazine]] calls "a trilogy dedicated to women and Salta," writing, "The three scripts were written by her, the three films were filmed in Salta, and, in all, always, something unexpected alters family cosmology. The characters see the life that they have armed, but, although a magma of bad omens descends on them, they do not react. In ''[[La Ciénaga (film)|La Ciénaga]]'', it is a domestic accident that the mother of a large family suffers. In ''[[The Holy Girl|The Holy Girl (La niña santa)]]'', it is a doctor who arrives in a town and stays in a hotel where the owner lives with her teenage daughter, a student of a religious school. In ''[[The Headless Woman (2008 film)|The Headless Woman (La mujer sin cabeza)]]'', it is an accident on a deserted route and a family cover-up to hide guilt and tragedy.”
“Martel’s filmic trilogy about life in the province of Salta, Argentina," writes film scholar Paul A. Schroeder Rodríguez, "explores the country’s incomplete transition to democracy from the perspective of strong, intelligent, and [[social privilege|socially privileged]] female protagonists who do not conform to dominant [[patriarchy|patriarchal]] values: first during childhood in ''La Ciénaga'' (''The Swamp'', 2001), then during sexual awakening in ''La niña santa'' (''The Holy Girl'', 2004); and finally in adulthood, in ''La mujer sin cabeza'' (''The Headless Woman'', 2008)”.... Martel’s work is finely tuned to the particular rhythms and values of provincial middle-class Argentina, a world whose economic stagnation and moral bankruptcy she dissects through narratives that play on viewers’ sympathies by constantly shifting between favorable and unfavorable perspectives on her characters.”<ref name="PASR">{{cite book |last1=Schroeder Rodríguez |first1=Paul A. |title=Latin American Cinema: A Comparative History |date=2016 |publisher=U of California |location=Oakland, CA |pages=266–81 |isbn=9780520288638 |format=Print |chapter=The Rise of the Woman Director: Lucrecia Martel's Salta Trilogy (2001-8)}}</ref>
====Critical reception====
[[Filmmaker (magazine)|''Filmmaker'' magazine]] wrote, “[Martel’s] debut feature ''La Ciénaga'' premiered at [[Sundance Film Festival|Sundance]], won the [[Alfred Bauer Prize|Alfred Bauer Award]] at [[Berlin International Film Festival|Berlin]], and received rave reviews wherever it played. Martel’s 2004 follow-up, ''The Holy Girl'', about the sexual and religious passions of two Argentinian teenage girls, premiered at [[2004 Cannes Film Festival|Cannes]] and consolidated Martel’s reputation as one of the finest emerging talents in [[world cinema]].”<ref name="ND" />
Film scholar Paul Julian Smith wrote that although “Martel has had to rely rather on a cocktail of small, mainly European, production companies” to fund her films, “industrial constraints and transnational flow have not compromised [her] artistic individuality.... [Her] severe [[art film|art movie]] aesthetics identify her with other [[transnational cinema|transnational]] [[auteur|auteurs]] favoured on the festival circuit.”<ref name="PJS" />
''La Ciénaga'' (2001) received numerous international awards,<ref>{{cite web |title=La Ciénaga (2001) Awards |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0240419/awards |website=[[IMDb]] |accessdate=27 August 2018 |language=en |format=Web}}</ref> and ''The Holy Girl'' and ''The Headless Woman'' were nominated for the [[Palme d'Or]] at the Cannes Film Festivals of 2004 and 2008, respectively.
In a survey of 35 prominent film critics, scholars and industry professionals based in [[New York City]], all three feature films figured among the top ten Latin American films of the decade, with ''La Ciénaga'' taking top place, beating the better-known (and more accessible) works of the Mexican male triad of [[Alejandro González Iñárritu]], [[Alfonso Cuarón]], and [[Guillermo del Toro]].<ref name="PJS" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cinematropical.com/programming.php?pid=3 |title=The Ten Best Latin American Films of the Decade |accessdate=7 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091206031105/http://www.cinematropical.com/programming.php?pid=3 |archivedate=6 December 2009}}</ref>
In August 2016, ''[[The Headless Woman (2008 film)|The Headless Woman]]'' ranked #89 on [[BBC's 100 Greatest Films of the 21st Century]], polled from 177 film critics around the world.<ref>{{cite web |title=The 21st Century's 100 greatest films |url=http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20160819-the-21st-centurys-100-greatest-films |website=[[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC)]] |accessdate=27 August 2018 |language=en |format=Web |date=23 August 2016}}</ref>
====Academic attention====
Martel's work has also attracted a good deal of academic attention. Many scholars have written extensively regarding the films’ critiques of gender and sexuality, as well as its bold depictions of class, race, nationality, and colonialism.
Film scholar Deborah Shaw argues that the trilogy “presents an anatomy of Argentine, [[bourgeoisie|bourgeois]] female identity” and “explores the micropolitics of gender, sexuality and location, rather than national narratives of [[oppression]] and [[transformative social change|collective liberation]].”<ref name="DSID">{{cite book |last1=Shaw |first1=Deborah |editor1-last=Martin |editor1-first=Deborah |editor2-last=Shaw |editor2-first=Deborah |title=Latin American Women Filmmakers: Production, Politics, Poetics |publisher=[[I.B. Tauris]] |location=London ; New York |pages=123–48 |isbn=9781784537111 |format=Print |chapter=Intimacy and Distance – Domestic Servants in Latin American Women's Cinema: ''La mujer sin cabeza'' and ''El niño pez/The Fish Child''|year=2017 }}</ref>
Paul A. Schroeder Rodríguez described the films as “[[Oedipus complex|Oedipal]] with a vengeance” and argues that “each of the films is set up as a dialectic between a [[desire#Film|desiring]] female subject and the [[cultural hegemony|hegemonic]] [[patriarchy|patriarchal]] reality.”<ref name="PASR" />
Film scholar Deborah Martin wrote [http://www.manchesteruniversitypress.co.uk/9780719090349/ a full-length book] on Martel's oeuvre, published in May 2016, in which she argues that Martel’s films “demonstrate possibilities of rupture and escape through her cinematic recreations of rebellious young girls’ forbidden desires.... Despite the fact that these films depict in detail structures of social and political oppression, desire acts as an uncontrollable and multiple force which can overcome these structures.”<ref name="DMDS">{{cite book |last1=Martin |first1=Deborah |last2=Shaw |first2=Deborah |title=Latin American Women Filmmakers: Production, Politics, Poetics |date=2017 |publisher=[[I.B. Tauris]] |location=London ; New York |pages=11–23 |isbn=9781784537111 |format=Print |chapter=Introduction}}</ref>
===Post-trilogy work===
In May 2008, Martel was reported as slated to direct the film adaptation of ''[[The Eternaut]]'', the very popular Argentine science fiction comic strip created by [[Héctor Germán Oesterheld]] and [[Francisco Solano López (comics)|Francisco Solano López]] in 1957 about a toxic snowfall and alien invasion of Buenos Aires.<ref>{{cite web |title=Lucrecia Martel filmará "El Eternauta" |url=http://www.perfil.com/noticias/contenidos/2008/05/13/noticia_0021.phtml |website=[[Perfil]] |accessdate=29 June 2018 |language=es |date=13 May 2008}}</ref><ref name="MY" /> In October 2008, Martel said of the project to ''[[Bomb (magazine)|BOMB Magazine]]'', “I sent my idea of how to adapt it to the producer, and he was interested. I also know that members of the Oesterheld family liked it.”<ref name="HG" /> According to film scholar Deborah Martin, Martel was adapting it as a "meditation on power and social class in Buenos Aires." In 2009, however, the project was dropped, after significant work had been undertaken on it, due to conceptual differences with the producer.<ref name="DMCLM" /><ref>{{cite web |last1=Makovsky |first1=Pablo |title=Historias de crímenes de clase |url=http://www.lacapital.com.ar/ed_senales/2009/12/edicion_60/contenidos/noticia_5001.html |website=[[La Capital]] |accessdate=29 June 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120223134802/http://www.lacapital.com.ar/ed_senales/2009/12/edicion_60/contenidos/noticia_5001.html |archivedate=23 February 2012 |location=Argentina |format=Web |date=13 December 2009}}</ref>
Martel’s 2010 short film ''Nueva Agirópolis'' ("New Argirópolis") metaphorically represents indigenous people’s resistance to capture and interrogation by the Argentine state<ref name="DMDS" /> as well as the inevitable [[cultural globalization#Hybridization|cultural hybridization]] that ensues between the two nations despite that resistance.<ref name="ERCV">{{cite journal |last1=Russo |first1=Eduardo |last2=Vallina |first2=Carlos |title=[en primera persona] Lucrecia Martel |journal=Tram[p]as de la Comunicación y la Cultura |date=May 2012 |issue=70 |url=http://sedici.unlp.edu.ar/bitstream/handle/10915/35270/Documento_completo.pdf?sequence=1 |accessdate=29 June 2018 |language=Spanish |format=Journal PDF |issn=2314-274X}}</ref> It takes its name from the 1850 book ''[[Argirópolis]]'', written by former Argentine [[President of Argentina|President]] and political activist [[Domingo Faustino Sarmiento]], in which Argirópolis is the name of the capital city of a [[utopia|utopian]] democratic [[confederation|confederacy]] between [[Argentina]], [[Uruguay]], and [[Paraguay]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Pinna |first1=Pablo |title=Argirópolis, la capital soñada por Sarmiento para unir Argentina, Uruguay y Paraguay |url=https://www.vix.com/es/mundo/182625/argiropolis-la-capital-sonada-por-sarmiento-para-unir-argentina-uruguay-y-paraguay |website=[[Batanga Media|VIX]] |accessdate=26 August 2018 |language=es |format=Web}}</ref> The short film was commissioned by the [[Ministry of Culture (Argentina)|Argentine Ministry of Culture]] as part of the [[Argentina Bicentennial|Bicentennial celebrations]]<ref name="DMJLACS">{{cite journal |last1=Martin |first1=Deborah |title=Lucrecia Martel's ''Nueva Argirópolis'': Rivers, Rumours and Resistance |journal=Journal of Latin American Cultural Studies |date=1 September 2016 |volume=25 |issue=3 |pages=449–465 |doi=10.1080/13569325.2016.1167018 |language=English |format=Submitted manuscript|url=http://discovery.ucl.ac.uk/1493022/ }}</ref> and shown in theaters as part of the larger [[anthology film]] ''[[:es:25 Miradas - 200 Minutos|25 miradas, 200 minutos]]'' ("25 Looks, 200 Minutes," 2010), an introspective look at the history of Argentina from the point of view of 25 film directors.<ref>{{cite web |title=Nueva Argirópolis (C) (2010) |url=https://www.filmaffinity.com/es/film546350.html |website=[[FilmAffinity]] |accessdate=29 June 2018 |language=es |format=Web}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=25 miradas, 200 minutos (2010) |url=https://www.filmaffinity.com/es/film500920.html |website=[[FilmAffinity]] |accessdate=29 June 2018 |language=es |format=Web}}</ref>
In July 2011, Martel's short film ''Muta'' ("Mutate") premiered at an invitation-only event in [[Beverly Hills]] attended by stars like [[Emma Roberts]], [[Hailee Steinfeld]], [[Ashley Tisdale]], [[Cat Deeley]], [[Diane Kruger]], [[Jeremy Renner]], and [[Marilyn Manson]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Steinberg |first1=Dan |title='Muta' by Miu Miu |url=http://www.latimes.com/la-et-muta-premiere-miu-miu-pictures-photogallery.html |website=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=29 August 2018 |language=en |format=Web}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Miu Miu Women’s Tales: ''MUTA'' by Lucrecia Martel |url=https://www.harpersbazaar.com/uk/fashion/fashion-news/news/a5456/miu-miu-womens-tales-muta-by-lucrecia-martel/ |website=[[Harper's Bazaar#Harper’s Bazaar UK|Harper’s Bazaar UK]] |accessdate=29 August 2018 |language=en |date=22 July 2011}}</ref> Commissioned by [[Miu Miu]], the Italian [[high fashion]] company owned by [[Prada]], the film is the second installment of the company's ''[[Women's Tales]]'' film series, which consists of short films produced in conjunction with high-profile international female directors. Directed and co-written by Martel, the film depicts a luxury modernist ghost ship haunted by faceless, insect-like female creatures attempting to rid themselves of the only man trying to get onboard.<ref>{{cite web |title=Muta (2011) |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1993373/ |website=[[IMDb]] |accessdate=29 August 2018 |language=en |format=Web}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Cozarinsky |first1=Edgardo |authorlink1=Edgardo Cozarinsky |title=''Muta''. 2011. Directed by Lucrecia Martel. ''La Noche (The Night)''. 2016. Directed by Edgardo Castro |url=https://www.moma.org/calendar/events/4443 |website=[[Museum of Modern Art|The Museum of Modern Art (MoMA)]] |language=en |format=Web}}</ref>
In her short film ''Leguas'' ("Leagues," 2015), Martel explores the subject of academic exclusion in Argentina’s indigenous communities.<ref name="MY" /> Named after an [[league (unit)|archaic unit of measurement]], the film depicts how education, though a social tool, can also create division and discrimination.<ref>{{cite web |title=Leagues (2015) |url=https://letterboxd.com/film/leagues/ |website=[[Letterboxd]] |accessdate=29 June 2018 |language=en |format=Web}}</ref> It was distributed as part of the anthology documentary film ''[[El aula vacía]]'' ("The Empty Classroom," 2015), in which eleven award-winning directors examine the underlying reasons why nearly one out of every two Latin American students never graduates high school.<ref>{{cite web |title=Leguas |url=https://homemcr.org/film/leguas/ |website=[[HOME (Manchester)|HOME]] |accessdate=29 June 2018 |location=Manchester, U.K. |language=en |format=Web}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=El aula vacía (2015) |url=https://www.filmaffinity.com/es/film333591.html |website=[[FilmAffinity]] |accessdate=29 June 2018 |language=es |format=Web}}</ref>
===Recent career===
Martel’s fourth feature film ''[[Zama (2017 film)|Zama]]'' premiered at the [[74th Venice International Film Festival|Venice International Film Festival]] in August 2017. An adaptation of [[Antonio di Benedetto]]’s 1956 [[Zama (novel)|novel of the same name]], it narrates the tragic story of Don Diego de Zama, a Spanish colonial functionary stationed in [[Asunción|Asunción, Paraguay]] who waits, in vain, for his superiors to authorize his return home to his wife and family. It was an international co-production between eight countries: Argentina, Brazil, Spain, Mexico, France, the U.S., the Netherlands, and Portugal, with stars like [[Pedro Almodóvar]], [[Gael García Bernal]], and [[Danny Glover]] among its long list of producers.<ref>{{cite web |last1=de la Fuente |first1=Anna Marie |title=Co-Productions on the Rise in Brazil |url=https://variety.com/2017/film/global/co-productions-brazil-1202434200/ |website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=27 August 2018 |language=English |format=Web |date=18 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="JH">{{cite web |last1=Hoberman |first1=J. |title=Lucrecia Martel: A Director Who Confounds and Thrills |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/13/movies/lucrecia-martel-zama-argentina.html |website=[[The New York Times]] |publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|accessdate=27 August 2018 |language=en |format=Web |date=13 April 2018}}</ref> It went on to screen at the [[2017 Toronto International Film Festival|Toronto International Film Festival]] and [[New York Film Festival]] and received widespread acclaim from critics.
Mexican news magazine ''[[Gatopardo (magazine)|Gatopardo]]'' wrote of the film, “Like the other characters of Lucrecia Martel, only now in the late eighteenth century, Diego de Zama is unable to take charge of his own life; his fate is left in the hands of others. The identity that he has imposed on himself and that others have imposed on him is his prison.”<ref name="MY" /> [[:es:Rolling Stone (Argentina)|''Rolling Stone'' of Argentina]] wrote, “[''Zama''] is not an easy bone to crack. Martel delivers her most abstract, most ungraspable, most mysterious creation yet.”<ref>{{cite web |last1=Brodersen |first1=Diego |title='Zama': Lucrecia Martel golpea con un trip colonial y filosófico |url=http://www.rollingstone.com.ar/2067302-zama-lucrecia-martel-golpea-con-un-trip-colonial-y-filosofico |website=[[:es:Rolling Stone (Argentina)|Rolling Stone Argentina]] |accessdate=26 August 2018 |language=Spanish |format=Web |date=28 September 2017}}</ref> British newspaper ''[[The Guardian]]'' wrote of the film, “I hope Martel won’t have to wait a further nine years before she makes her next film. She’s too good a director to be sat on the sidelines for long and ''Zama'' may just be her left-field masterpiece; a picture that’s antic, sensual and strange, with a top-note of menace and a malarial air.”<ref>{{cite web |last1=Brooks |first1=Xan |title=Zama review – Lucrecia Martel emerges from the wilderness with a strange, sensual wonder |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/aug/31/zama-review-lucrecia-martel-emerges-from-the-wilderness-with-a-strange-sensual-wonder |website=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=29 June 2018 |location=London, U.K. |language=en |format=Web |date=31 August 2017}}</ref> The film was chosen to represent Argentina in the [[List of submissions to the 90th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film|Oscar]] and [[32nd Goya Awards|Goya Awards]],<ref>{{cite web |last1=Mango |first1=Agustin |title=Oscars: Argentina Selects 'Zama' for Foreign-Language Category |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/oscars-argentina-selects-zama-foreign-language-category-1044357 |website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |accessdate=26 August 2018 |language=en |format=Web |date=29 September 2017}}</ref> the latter of which it received the nomination for [[Goya Award for Best Spanish Language Foreign Film|Best Spanish Language Foreign Film]].
In May 2018, Martel was [[artist-in-residence|filmmaker-in-residence]] at the [[University of Cambridge]], where she offered a sequence of seminars on her filmmaking practice to students, staff, and the university community.<ref>{{cite web |title=‘The greatest director in the world right now’ begins residency at Centre for Film and Screen |url=https://www.cam.ac.uk/research/news/the-greatest-director-in-the-world-right-now-begins-residency-at-centre-for-film-and-screen |website=[[University of Cambridge]] |accessdate=29 August 2018 |language=en |format=Web |date=4 May 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life==
Martel has cited [[María Luisa Bemberg]],<ref name="DMDS" /> [[Ingmar Bergman]],<ref name="SJ">{{cite web |last1=Johnstone |first1=Sheila |title=Film-makers on film: Lucrecia Martel |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/filmmakersonfilm/3636623/Film-makers-on-film-Lucrecia-Martel.html |website=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |accessdate=5 May 2018 |location=London, U.K. |language=en |format=Web |date=7 February 2005}}</ref> and [[Pedro Almodóvar]]<ref name="MY" /> as influences.
In 2006, she was a member of the [[2006 Cannes Film Festival|Cannes Film Festival]] [[List of Cannes Film Festival juries (Feature films)|Feature Films Jury]], alongside [[Wong Kar-wai]], [[Helena Bonham Carter]], and [[Samuel L. Jackson]].<ref name="LMCFF" />
She has been in a relationship with the lead vocalist of [[:es:Orquesta Típica Fernández Fierro|Fernández Fierro Orchestra]] Julieta Laso since 2016. Martel [[coming out|came out]] to her family just days before the 2001 premiere of ''[[La Ciénaga (film)|La Ciénaga]]'' because she was worried about the implicit [[homosexuality]] depicted in the film. Her mother reacted lovingly to the news and said she knew since Martel was 7 years old.
In February 2016, while editing ''[[Zama (2017 film)|Zama]]'', Martel was diagnosed with [[uterine cancer]]. She stated that her illness caused a delay in the film's [[post-production]] but ultimately catalyzed its completion. In November 2017, [[IndieWire]] reported that she has been in [[cure#Remission|remission]] since late 2016.<ref name="EC">{{cite web |last1=Kohn |first1=Eric |title=How Pedro Almódovar Pushed Argentina's Greatest Filmmaker to Make Her Best Movie Ever |url=https://www.indiewire.com/2017/11/lucrecia-martel-zama-interview-pedro-almodovar-1201899907/ |website=[[IndieWire]] |accessdate=27 August 2018 |language=en |format=Web |date=21 November 2017}}</ref>
As of June 2018, she lives in the [[Buenos Aires]] neighborhood of [[Villa Crespo]].<ref name="MY" />
==Filmography==
===Shorts=== * ''El 56'' ("The 56," 1988) * ''Piso 24'' ("24th floor," 1989) * ''No te la llevarás, maldito'' ("You Won’t Get Her, Bastard," 1989) * ''La otra'' ("The Other," 1990) * ''Besos rojos'' ("Red Kisses," 1991) * ''[[:es:Rey Muerto (cortometraje)|Rey muerto]]'' ("Dead King," 1995), distributed as part of the omnibus film ''[[:es:Historias breves|Historias breves]]'' ("Short Stories," 1995) * ''La ciudad que huye'' ("The City That Flees," 2006) * ''Nueva Argirópolis'' ("New Argirópolis," 2010), distributed as part of the anthology film ''[[:es:25 Miradas - 200 Minutos|25 miradas, 200 minutos]]'' ("25 Looks, 200 Minutes," 2010) * ''Pescados'' ("Fishes," 2010) * ''Muta'' ("Mutate," 2011) * ''Leguas'' ("Leagues," 2015), distributed as part of the anthology documentary film ''[[El aula vacía]]'' ("The Empty Classroom," 2015)
===Features=== * ''[[La Ciénaga (film)|La Ciénaga]]'' (2001) * ''[[The Holy Girl]]'' (2004) * ''[[The Headless Woman (2008 film)|The Headless Woman]]'' (2008) * ''[[Zama (2017 film)|Zama]]'' (2017)
===Television=== * ''[[:es:Magazine For Fai|Magazine For Fai]]'' (1995-1999) * ''Encarnación Ezcurra'' (1998) * ''Las dependencias'' ("The Outbuildings," 1999)

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox musical artist |background = solo_singer |image = |caption = Micachu; photo by Leah Walker |occupation = |birth_name = Mica Levi |birth_date = {{birth year and age|1987|02}} |birth_place = [[Surrey]], England,
United Kingdom |origin = |genre = {{hlist|[[Experimental pop]]| [[avant-garde pop|avant-pop]]||[[lo-fi music|lo-fi]]| [[noise pop]]|[[film score]]}} |instrument = {{hlist|[[Vocals]]|[[guitar]]|[[electronics]]|[[found objects]]}} |years_active = 2006–present |label = {{hlist|[[Rough Trade Records|Rough Trade]]|[[Milan Records|Milan]]|[[Matthew Herbert|Accidental]]|Slip}} | associated_acts = {{hlist|[[Arca (musician)|Arca]]|[[Micachu#Singles / EPs|Brother May]]|[[Dean Blunt]]|[[Dels (musician)|DELS]]|[[Ghostpoet]]|Good Sad Happy Bad|[[Kit Downes]]|[[Kwes]]|[[Matthew Herbert]]|[[London Contemporary Orchestra]]|Oliver Coates|[[Tirzah musician)|Tirzah]]}} |website = {{url|http://micachu.biz}} }} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Good Sad Happy Bad | image = | image_size = | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = | genre = | years_active = 2008–present | label = Rough Trade | associated_acts = | website = | current_members = Mica Levi
Raisa Khan
Marc Pell | past_members = }} '''Mica Levi''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|m|iː|k|ə|_|ˈ|l|iː|v|i}}; born February 1987), also known by her stage name '''Micachu''', is an [[English people|English]] [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]], [[composer]] and [[Hip hop production|producer]].{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/micachu-mn0001480353|title=Micachu {{!}} Biography, Albums, & Streaming Radio {{!}} AllMusic|website=AllMusic|access-date=2016-07-06}} She is classically trained and since 2008 has released [[experimental pop]] music with her band Micachu and the Shapes, including their critically praised debut album ''[[Jewellery (album)|Jewellery]]'' in 2009. In 2014, Levi branched out into film composing, creating the score for the [[Jonathan Glazer]] film ''[[Under the Skin (2013 film)|Under the Skin]]''. Her work was widely praised[http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19239-mica-levi-under-the-skin-ost/ Mica Levi: Under the Skin OST Album Review]. Pitchfork (2014-04-17). Retrieved on 2017-02-25.Weingarten, Christopher R.. (2014-12-29) [https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/20-best-avant-albums-of-2014-20141229/mica-levi-under-the-skin-original-motion-picture-soundtrack-20141222 Mica Levi, 'Under the Skin: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack' | 20 Best Avant Albums of 2014]. ''[[Rolling Stone]]''. Retrieved on 2017-02-25.[https://web.archive.org/web/20140325020422/http://www.thelineofbestfit.com/reviews/albums/mica-levi-under-the-skin-ost-148911] and Levi received a [[European Film Award for Best Composer]] and a [[BAFTA Award for Best Film Music]] nomination. Her score for [[Pablo Larraín]]'s ''[[Jackie (2016 film)|Jackie]]'' received an [[Academy Award]] nomination for Best Original Score.{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/71070-oscars-2017-mica-levis-jackie-nominated-for-best-original-score/|title=Oscars 2017: Mica Levi’s Jackie Nominated for Best Original Score {{!}} Pitchfork|website=pitchfork.com|access-date=2017-01-25}} ==Early life== Levi was born and raised in [[Surrey]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/aug/02/micachu-shapes-review-renaissance-woman-mica-levi|title=Micachu and the Shapes review – renaissance woman goes back to basics|last=Thompson|first=Ben|date=2015-08-02|website=the Guardian|access-date=2016-07-06}}{{cite web|url=http://clashmusic.com/features/micachu-interview|title=Micachu Interview _ Features _ Clash Magazine|last=Diver|first=Mike|date=2009-05-28|website=the Guardian|access-date=2016-07-06}} the daughter of two musicians. She is half Romanian. Levi started writing and playing music at the age of four. ==Music== Levi moved to London in her teens and performed as a DJ and released a [[mixtape]] titled ''Filthy Friends'', which was posted on her official [[Myspace]] page.{{cite web|url=http://diymag.com/2016/03/11/micachu-teams-up-with-brother-may-for-may-and-meeks-ep|title=Micachu teams up with Brother May for 'May And Meeks' EP|website=DIY|access-date=2016-07-06}} For ''Filthy Friends'' she enlisted the help of friends and musicians of various backgrounds including MCs Baker Trouble, Brother May, Man Like Me & [[Ghostpoet]],{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/ghostpoet-interview-id-do-music-for-a-cheese-and-onion-sandwich-10060068.html|title=Rapper Ghostpoet talks about his struggle for success|date=2015-02-21|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-07-06}} singer-songwriter [[Jack Peñate]], jazz band Troyka, London pop-band [[Golden Silvers]] as well as producers [[Kwes]] and [[Toddla T]]. Following its release, ''Filthy Friends'' became sought after on the [[London]] club scene. While a student at Guildhall, Levi was commissioned to write an orchestral piece for the [[London Philharmonic Orchestra]] which was performed at the [[Royal Festival Hall]] in April 2008.Burrows, Tim. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/4839344/Micachu-and-the-Shapes-the-Shape-of-things-to-come.html Micachu and the Shapes: The Shape of Things To Come], "[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]], 4 March 2009" [[File:Micachu at Crash Mansion 2008.jpg|thumb|Performing in [[New York City]], October 2008]] Levi was an Artist-in-Residence at the Southbank Centre in London in 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.southbankcentre.co.uk/about-us/resident-orchestras-and-associate-artists |title=Resident Orchestras & Artists in Residence |publisher=Southbank Centre |date= |accessdate=2016-09-12}} Levi co-wrote and produced Tirzah's ''I'm Not Dancing'' EP, which was released by Greco-Roman Records in August 2013, to critical acclaim.{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/tracks/15810-im-not-dancing/ |title=Tirzah: "I'm Not Dancing" | Tracks |publisher=Pitchfork |date=2013-08-01 |accessdate=2014-07-23}} Levi contributed to the soundtrack for Phil Collins' ''Ceremony'' at Manchester International Festival 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://mif.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/MIF17-Headline-release-1.pdf|title=Manchester International Festival Full Programme Press Release 2017|last=|first=|date=November 2017|website=MIF.co.uk|access-date=}} ===Micachu and the Shapes=== Levi formed a band called Micachu and the Shapes, which included Raisa Khan on keyboards and Marc Pell on drums. They signed to [[Matthew Herbert|Accidental Records]]. With the Shapes, Levi's focus has been on experimental pop music. Most of this music prominently features an acoustic half-guitar with various [[Alternate tunings|non-standard tunings]], extensive distortion, and use of noise and found-object elements, as well as occasionally unusual time signatures. Despite these experimental leanings, the artist categorizes her output with the Shapes as pop music. Their debut album, ''Jewellery'', produced with influential electronic musician [[Matthew Herbert]], was recorded around Mica's composition studies at [[Guildhall School]]. Advance copies of the record reached the press in early 2009, and generated positive feedback. In the wake of this growing buzz, Micachu and the Shapes were signed to [[Rough Trade Records|Rough Trade]],{{cite web|url=http://www.roughtraderecords.com/artist/micachu|title=Rough Trade Records|last=Records|first=Rough Trade|website=Rough Trade Records|access-date=2016-07-07}} who released ''Jewellery'' on 9 March 2009. Drowned In Sound consequently hailed the record as "thrillingly improbable pop made by a grade-A maverick."{{cite web|last=Ubaghs |first=Charles |url=http://drownedinsound.com/releases/14119/reviews/4136399 |title=Album Review: Micachu - Jewellery / Releases / Releases // Drowned In Sound |website=Drownedinsound.com |date=2009-03-17 |accessdate=2017-01-10}} In 2009, the band received a grant from the [[PRS for Music|PRS for Music Foundation]].Hogan, Marc. [http://pitchfork.com/features/articles/7776-whats-the-matter-with-sweden/2/ "What's the Matter with Sweden?" in Pitchfork.com] 29 March 2010 Micachu and the Shapes toured widely throughout the UK in 2008, including performances at [[Bestival]] and [[V Festival]]. The band played in the US at the [[CMJ Music Marathon]] in [[New York City]] and [[SXSW]] in Austin, Texas. They also performed on the Main Stage of the [[Siren Music Festival]] at [[Coney Island]] in [[Brooklyn]] in July 2009. Touring continued throughout Europe and North America in the summer and fall of 2009.{{cite web|url=https://www.myspace.com/micayomusic |title=Micachu | Listen and Stream Free Music, Albums, New Releases, Photos, Videos |website=Myspace.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-10}} In Spring of 2010, Micachu and the Shapes supported [[Spoon (band)|Spoon]] on tour throughout North America. The band performed with the [[London Sinfonietta]] at Kings Place, London in May 2010 and in March 2011 released the live recording as the album "Chopped and Screwed"."[http://www.roughtraderecords.com/micachu/3656/micachu-the-shapes-and-london-sinfonietta-present-chopped-screwed Micachu and the Shapes and London Sinfonietta present: CHOPPED & SCREWED]", ''Rough Trade Records''. Unlike their previous effort, the recording largely avoids pop sensibilities in favor of a slower, hip-hop indebted style and repetitive, discordant string arrangements. The band were chosen by [[Animal Collective]] to perform at the [[All Tomorrow's Parties (music festival)|All Tomorrow's Parties]] festival that they curated in May 2011 in Minehead, England.{{cite web|url=https://www.atpfestival.com/events/atpanimalcollective.php |title=ATP curated by Animal Collective - All Tomorrow's Parties |publisher=Atpfestival.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-23}} The follow-up to their debut, ''[[Never (album)|Never]]'', was released on 23 July 2012. The band released the album ''Good Sad Happy Bad'' on 11 September 2015.{{cite web |url = http://www.metacritic.com/music/good-sad-happy-bad/micachu-the-shapes/critic-reviews |title = ''Good Sad Happy Bad'' critics reviews |date = September 10, 2015 |accessdate = September 12, 2016 |publisher = Mertacritic.com}}[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/13/arts/music/pop-and-jazz-listings-and-albums-for-the-fall-season.html "Pop and Jazz Listings and Albums for the Fall Season"]. ''New York Times'', SEPT. 7, 2015 In March 2016, the band announced on social media that they were changing their name to Good Sad Happy Bad.{{cite AV media |date=March 23, 2016 |title=good sad happy bad |medium=Video |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4a7HXJMHz2g |access-date=April 1, 2017 |quote=we just wanted to tell you that rather than being a recording "good sad happy bad" is the new name of our band.}}{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?story_fbid=10153218749922242&id=10361552241&match=aGFwcHksZ29vZCxzYWQsYmFk |title=Micachu shared a Page |author={{Facebook|Micachu-10361552241|Micachu}} |date=March 23, 2016 |website=[[Facebook]] |access-date=April 1, 2017 |quote=Our band name is now GOOD SAD HAPPY BAD and we did this because we feel our last record was more than just a recording.}} == Film scores == Levi's first major film score was for [[Jonathan Glazer]]'s 2014 film ''[[Under the Skin (2013 film)|Under the Skin]].''{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/mar/15/mica-levi-under-the-skin-soundtrack|title=How Mica Levi got Under The Skin of her first film soundtrack|last=Levi|first=Mica|date=2014-03-15|website=the Guardian|access-date=2016-07-06}} The film is based on the [[Under the Skin (novel)|novel of the same name]] by [[Michel Faber]] and stars Scarlett Johansson. Produced at age 26 and created in collaboration with Glazer, Levi's film score themes are so tightly woven into the film{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19239-mica-levi-under-the-skin-ost/|title=Mica Levi: Under the Skin OST Album Review {{!}} Pitchfork|website=pitchfork.com|access-date=2017-01-25}} that they give a symbiotic quality, in which the aural feels inseparable from the visual.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2016/artisans/production/music-sound-arrival-jackie-1201892755/|title=‘Arrival,’ ‘Jackie’ Composers Push Boundaries of Music and Sound Design|last=Tapley|first=Kristopher|date=2016-10-19|newspaper=Variety|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-25}} The score was widely acclaimed for pushing the boundaries of music and sound design and Levi was nominated for multiple awards. She won Best Composer at the 2014 [[European Film Awards]],{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/micachu/81948|title=Mica Levi on scoring 'Under the Skin': 'I dreamt the world came out of Scarlett Johansson's face' {{!}} NME.COM|last=NME.COM|website=NME.COM|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-07-06}} and tied with [[Jonny Greenwood]] for Best Music/Score at the 2014 Los Angeles Film Critics Awards.{{cite web|url=http://www.lafca.net/years/2014.html |title=LAFCA |publisher=LAFCA |date= |accessdate=2017-01-10}} She was also nominated for the 2015 [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA]] Award for Best Film Music.{{cite web|url=http://www.factmag.com/2015/01/09/mica-levi-bafta-under-the-skin-score/|title=Mica Levi earns BAFTA nomination for Under The Skin score|website=FACT Magazine: Music News, New Music.|access-date=2016-07-06}} In 2016, Levi completed her second major film score, for [[Pablo Larraín]]'s [[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis]] biopic ''[[Jackie (2016 film)|Jackie]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.factmag.com/2016/08/16/mica-levi-micachu-jackie-biopic-score/|title=Mica Levi scores Jackie Kennedy biopic starring Natalie Portman|date=August 16, 2016|accessdate=October 10, 2016}} Larraín had been a juror at the 2013 Venice Film Festival, and thought that ''Under the Skin'' deserved a film score prize. Composer [[Ryuichi Sakamoto]], also on the jury, was enthralled by Levi’s bold score for the film, and he and Larraín spoke passionately of her accomplishment, which led to the collaboration on ''Jackie''. Levi was nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Original Score|Best Original Score]] at the [[89th Academy Awards]], making her the fifth woman nominated in the category,{{cite web |url=http://www.newyorker.com/culture/persons-of-interest/mica-levis-anti-musical-soundtracks |title=Mica Levi's Intensely Unconventional Film Scores |last=Beauman |first=Ned |date=February 23, 2017 |website=[[The New Yorker]] |access-date=April 1, 2017}} but lost to [[Justin Hurwitz]] for ''[[La La Land (film)|La La Land]]''. ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2"| Album details !| Peak positions |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! style="width:40px;"| [[UK Albums Chart|UK]] |- | 2009 | style="text-align:left;"| '''''[[Jewellery (album)|Jewellery]]''''' (with the Shapes) * Release date: 9 March 2009 * Label: [[Matthew Herbert|Accidental Records]] and [[Rough Trade Records]] | 196 |- | 2012 | style="text-align:left;"| '''''[[Never (album)|Never]]''''' (with the Shapes){{cite web|url=http://thequietus.com/articles/08669-kwesachu-vol-2-mixtape-download |title=News | DOWNLOAD: Kwesachu Vol. 2 |publisher=[[The Quietus]] |date=2012-04-30 |accessdate=2017-01-10}} * Release date: 23 July 2012 * Label: Rough Trade Records | - |- | 2014 | style="text-align:left;"| '''''[[Under the Skin (2013)|Under the Skin]]''''' ([[Soundtrack|OST]]){{cite web|author=Jayson Greene |url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19239-mica-levi-under-the-skin-ost/ |title=Mica Levi: Under the Skin OST Album Review |publisher=Pitchfork |date=2014-04-17 |accessdate=2017-01-10}} * Release date: 17 March 2014 * Label: [[Milan Records]] and Rough Trade Records | - |- | 2015 | style="text-align:left;"| '''''Good Sad Happy Bad''''' (with the Shapes) * Release date: 11 September 2015 * Label: Rough Trade Records | - |- | 2016 | style="text-align:left;"| '''''Remain Calm''''' (with Oliver Coates) * Release date: 25 November 2016 * Label: Slip Records | - |- | 2016 | style="text-align:left;"| '''''[[Jackie (2016 film)|Jackie]]''''' ([[Soundtrack|OST]]) * Release date: 16 December 2016 * Label: Milan | - |} ===Live albums=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2"| Album details !| Peak positions |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! style="width:40px;"| [[UK Albums Chart|UK]] |- | 2011 | style="text-align:left;"| '''''Chopped and Screwed''''' (with the Shapes and the [[London Sinfonietta]]) * Release date: 23 March 2011 (Australia), 28 March 2011 (U.K./Rest of world) * Label: [[Remote Control Records|Remote Control]] and Rough Trade Records | -- |} ===Mixtapes=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! Year ! Mixtape details |- ||2009 |align="left"| '''''Filthy Friends''''' *Released: 9 February 2009 *Label: Self-released *Formats: [[CD]], Digital download |- ||2010 |align="left"| '''''[[Kwesachu Mixtape Vol.1]]''''' with [[Kwes.]] *Released: 5 June 2009 *Label: Self-released *Formats: [[Cassette tape|Cassette Tape]], Digital download |- |rowspan="2"|2011 |align="left"| '''''Meat Batch''''' with Kwake Bass *Released: 22 March 2011 *Label: For BTS Radio *Formats: Digital download |- |align="left"| '''''Chopped & Screwed Mixtape''''' with Brother May *Released: 2011 *Label: Self-released *Formats: Digital download |- ||2012 |align="left"| '''''Kwesachu Mixtape Vol.2''''' with Kwes. *Released: 30 April 2012 *Label: Self-released *Formats: Cassette Tape, Digital download |- ||2014 |align="left"| '''''Feeling Romantic Feeling Tropical Feeling Ill''''' *Released: 27 November 2014 *Label: Self-released ([[Demdike Stare]] Self-Released) *Formats: Cassette Tape, Digital download |} ===Singles / EPs=== * "Golden Phone" (2008) * "Lips" (2009) * "Turn Me Well" (2009) * "I'm Not Dancing" (2013) (with Tirzah) * "No Romance" (2014) (with Tirzah) * "Thinking of You" (2015) (with Nozinja, Tirzah and Mumdance) * "Make It Up" (2015) (with Tirzah) * "Taz and May Vids" (2016) (with Tirzah and Brother May) * "Looking Up at the Sun / Mash One" (2016) (with Good Sad Happy Bad) * "Clothes Wear Me" (2016) (with KEVIN) * "Delete Beach" (2017) ===Production=== * [[The xx|Romy of The xx]] - "[[Closer (Ne-Yo song)|Closer]] (cover of [[Ne-Yo]]'s song)" (2009) (co-produced with [[Kwes]]) * [[DELS]] - "Violina" and "Melting Patterns" (2013) * Tirzah - "I'm Not Dancing EP" (2013) * Tirzah - "No Romance EP" (2014) * [[DELS]] - "RGB" (2014) * Tirzah - "Make It Up EP" (2015) * [[Wiki (rapper)|Wiki]] - "Cherry Tree" (2015) (co-produced with [[Ratking (group)|Sporting Life]]) * Brother May - "May and Meeks" (2016) * Tirzah - "Devotion" (2018) ===As featured artist=== * [[Speech Debelle]] - "Better Days" (2009) * [[Dean Blunt|Babyfather]] - "God Hour" (2016) * [[Mount Kimbie]] - "Marilyn" (2017) ==Awards and recognition== [[European Film Awards]], [[European Film Award for Best Composer|Best Composer]] for soundtrack to ''[[Under the Skin (2013 film)|Under the Skin]]''{{cite web|url = https://www.europeanfilmacademy.org/News-detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews%255Btt_news%255D=288&cHash=ce956284f7312daf001845328bc96277|title = European Film Academy : THE 27TH EUROPEAN FILM AWARDS: WINNERS|website = Europeanfilmacademy.org|access-date = 2016-03-12}} (2014) [[British Academy Film Awards|BAFTA]] nomination for soundtrack to ''Under the Skin''{{cite web|url = http://www.bafta.org/film/awards/original-music-nominees-in-2015|title = Original Music Nominees in 2015|website = Bafta.org|access-date = 2016-03-12}} (2014) Los Angeles Film Critics Award, Best Music Score for soundtrack to ''Under the Skin''. Tied with [[Jonny Greenwood]].{{cite web|url = http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6385939/la-film-critics-awards-jonny-greenwood-mica-levi-tie-in-best-music-score|title = L.A. Film Critics Awards: Jonny Greenwood & Mica Levi Tie in Best Music Score Category|website = Billboard|access-date = 2016-03-12}} (2014) Nominated – [[BAFTA Award for Best Film Music]] for ''[[Jackie (2016 film)|Jackie]]'' (2016) Nominated – [[Academy Award for Best Original Score]] for ''Jackie'' (2016) ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://micachu.biz/ Micachu website] * [http://accidentalrecords.com/portfolio/michachu/ Accidental Records profile] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/hi/music/newsid_7543000/7543872.stm [[BBC]] newsbeat: Is Micachu the next big thing?] * [http://www.roughtraderecords.com/artist/micachu Michachu page at [[Rough Trade Records]]] * [http://www.ruadebaixo.com/micachu-the-shapes.html Interview - December 2009 -(Portuguese web-zine) ] * [http://www.btsradio.com/html/micachu-vs-kwake-bass-meat-batch-bts-radio-mix.html Micachu vs Kwake Bass "Meat Batch Mix"] on Andrew Meza's BTS Radio * [http://reviews.headphonecommute.com/2014/12/12/interview-with-mica-levi/ Interview with Mica Levi] on Headphone Commute, December 2014 * {{IMDb name|id=5908010}} {{European Film Award for Best Composer}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1987 births]] [[Category:English female guitarists]] [[Category:English experimental musicians]] [[Category:British alternative rock musicians]] [[Category:English record producers]] [[Category:Grime music artists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Singers from London]] [[Category:People from Surrey]] [[Category:People educated at Purcell School]] [[Category:Women in electronic music]] [[Category:Female film score composers]] [[Category:English film score composers]] [[Category:English female pop singers]] [[Category:British people of Romanian descent]]
